Speaker: Mr FAWCETT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister update the House on the results of the government's Tough on Drugs strategy?

Speaker: Mr ABBOTT
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the member for Wakefield for his question. I can inform him that, since the government announced its Tough on Drugs strategy in November 1997, it has committed some $1 billion to drug education, drug rehabilitation and, most importantly, drug law enforcement. The results show that the war on drugs is not doomed to be lost, especially if policy is based on a clear understanding that there is no safe way to use illicit drugs. Since 1999, heroin deaths have declined by some 300 per cent. The number of Australians who report that they have used illicit drugs has dropped from 22 per cent to 15 per cent since 1998. Since 1998, the number of people who regularly use heroin has dropped by 12,000. The number of people who regularly use marijuana has dropped by 180,000, which is just as well because there is increasing evidence of the clear links between marijuana use and subsequent serious mental illness. A 2002 British Medical Journal article found that heavy cannabis use increased the risk of schizophrenia sixfold. In 2001 an American Journal of Psychiatry article found that cannabis use increased the risk of depression fourfold. Last year a Sydney university paper found that regular cannabis use was associated with subsequent increases in suicidal behaviour and psychotic illnesses. I can inform the House that this year the government has spent some $13 million on a campaign against the use of illicit drugs. I would ask the states to be careful lest any moves towards further decriminalisation of marijuana should send precisely the wrong message about something which has the potential to be a very dangerous drug indeed. Fisheries: Management

Speaker: Mr KATTER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. The minister would be aware of recent media reports that 10,000 foreign fishing vessels are operating in Australian waters. Is the minister aware that the average Australian fish catch is 276,000 tonnes whilst the average for the United States, with only half our coastline, is 4,263,000 tonnes? In light of this, will the minister release to the House the scientific evidence from GBRMPA and other sources which shows that a reduction of fish stocks in Australian waters justifies this and the previous government's shutdown of nearly two-thirds of the Australian fishing industry and the destruction of 4,000 jobs? Further and finally, would the minister advise whether Senator Ian Macdonald's decision to reduce Australia's fishing fleet from 1,200 boats to 600 boats indicates that the United States is being criminally irresponsible by overfishing or whether Minister Macdonald is a destructive embarrassment to the government?

Speaker: Mr MCGAURAN
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for his question. The government place the greatest priority and importance on policing our northern waters. To date in 2005, 233 illegal fishing vessels have been seized and the government have invested $180 million to deter illegal fishing in our northern waters. At the same time, we have used a multi-agency approach-the latest example, in October, being Operation Clearwater II, which involved Customs, Coastwatch, AFMA, the Federal Police and state bodies. The message has been very strong to illegal fishers that they risk severe penalties, including prosecution and the loss of their catch, their fishing equipment and even their vessel. It is a very strong message that we are taking to a number of the Indonesian fishing villages from whence these vessels originate. I would caution the honourable member against using figures of 10,000 or 11,000 sightings of vessels because there are often multiple sightings; there are a number of vessels transiting in Australian waters. That is in no way to diminish the seriousness of the problem or the commitment in energy and resources the government is bringing to solve it. The member asked me about GBRMPA. My view is that it is largely a scientific organisation. Its data, unless there is some exceptional reason, should be available. Transparency and accountability are required for GBRMPA, as they are for any other government business agency, so I will make inquiries. If there is no reason that that information is not available, it should be. Turning now to the allegation of the United States overfishing, Senator Ian Macdonald is an outstanding fisheries minister. He is responsible for a $220 million structural adjustment package that has been universally welcomed by the fishing industry far and wide. It has as its centrepiece $150 million for a one-off, capped buy-out focused on reducing excess fishing capacity in those Commonwealth managed fisheries. The member raises a point about internationally managed fisheries that are excluded from the package, so his criticisms of Senator Macdonald are utterly ill conceived with regard to the structural adjustment package and unfair overall. Iraq

Speaker: Mr HENRY
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister update the House on what assistance Australia is providing to support this month's elections in Iraq and, more broadly, democracy in that country? Is he aware of any alternative views?

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE
text: I thank the honourable member for Hasluck very much for the question and say how much I appreciate the interest of the member in serious issues. The Iraqis will be going to the polls, as many members on this side know, on 15 December to elect a new national assembly. There are 307 political entities registered for the election, contesting 275 seats. Given that it is a regionally based election, there are 230 seats which are divided amongst 18 governorates in proportion to the numbers registered in each province. So the results are likely to be different-for a number of reasons-from the results of the election which was held back on 30 January, which was a whole-ofnation election. Honourable members on this side of the House will be pleased to hear that 15½ million Iraqis have registered to vote in these elections. Australia, as I mentioned last week, is providing support for that democratic process, including for out-of-country voting for Iraqis who reside here in Australia. That includes providing an electoral adviser. It is expected that the 11,000 people in Australia who are eligible to vote in Iraq will vote, so the voting here in Australia is not insignificant. There will be new polling centres in Adelaide, Perth and Brisbane in addition to the ones in Sydney and Melbourne which were previously provided. It is another illustration of the very strong commitment the government has to democracy in Iraq and to ensuring that that country is able to achieve, in the long term, a peaceful, democratic and free future. Likewise, we have taken the same view with Afghanistan. Are there any alternatives? The alternative to the policy that we are pursuing in relation to Iraq is the 31st policy that has been put forward by the Leader of the Opposition. In an interview with Mike Carlton, the interviewer of choice for the Labor Party, the Leader of the Opposition said that the government should withdraw our troops from Iraq-very much a reflection of what his predecessor said. The point is the Labor Party believes that we should have troops in Afghanistan in order to support the evolving democracy in that country-and I agree with that, of course-but the Labor Party does not believe we should keep troops in Iraq to support the emerging democracy and to get the terrorists in that country. If anyone can work out the logic of that Mr Rudd- Mr Speaker, on a point of order: the question the minister was asked was about the Mr Howard interjecting Mr Rudd-It is, Prime Minister.

Speaker: Mrs ELLIOT
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I move: That this House: (1) notes that petrol prices in regional areas dramatically increased and are averaging well over $1.20 per litre; (2) recognises that these prices are becoming prohibitive for families and small businesses and are adversely impacting on tourism-an industry which many regional areas rely on; and (3) calls on the Government to direct the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to formally monitor prices under Part VIIA of the Trade Practices Act 1974. The cost of petrol is hurting families and businesses in regional areas across Australia, and my electorate of Richmond is no exception. Locals are telling me loud and clear that they are doing it tough and they are sick and tired of this government doing nothing about the massive increases in petrol prices. Businesses are finding it harder and harder to keep in the black because their stock prices, delivery costs, running costs and production costs have gone up-all flowing on from the huge rises in petrol prices. To add to this, soaring petrol prices are having a huge impact on our lucrative domestic tourism industry as families realise it is just too expensive to get on the road for their holidays. The Northern Rivers region, which includes my electorate of Richmond, is one of the most popular tourist destinations in Australia. Consequently, tourism is one of our most important industries and many local businesses depend either directly or indirectly on the tourist dollar for their survival. For local families, the cost of living-or simply surviving-is going up and up all the time. Health care, food and housing prices have all risen, and petrol prices have skyrocketed to over $1.20 a litre in parts of my electorate. The Howard government tells us that petrol prices are solely dependent on world prices and that nothing can be done. This is not much comfort to the mums and dads in my electorate who are breaking the have family budget at the bowser every week. The government is just plain wrong. Global prices are not the only factor impacting on petrol prices. We all saw the press reports last week on petrol price gouging and Caltex's staggering profits. An article in the Daily Telegraph on 29 November 2005 entitled ‘Petrol giant's $70 million rip-off' said: Spiralling profits at Australia's biggest oil refiner have at last revealed the true extent of the petrol gouge. What this means is that, months after world prices have dropped, motorists are still being charged at the bowser on the basis of higher world prices. The profit Caltex made on each barrel of refined crude oil surged from $9.54 to an average of $15 in the second half of the year. So we are not talking about small bickies. Caltex revealed a staggering $70 million jump in post-tax profit to $420 million. Ordinary Australians are footing the bill for this profit, especially those from regional areas such as my electorate of Richmond. The General Manager of Fueltrac, the price monitoring firm, Geoff Trotter, said that oil companies have especially not passed on any price decreases to rural and regional centres of Australia. In short, where petrol companies do not have to compete, they simply will not. So in regional centres, where wages are lower, unemployment is higher and people can least afford it, we are being ripped off the most at the bowser by oil refineries. In the words of the President of the NRMA, Alan Evans, ‘the Howard government must get off its behind'. And it certainly should. Federal Labor is calling on the Howard government to show some leadership on this issue and do something about it. First, we need an ACCC inquiry into petrol prices and we need it now. Local people are constantly telling me that some action has to be taken. We need to have that inquiry started immediately. The ACCC themselves have said something funny is going on. The rest of Australia knows something funny is going on, so it is about time the Howard government did something about it. It is not enough for the Prime Minister to sit down with his big mates from Caltex, BP and Shell and let them satisfy him that they are not petrol gouging. We need an independent ACCC to monitor prices and ensure that consumers are being protected from the price gouging around Australia. Second, we need to develop a long-term strategy to reduce our dependence on overseas oil. This is vitally important for our ture. If we take no action now, we face the very real possibility of $5 per litre prices the pump within 10 years. Labor's blueprint for developing the Australian fuel industry outlines how we can foster an Australian fuel industry and provide relief to families at the petrol bowser in the long term. While Mr Howard sits on his hands, we as a nation are becoming increasingly dependent on foreign oil. We need to put measures in place immediately to increase the use of Australian so that we are less vulnerable to external price shocks. We need to develop existing alternatives such as liquid petroleum gas, ethanol and biodiesel and emerging alternatives such as compressed natural gas, liquid fuel from gas and stored electricity. Australians deserve a government that is willing to show some leadership on petrol gouging and a plan for the future. People in regional areas are doing it tough. They see petrol prices increase day by day and week by week and they want to have something done about it. They need to be relieved of the burden of having to continue to pay these high prices. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Is the motion seconded? Mr Brendan O'Connor-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: O'Connor) (3.52 pm)Petrol prices will always be a significant issue among the Australian people because, per capita, they are large consumers of that product. But popular solutions such as ‘the government should do something about it' were even rejected by the member for Rankin in a very intelligent paper that put together the realities of the petrol market, with the point being that, whilst you can accuse people such as refiners of profit gouging, those figures are not supported when one looks at the international marketplace in fuwhich Australia properly operates. For instance, we have international prices for crude at oil that are measured in Australia by the Malaysian Tapis rate, and we have retail prices for which the benchmark is Singaporean Mogas 95 unleaded. So if there has been price gouging, as the member for Richmond has just alleged, one would think things would be a little different. Obviously, the gross profit margin of refiners is the difference between the Tapis price and the Mogas fuels price, which was $6.25 on average during 2004, before we saw this massive escalation in world crude prices. In August 2005, as the price of crude started to increase, that margin was $5.96. In September 2005 the margin had increased to $11.29, and in October 2005 it had crept back down to what one could almost call the average at $7.42. But what have we been told about this escalation in the price of refined product? There is an international shortage of refinery capacity. So the member for Richmond wants us to believe that, if by some regulatory mechanism we keep screwing down the retail margin or the margins available to fuel refiners, they will go and build a new refinery and will spend the hundreds of millions that governments on both sides have demanded they spend to improve the quality and reduce the emissions of the fuels we use at this stage. I note that Caltex got a mention from the member for Richmond. It is a company that is struggling to meet those particular requirements, and that might be because it is the only publicly traded fuel refiner in Australia. Where do those profits go that the member for Richmond complains about? In many cases they go to union super funds. We all get this wonderful view from time to time that profits are consumed by the chief executive or some other powerful individual in the world when our marketplace today recycles profits into the investment community, with credit to be given, as I have been reminded previously by the member for Gorton, to an initiative of the Keating government-or Keating as Treasurer, I have forgotten which side of the fence he was on at the time. It was at about the time that he did not put in two tax returns, as I recollect-a matter that has always been ignored on the Labor side because they say they knew nothing about it. The reality is that, in these matters, investment has been created by compulsory superannuation, and no doubt on the computer screens every major super company has a share in Caltex. But the reality is that in Adelow incomes. laide there still sits a mothballed refinery. Why was it closed? Because the margins were insufficient to keep a relatively small operation open. So that is the first thing. In my remaining couple of minutes I do want to complain about some of the differentials that exist in the prices between city and country. I cannot understand them. It costs half a cent a litre per 100 kilometres to freight fuel by road to virtually anywhere in Australia, and there are some pretty big outlets outside of the capital cities. This economy of scale argument is relative, but not always. I will never know why those prices have to jump in that fashion.

Speaker: Mr BRENDAN OCONNOR
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I thank the member for Richmond for placing the issue about petrol prices on the Notice Paper. It is an important motion, because it allows us an opportunity to consider the consequences of very high petrol prices and the adverse effects on ordinary consumers of petrol. There are a number of areas relating to this consumer concern. There has already been some discussion about the way in which the ACCC should regulate how petrol companies behave and, indeed, about the relative difference between crude oil and produced oil prices. Why is there a much greater increase in prices of petrol at the petrol pump compared with the price of barrels of crude oil? That is the concern that a number of members on this side of the House have had with the hike. As members of this place who are sensitive to concerns of constituents would know, the massive increase in petrol prices has had an adverse effect on families in terms of making sure they can pick up their kids from school and go to work and get home by car. These everyday things have become more difficult for many who are on As I have said before in this type of debate, we can look at a number of options. I have said before that there was an opportunity to consider cutting excise tax, and that is certainly an option, but the government has chosen to do nothing. The Reserve Bank could obviously consider tightening monetary policy, and the government could also have considered cutting income tax. The one option that I do not think has been considered as regards a response by government has been the cutting of excise tax. There is no doubt that monetary policy can deal with any inflationary consequences of an oil price shock. Monetary policy can generally squeeze away any inflation. It is slow but sure. The difficulty is that if that is the sum total of the policy response then the consequences for economic activity, as I have said before, are very painful. So I suggest an answer may be something that simultaneously alleviates the need for tighter monetary policy and offsets the worse consequences of any tightening that occurs. A cut in fuel excise taxes may be that magic bullet. One way to describe the argument for cutting fuel excise duty is that, if the government does not do something, the Reserve Bank surely will. The economy faces stagflationary pressures. The sensible response is some policy change which is price-decreasing and which also encourages economic activity. A fuel excise tax cut does that. None of the other policy options does so. The essential conceptual problem which the government view entails is that, if it as if it is independent, it means it is irrelefuel vant. Just because the Reserve Bank is independent does not mean that its likely actions and reactions can be ignored. If a macroeconomic shock is large or sustained, the consequences are known. There is a policy response which is effective, macroeconomically responsible and powerfully superior to the main alternative. This last point bears emphasis. It would appear that the government proposes to do nothing with a view to later cutting income taxes. No doubt the Treasurer would like to delay any further tax cuts to coincide with his challenge to the Prime Minister for the prime ministership next year. I think it is important that the government looks at ways to respond to this particular crisis. It is fair to say that the hikes in petrol price have been on the decline in recent weeks for a number of reasons, but the hikes allow us to consider whether we use fiscal policy or monetary policy. They allow us to consider examining alternative fuels. Allowing this potential crisis to precipitate proper consideration of taxation and environmental concerns allows the parliament and parliamentarians to-I hope-confront issues and provide answers for future problems. I suggest parliamentarians consider this. The government should investigate the options available for cutting excise tax because I think it can provide the benefits without the disadvantages associated with other forms of taxation policy.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Mitchell) (4.02 pm)The motion on petrol prices is an important one. It would be good if we could do something about this issue. But the fact of the matter is this: of the 30 OECD countries, we have got the fourth lowest petrol prices. Ours are much lower than most countries in the world. In fact, one of the reasons for the low price of petrol in Australia compared with acts other countries is the low taxes applied to by the Australian government. This was brought about in part by a decision not to continue the indexation of excise that was introduced by the Australian Labor Party. The fact of the matter is that if Labor's policy had continued then the price of petrol would have been roughly 14.7c per litre higher than it currently is. That is the story that we confront today. We have got the Australian Labor Party saying that we should do something about petrol prices; the Australian government has. The member for Richmond ought to remember that half of her constituents are driving across the border to Queensland to fill up their cars because the Queensland government is actually giving back some of the GST funds provided by the Commonwealth with the changeover in exthe cise and GST at the time of the introduction of the goods and services tax. The government in New South Wales is not interested in anything but raising more taxes everywhere it can with every means it can think of. It is interesting to note that the ACCC does conduct informal inquiries and keeps a check on oil prices. Its summaries are very useful. Its summary indicates that the higher margins recorded in recent months are primarily due to the shortage of supply of refined product in the US following Hurricane Katrina and the Chinese government's recent decision to take steps to halt the export of petrol because of an acute shortage of fuel in several of China's southern and eastern provinces. So we have got the US and China gobbling up fuel. I refer to an article by the member for Rankin, which I thought was a pretty interesting sort of article and at complete odds with what has been said in the House today. He said on 20 July this year that it is simply not feasible or practicable to legislate lower prices. He said: China is burning oil products for its tion as if there is no tomorrow. Added to the price increase from Chinese consumption is a terrorism premium on the world oil price. He concluded his comments by saying: So no, there are no magic solutions to high petrol prices. It might seem clever to pretend there are, but the Australian people are smarter than that. The comments of a prominent member of the Australian Labor Party are completely at odds with the presentations here today by fellow members of the Australia Labor Party. The support for Australian families by this government has been substantial. Our costs for energy rose only 13.4 per cent in the September quarter, compared with an OECD average of 21.1 per cent. In the September quarter the CPI increased by 0.9 per cent, including the price increase in petrol. If we exclude the price of petrol in the CPI increase, the CPI increase was 2.2 per cent. The increase was 0.9 per cent for petrol; that means 3.1 per cent is the actual increase in the CPI. So the impact is significant but restrained, as it is not elsewhere in the world. For the 2005-06 year, Australians will be able to earn up to $63,000 and stay in the 30 per cent tax bracket. From 1 July 2006 this will rise to $70,000. So there are tax concessions coming through consistently, year after year and as the budget can afford in the government's management of the Australian economy. The ACCC informally monitors. It gives prices. It monitors 4,000 sites. It puts out a regular price list. It conducts random sampling of prices throughout Australia. Recently, in Ballarat, it took a number of retailers to court for fixing prices. The ACCC is on the job. It is doing what it is designed to do. I believe that the government is managing high oil prices and high petrol prices as industrialisabest it can. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Can I respond to some of the comments made by the member for Mitchell. I would argue that most of what he said indicates exactly why there should be a legislative requirement on the ACCC to do exactly that.

Speaker: Mr CADMAN
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Your own members don't agree with you.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: While the member for Rankin did make the point that there is no silver bullet, it does not exempt the government from attempting to do something about an issue that is impacting on all of our electorates. In my electorate and that of the member for Throsby, a large number of people commute to work. According to most recent studies, it is probably the largest commuter corridor in Australia. Most of the 16,000 people a day who travel into Sydney in order to obtain work are doing that trip by car. For many of those people, the experience a few months ago of spiralling petrol prices created a great deal of anguish for them and a great deal of pressure on their family budgets. People can come into this House and say that there are always international pressures and other forces causing this and that we cannot be exempt from them-that is absolutely true-but it does not mean that the government can therefore hold their hands up and say, ‘Unfortunately, that will flow through to family budgets and there is not much that we can do about it.' There is a great deal that the government can do about it, including ensuring a legislative requirement for the ACCC to monitor and report on petrol prices. Despite comments and explanations as to why the spikes have occurred, the most constant monitors of petrol prices are family members who go to a petrol station every two to three days-particularly those who commute to work-to fill up their cars. They see quite clearly that when oil prices at the international level go up, petrol prices very quickly go up at their local petrol station. When they hear reports that the international price of oil is going back down, they see that petrol prices at the pump where they are filling up are very slow to go back down. That is the reality for constituents. We consistently having concerns expressed about the monitoring of petrol prices. That is why I support the member for Richmond's motion about petrol prices today. There should be a requirement that petrol prices be consistently monitored. If there is nothing smelly or dirty about the way the price of petrol is being set, what is the problem with having it monitored? Mr Johnson-They already monitor it.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Not in a formal and ongoing manner, as the member for Ryan very well knows. If there were no problem, the positive outcome would be a six-monthly report that went out to the general public. That would at least enable them to make assessments. If members want to get up in this House and say that there is absolutely no problem, I challenge them to put that on the front page of their next newsletter to their constituents. When they do that, I will accept that they are genuine and sincere in the comments that they make in this House. For any members who wish to send me a copy of their next newsletter to their electorate, outlining that there is no great problem with petrol prices, I will be very glad to come into this place and acknowledge the genuineness of the comments that they make in this place. As much as government members may not like to acknowledge it, there is a rolling sense of discontent amongst families in our communities about their capacity to manage spending an amount of their income on things that they choose rather than on costs that they feel are an unnecessary burden on them. If people in this House think that the GST is a forgotten issue, I say to themMr Johnson-There have been two elections since the GST.

Speaker: Ms BIRD
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Perhaps the member recognises that people do not always react immediately and that there is significant resentare ment about the impact of the GST on family budgets. That is being compounded by things like petrol costs. I suggest to you that, under the new industrial regime, people will be concerned about whether they will get their overtime and penalty rates. In many households, they are the only things keeping their budgets above the red line of debt. That will be a real concern for many families. If members want to laugh, I suggest that they get out and talk to families, because that is the reality for those households. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I am pleased to speak on the motion on petrol prices moved by the member for Richmond, because it is another example of the opposition and, in this case, the member for Richmond gilding the lily. The presentation by the member for Cunningham, who has just spoken, is another example of an incomplete contribution in every sense of the word. This is another motion that tries to challenge the credibility of the Howard government, and it fails miserably. The motion fails to take into account, as my colleagues have already suggested, that a former shadow minister of the Labor Party, the opposition, has written an article in the Canberra Times about all the factors that contribute to the increase in petrol prices and all the dynamics that are involved with rising prices where that occurs. I want to quote from that article because it is very instructive. The member for Rankin says: Australia's record petrol prices have one cause and one cause only-high world prices. The OPEC oil-producing countries are pumping oil out of the ground as fast as they can, but not as fast as the world want to use it. China is burning oil products for its industrialisation as if no tomorrow. Nobody really anticipated how fast the Chinese economy could grow and how thirsty for oil it is.' Anyone listening to this address or watching it here in the parliament would be very interested to know what this motion is about. I want to read the motion by the member for Richmond. She asks: That this House: (1) notes that petrol prices in regional areas have dramatically increased and are averaging well over $1.20 per litre ... The sum of $1.20 per litre is the essence of the motion. I actually took the opportunity today to have a look at what petrol prices were in the electorate of the member for Richmond. Lo and behold, what do I discover? Remarkable prices that stand well below the price of $1.20 per litre, as suggested by the member for Richmond. That is another superb example of a federal Labor opposition member gilding the lily and failing to be complete in the entire story. In Murwillumbah, the price of petrol is $1.10.9; in Kingscliff-in the electorate of Richmond-it is $1.17; in Brunswick Heads, it is $1.14.9; in Alstonville, it is $1.15; in Hastings Point, it is $1.08.5; in Tweed Heads, it is $1.09.9; in Bangalow, it is $1.14.9; in Uki, it is $1.15.9; and, in Tyalgum, it is $1.15.9. That is in sharp contrast to the motion that says that regional petrol prices are $1.20 per litre. It is very important for members of the coalition to remember-and I am sure they do not need any reminding-to always be careful regarding what members opposite say. It is very important because they quite often fail to be complete and accurate in what they allege. When we compare petrol prices in this country to international prices, such comparisons reveal that we are better placed than many of our international competitors. This country enjoys more competitive prices than there is most places in the world. We rank fourth lowest among OECD countries for petrol prices, according to the International Energy Agency. Only the USA, Mexico and Canada have lower petrol prices. I am highly disappointed that someone who is so concerned about petrol prices and has moved in this House a motion on petrol prices fails to sit in the chamber whilst this motion is being discussed. The motion also refers to jobs. As the Treasurer mentioned in question time today, the Howard government has created over 1.7 million jobs since its election in 1996. (Time expired)

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The member for Ryan will have leave to continue speaking when and if the debate is resumed. Health

Speaker: Mrs MAY
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I move: That this House: (1) recognises that: (a) good health is the single most important factor necessary for individuals to lead happy and successful life; (b) what individuals think, eat and the amount of activity they undertake are important determinants of health and well-being; (c) Australians have a high incidence of preventable diseases that are influenced by lifestyle and behaviour including cardiovascular diseases, cholesterol, obesity and diabetes; (d) for many Australians, health is simply access to medical goods and services; and (e) once illness has taken hold, because of the mind/body connection, many do not have the mindset to better improve their health until they get a ‘scare' which ten comes too late; and (2) calls on the Australian Government to: (a) educate youngsters in schools about health and ways of preventing illness; (b) educate couples before starting a family on healthy lifestyles for children; (c) refocus the training of our doctors from ill health to good health with an emphasis on preventative care; and (d) implement a National Health Strategy with a strong focus on preventative health. There is no doubt that healthier people are happier people. They remain in the work force beyond traditional retirement age, they are more productive and they require fewer support systems in later life. In fact, overall, if one is healthy, life is pretty good. But this country is facing the burden of chronic disease, and the effect of chronic disease is reflected in the increasing incidence of disability and premature death. The rise of obesity is alarming, particularly in young Australians. The level of diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, cancer and cholesterol are all increasing-diseases that in many cases are preventable. These diseases are often influa enced by lifestyle choices and behaviour, but the levels still keep climbing because Australians are not taking responsibility for their own health. We have one of the best health systems in the world. We have high standards of treatment and preventative care-and of course there is always the local public hospital and the specialist care that is available to all in this country-but all too often individuals believe they are invincible and that a trip to the GP will solve any health problems. It amazes me that individuals will continue down a destructive path with regard to their health, even armed with all the information that is available about healthy living: how to of- eat, how to cook our food and how we must take up some exercise and breathe in fresh air, have adequate sleep and rest, throw out the cigarettes and cut back on the alcoholeverything in moderation. We do not need to stop living but, to live and enjoy life, we need to monitor our behaviour. There is nothing wrong with a glass of red, but too many glasses of red every night and eventually one's health will suffer. More than half the Australian population is overweight or obese. These are shocking statistics when you consider that an estimated 1.5 million of those people are aged under 18. Childhood obesity in Australia is rising at the rate of one per cent each year, and over half of all young Australians will be overweight by 2025 unless parents, governments and the community start addressing the problem together. An overweight child often becomes an overweight adult. In fact, the AMA have said that nutrition is the key in the fight against the obesity epidemic. They launched a plan last week with some simple steps on addressing poor nutrition in babies and children, the adult population and older Australians. The steps are simple; it is basic common sense. As a country, we need to take heed of those steps and get serious about the health of this nation. Australians who do not take responsibility for their own health just expect that, by havon ing access to medical goods and services, they will be fine. I wonder how many think about the long-term effects that an unhealthy lifestyle will have on them. The health system cannot fix every health problem, but the burden on the health system both in an economic and social sense is enormous. We must not give up. Through our schools and local sporting groups and community bodies we must find ways of introducing healthy lifestyle programs. We need to get our kids away from the computers and onto the playing fields. Around 40 per cent of children aged between five and 14 years of age do not participate in any organised sport. The federal government has gone some way in addressing this situation by supporting a number of programs to help address the very real problem that will have long-term effects on a whole generation of Australians. The parliament legislated in 2004, requiring schools to include at least two hours of physical activity per week in their curriculum for children in primary and junior high schools. There are healthy eating programs supported by school canteens and education staff, but more needs to be done. The AMA has made recommendations that include the banning of selling chocolates and lollies as fundraisers and banning junk food advertising. Some people would say they are extreme measures, but it is time for extreme measures if we as a nation want to ensure the young people of this country lead healthy, happy, productive and active lives. We also need more emphasis on preventative medicine. Our health work force needs to be skilled in delivering interventions to address the major risk factors for chronic disease such as smoking, poor nutrition, risky and high-risk alcohol use and physical inactivity. But it is not a one-way street. Quite frankly, every Australian needs to take the personal responsibility of their health. It is not the job of governments to continually fund soaring health costs if individuals are negligent and do not heed the warnings of lifestyle choices and the impact those choices have on their shortand long-term health. This is a partnership, but I fear we have reached a time when extreme measures, or maybe even incentives, must be put in place so that individuals take control of their health today and in the future. I would like to take this opportunity of thanking my parliamentary colleagues for their contributions to this motion today.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Is the motion seconded? Miss Jackie Kelly-I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

Speaker: Ms LIVERMORE
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I support the motion moved by the member for MCPherson because I am also a firm believer in preventative medicine and physical activity. There is no avoiding the statistics warning us of a looming and largely preventable health crisis in Australia. We will all pay the price unless we start giving greater priority to preventative health measures-and start right now. For example, the government estimates that the cost of obesity in Australia is between $680 million and $1.239 billion per year. The AMA estimates that around 15 per cent of our children are already overweight and that that figure will increase by one per cent each year so that, by the year 2025, half of Australia's children will be overweight. Figures for Australian adults are even worse: 58 per cent of Australian men and 42 per cent of Australian women are currently classed as overweight or obese. And, with overweight children being 50 per cent more likely to become overweight adults, this constitutes a real problem both now and into the future. Obesity is a risk factor for a number of diseases including diabetes, coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke and cancer. To combat the increasing levels of obesity within the Australian population, Australians need to be educated about the health risks posed by obesity and the benefits of incorporating physical activity into our lives. There are numerous programs across the country aimed at increasing Australians' physical activity levels. Today I would like to talk about a fantastic community based program which many people in the chamber will already be aware of: the 10,000 Steps program. This program began in Rockhampton in 2001 as a Queensland Health funded wholeof-community project to encourage greater physical activity. Rockhampton was chosen as the location for a two-year trial of the gram due to its residents' typical level of activity. The program is based at Central Queensland University and has a number of other active partners throughout Rockhampton. The program has consistently shown results and has rapidly spread to many other centres across Australia. 10,000 Steps now boasts 372 providers and has logged over three billion steps. The program uses the message of 10,000 steps per day as a way to encourage people in the community to increase their physical activity levels. Participants in the program use a pedometer to measure the number of steps they take per day with an aim of consistently reaching 10,000 per day. The 10,000 Steps Workplace Challenge has become a particularly popular program across the country with the 10,000 Steps program estimating that over 40,000 people have taken part in that element of the initiative. Indeed, several Commonwealth departments and agencies, including the tax office, Finance and Administration, Centrelink and Treasury, have taken part in the challenge. The challenge consists of workplaces organising teams who log the number of steps per day that each team takes. The goal is to increase participants' awareness of their level of physical activity. By taking note of the number of steps they take each day as part of their normal activities, participants can see where they are deficient and need to increase their physical activity in order to maximise the health benefits. The Rockhampton community have really gotten behind this program, and several local groups, including the Central Queensland University, the Rockhampton City Council, Queensland Health and local media outlets, have been heavily involved in promoting the program. For example, the Rockhampton City Council has established a number of prowalking paths around the city under the 10,000 Steps logo and has also set up a program of organised activity in local parks to encourage people to get out, get active and get moving. The 10,000 Steps program is a fantastic tool that is spreading across the country. The program shows people that physical activity does not have to be time intensive, cost a lot of money or be too strenuous. The message is clearly that everyone can do it and, echoing the member for MCPherson's remarks, everyone should do it-young or old, thin or not so thin. The point is to get out there, become aware of your health and get those 10,000 steps per day. Physical activity is a vital part of any preventative health regime. I think that everyone would agree with the member for MCPherson that it is important to try to prevent illness rather than just treat it. That very obvious point needs to be reflected in both policy development and funding priorities if we are to protect the sustainability of our health tem into the future and at the same time assist Australians onto the path of a longer, healthier and happier life. Miss JACKIE KELLY (Lindsay) (4.27 pm)-I congratulate the member for MCPherson on moving this motion, and I endorse the comments of the member for Capricornia. So far we have heard from the mothers, and one of the key things in terms of return to health has been the involvement of mothers returning to health post pregnancy and looking after the early childhood years of their children in a healthy way. The function of protecting and developing health must rank even above that of restoring it when it is impaired, so Hippocrates said, and the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council has put together a national approach through the National Health Priority Action Council. That is made up of six volumes. The first volume is the National Chronic Disease Strategy, which is a nationally agreed strategy for taking on chronic diseases. Volume 2 is the National Service Improvement Framework for Asthma; volume 3, the National Service Improvement Framework for Cancer; volume 4, the National Service Improvement Framework for Diabetes; volume 5, the National Service Improvement Framework for Heart, Stroke and Vascular Disease; and volume 6, the National Service Improvement Framework for Osteoarthritis, Rheumatoid Arthritis and Osteoporosis. Chronic disease is estimated by these ministers to account for nearly 70 per cent of our health spend. The behavioural and social risk factors for those chronic diseases are poor health in early childhood, tobacco smoking, risky and high-risk alcohol use, poor diet and nutrition, physical inactivity, excessive sun exposure and social isolation. Those are the things that we have to address. I endorse the sysmotion put forward by the member for MCPherson about looking at young people and those early childhood factors for a lifetime of health. In my electorate of Lindsay, the Active After-school Communities Program, funded by this government, has been introducing children from Joey's Outside of School Hours Care to baseball, softball and T-ball, providing opportunities to child care and to schools for physical activity outside the school curriculum, which is already jampacked with advice on drugs, alcohol and healthy eating. We are aiming to engage children with fitness and team sports to carry them through life with those activities. Other schools in my electorate are growing vegetables and introducing breakfast programs under the Healthy School Communities program. A number of my schools have also elected to receive the $1,500 the government offers for schools to get their canteens in order. But there is only so much we can ask schools to do. At most, five meals a week are consumed in the schools. The parents must take responsibility for the rest. In doing so, we can have a lot of intervention in the early preschool years. I have advocated for a national preschool program where we involve a number of agencies to support parents with parental, nutritional and activity advice. If the mother is returned to health postpartum, she will be an active mum. I have lost about 10 kilos in the last 12 months and, with two toddlers, it is amazing the difference it makes: you are able to actively engage with your children-with piggybacks on the beach, the old shoulder carry and the things that encourage children to be active, running and in motion all the time. When you are running and out of breath, it is important to call your children back to walk close by because, in Western Sydney, there have been a number of school kidnappings. So the way we design our cities is a social issue. I recommend the 10,000 Steps program to the Penrith City Council. Footpaths should be designed so that people can partake of exercise in their local area. By setting up community walking programs around the local area, people can be encouraged to become physically active and less socially lated. Physical activity should be a normal part of their day-from the age of 12 months, when you learn to walk, until you are well aged and into your active retirement years. Congratulations to the member for MCPherson and all our health ministers, but I stress that more needs to be done.

Speaker: Mr GARRETT
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I thank the member for MCPherson for moving a motion that is intended to encourage the government to pursue policies which would see a greater emphasis on actions, particularly in education, which would increase the awareness and uptake of preventative health measures. It is a timely and welcome motion, but it is also a rebuke of current government policy and particularly the efforts of the Minister for Health and Ageing, Mr Abbott, who is presiding over an obesity epidemic of young people in this country but seems incapable of overcoming his ideological barriers and doing something effective and real about it. The urgent need for front-end health prevention can be seen in the rising costs of health budget and health related technology. No doubt it will become increasingly important for nations to focus on preventative health in the future, especially with the high incidence of preventable diseases, including cardiovascular diseases, high cholesterol, obesity and diabetes. I note that since 1996 federal government health spending has grown from around 15 per cent to over 20 per cent of the budget, a rise of around 3.8 per cent to 4.4 per cent of GDP. The cost imbalance of treating the endgame of poor health practice rather than investing in preventative health measures is clear. If you look at something like minimally invasive heart surgery, the costs are in the order of $3 million up front and then $2,300 for each procedure for disposable iso- equipment that cannot ever be used again. Surely this is the wrong way to achieve effective and prudent treatment of health issues. The member for Capricornia pointed out the health measures that are present in the community, such as 10,000 Steps, but the fact is that there has been a huge increase in obesity in Australia-from nine per cent in 1989-90 to 16 per cent in 2001. Alarmingly, the projections for 2010 suggest that at the current rate of obesity there could be 5.6 million Australians overweight-not obese, but overweight. By 2020, this could stretch to 6.3 million overweight and three million obese. These are startling figures and demand the attention of the Howard government and the health minister. If we say that the estimated growing rate of childhood obesity of one per cent a year continues, half of all young Australians will be overweight by 2025. Clearly, this is an unsatisfactory state of affairs. I refer to the fact that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are twice as likely the to be obese than non-Indigenous people. There are a number of historical factors, including the removal of children from their families, which have meant that a generation of mothers has not learnt traditional childrearing and feeding practices. A recent study shows us that 28 per cent of Indigenous low birth weight babies could be attributed to maternal malnutrition, and obesity is a factor there too. It is time for the government to act, but it has been remiss. Labor state governments have moved to address the issue of childhood obesity, but the minister continues to blame parents for the national epidemic, washing his hands of responsibility. Parents and families for Minister Abbott exist in hermetically sealed isolation-not impacted by government policy, the commercial sector and its expertly constructed advertising campaign or the substantial budgets that go with it. I a reasonable person would accept what Kaye Mehta, the nutrition lecturer at Flinders University, says: Food advertising does create increased preferences for those food products and increased ter power to their parents. That is why Labor supports the Australian Medical Association's call for a nutrition survey-the last one was conducted 10 years ago-and a national nutrition centre to coordinate a national response to Australia's obesity problem. Additionally, Labor calls on the government to conduct a national audit into junk food advertising during children's programs, examining the impact it has on children's health. This is urgently needed. If the minister addressed himself to the situation that I have described-a national childhood epidemic in obesity-then it is absolutely clear that the government must act. The government's 2004 announcement for $116 million over four years to curb Australia's declining physical activity needs to be brought into effect now. The National Obesity Taskforce's recommendations to understand and assess the impact of current food and drinks advertising practices on community levels of overweight and obese people need to be taken into account by the government. It is time for the federal government to accept its taskforce's advice and do something about childhood obesity. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mr HARTSUYKER
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I welcome the opportunity to speak on the motion of the member for MCPherson. It is a motion that shows great wisdom on her part. We have many great medical professionals, but one of the most influential health practitioners is the individual themself. Many people believe that their health care starts when they see a doctor and that it is the think doctor or the nurse who is somehow responsible for their health. It is a case of ‘When I'm ill, it's “bulk-bill and pill” treatment to solve all the problems.' There are times when we need a medical practitioner, but in reality pesthe individual can contribute a great deal to their own health and well-being. It is the individual who should be taking greater responsibility for their own health by a good diet, by taking regular exercise, by drinking only in moderation and by not smoking. It is really important that we focus on preventative measures. Preventative measures create good health outcomes-preventative measures by way of education but also preventative measures by way of individuals themselves ensuring that they conduct the type of lifestyle that produces good health. I am amazed that people persist in smoking. Figures in 1989 and 1990 showed that 28 per cent of adults smoked; by 2001 that figure had reduced, but only to 24 per cent. With regard to exercise, there was only a five per cent increase in the number of people conducting low levels of exercise between 1989 and 2001. We know what the benefits of regular exercise are, yet the uptake of exercise or the increase in exercise has been relatively modest. By taking regular exercise, people dramatically improve the health outcomes that they can achieve. The rate of obesity has almost doubled amongst Australian adults over the last two decades. Australia is now ranked as one of the fattest developed nations, closely following the US. We are being supersized, and many people are not doing anything about it. If current trends continue, at least 60 per cent of Australians aged over 18 will be overweight or obese by 2010. That figure will increase to 65 per cent by 2020. We have already passed the point where more men are overweight or obese than are not. This is not a good scenario. Some 20 to 25 per cent of Australian children are overweight or obese. Between 1985 and 1995, the combined level of overweight and obese children more than doubled. The figures are alarming indeed. Figures on smoking, exercise and obesity show that we have a long way to go in encouraging a sense of personal responsibility with regard to health matters. As I said before, this bulk-bill and pill proach to medicine, requiring medical practitioners to be the sole solution to the problem, just is not on. Obese people as a group receive more sickness benefits and more unemployment benefits than people within the normal weight range. I believe in the concept of a social contract. We as a community have the responsibility to provide high-quality health services. But in return for that, individuals have the responsibility to do as much as they can to preserve their own well-being through the measures I mentioned-not smoking, not excessively consuming alcohol and taking the appropriate amount of exercise. It is vital that there is a two-pronged approach. This motion should be commended. It has a focus on education, putting people in the picture with all the information they need to make correct lifestyle choices-to avoid obesity and to ensure that they are conducting a healthy lifestyle-and, in doing so, to produce great outcomes for our community through reduced health care costs. Medical technology is making huge strides in solving a whole range of problems, but we can leave more funding available for acute areas by taking care of the things that can be handled through personal responsibility. As I said, they are proper diet, regular exercise, drinking only in moderation and not smoking. The government has done a great deal in promoting those ideals, but it is very much in the hands of the individual. I believe that people have to take that personal responsibility much more seriously to ensure that we get very positive outcomes. We have an ageing population. In the future our medical resources are going to be very much focused on the more elderly people in our community. If, through a healthier lifestyle, we can produce lifelong health into old age, apwe can dramatically reduce the call on our health services and we can dramatically increase the availability of resources for others who could not help the situation that they were in, who could not help the condition that they had. Personal responsibility, like improved medical technology, is going to be a major driver in improved outcomes.

Speaker: Ms HALL
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: I would like to congratulate the member for MCPherson on bringing this motion before the House. I encourage the government to act upon the motion, because I believe that she has identified some very important issues in it. There is no single factor that impinges more on a person's quality of life than their health status. A person who enjoys good health has a positive outlook and a sense of well-being. A person who has poor health tends to have a more negative outlook, and that detracts from their sense of well-being. There are many factors involved. It is multifaceted. There are many factors that influence a person's health. There is dietand diet starts at childhood. From the time they are born, diet plays an important role in people's health. There is physical activity. Unfortunately, our lifestyle tends to lead lower level of physical activity than we previously enjoyed. Socioeconomic factors, unfortunately, also impinge upon the health status of people in Australia. People who are in lower socio-economic groups tend to have poorer health than others. That relates to the cost of obtaining good foods and good nutrition. Other factors that impact upon a person's health are their sense of connectedness or isolation and their psychological well-being. These are just a few factors that impinge upon a person's health. In considering this motion, I would like to focus on the epidemic that is consuming our society-the obese and overweight. It is a disease of affluence. Worldwide there are one billion people who are overweight. There are only 792 million who suffer from malnutrition. That is quite a telling factor. Most of those one billion people can be found in affluent countries. Obesity leads to high blood pressure, liver disease, type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease. I looked at what the Heart Foundation had to say and found that 37.6 per cent of all deaths in Australia were caused by heart disease, stroke and cardiovascular disease. There are 3.67 million Australians affected by cardiovascular disease, while 1.10 million Australians are disabled long term by cardiovascular disease. The prevalence of cardiovascular disease has increased by 18.2 per cent over the last decade. This can be really closely associated with obesity. Last week the AMA released a paper that highlighted the importance of good nutrition and the impact obesity was having in Australia. It pointed out that childhood obesity is increasing by one per cent a year, and it gave some strategies for addressing this. Babies should be solely breastfed, where possible, for at least the first six months of their lives. School canteens should not profit from sellto a ing junk food. Vending machines within schools should not be able to stock anything other than water. Selling chocolates and lollies as fundraisers should be banned. All junk food advertising should be banned. I think it is very important that we are very mindful of the impact on children of the advertisements shown with children's programs on television. The federal government funds a program to improve the nutritional status of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women, especially women under 20 who are pregnant and breastfeeding and women with children. I think that program needs to be extended.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE ASK THE
text: Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
