Speaker: Mr BYRNE
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I grieve today for those who experience mental illness and for the carers and companions of those who experience mental illness in this country. It is not as though this subject is unfamiliar to this House or to any level of government but, in light of the horrendous cost of untreated mental illness and uncared for mental illness in this country, something that continues to disturb me is the number of our fellow citizens who are committing suicide or leading lost lives-and the terrible costs to the carers of those with mental illness in the community. In 1993, there was a groundbreaking study and report by the then Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin. It spoke about mental illness, about how those with mental illness were being treated and about the stigma associated with mental illness. Primarily as a consequence of that report, two good federal government programs have arisen. Two other reports have followed that 1993 report-Out of hospital, out of mind, an excellent report by the Australian Mental Health Council; and the most recent report by that same council, in conjunction with the Human Rights Commissioner, called, interestingly, Not for service: experiences of injustice and despair in mental health care in Australia. With respect to Not for service and its recommendations, the report really hits the nail on the head when it talks about why governments of all persuasions must take some level of responsibility for fixing this community disaster. I will read from the executive summary of Not for service, which is the latest report to be commissioned into the state of mental health in this country: What this cumulative data shows is that after 12 years of mental health reform in Australia, any person seeking mental health care runs the serious risk that his or her basic needs will be ignored, trivialised or neglected. The adverse health, social and economic effects of Australia's mental health care system falls largely on those with recurrent or chronic disorders and their families and carers. These are some of the most vulnerable people in our community. In the short-term, the system as it currently operates may result in a failure to provide basic medical and psychological health care, inappropriate use of short term seclusion, confinement or overreliance on sedating medications. Longer-term, the impact may include deteriorating mental health and well-being, suicide, higher rates of homelessness, prolonged unemployment, incarceration or increased financial burden and poverty. Failure to attend to the urgent needs of those with severe mental disorders on a systemic basis may also lead to infringements of the wider rights of the community to reside in a safe and secure environment. For many people, ongoing financial and personal support from family and friends is the only real safeguard against these outcomes. These are stories that we heard 12 years ago. Given the problem with the provision of mental health services in this country acknowledged in this latest report, it is incumbent upon us as legislators in this place-and people that provide funding to health systems in some ways, particularly to the mental health system-to do something. I understand that as a consequence of this report the Prime Minister has given an undertaking to raise this matter at COAG. I would like to point out that this is a national priority. In 2001, 2,454 persons died by suicide. Virtually all those deaths occurred as a consequence of mental illness. So it is not as though we have a lot of time. We do not have time, because the more time we spend not addressing this particular situation the more people are dying in this country. In a fair-minded country-and a country that professes to look after its most vulnerable-we cannot stand here as legislators, as a government and an opposition, and say that we have done enough. We have to do more. Speaking about statistics: currently, for example, I think as a consequence of the lack of funding across all levels of government for mental health services, 62 per cent of people with mental health disorders do not actually access services. Most of the 38 per cent of people who do access services will seek treatment by a general practitioner. There are a lot of people who are literally dying in this country because they cannot get access for appropriate treatment, services and care. I say in this place that we cannot accept that. We speak about statistics-we talk about, say, the fact that one in five people have a mental illness in this country. I would like to read you the story of someone who could not get access to the treatment that she needed and what sort of effect it had on her. I have been told that I can tell this story but obviously not relate this person's name. This was a person who sought a treatment that had been successful at a psychiatric facility in the south-eastern suburbs of Melbourne but who was told that she could not continue to get that treatment because of funding cuts. She says: A cloud of depression has enfolded me. I have been fighting so hard, trying to think positive and trying to keep busy and exercise, telling myself it will pass ... Everything is too hard-I am scared, frustrated and sad, my head is going round and round. I can't turn it off-everything is too worrying. This individual has a psychotic disorder. She continues: I have tried, I can't do it. I want etly. I lovethis particular personwith all my heart. I don't want to hurt them, but my feelings are too overwhelming ... I need to turn off permanently. It's got to the stage where I can't keep a lid on things ... It's time to end this turmoil. I have to turn everything off. This is where, I am afraid, it gets a little bit difficult: I tried to suffocate myself for 1 hour in bed this afternoon with a big rubbish bag ... It didn't work. I was so upset. I wanted to go off in a hose and drift off to sleep ... But she could not actually do it. She continues: Please everyone know that I did try extra extra hard, but I failed ... This person, in this state in this countrywhat are we doing as a fair minded country? Whilst this is a horrendous situation, this person has now been able to access appropriate treatment and is well. So the fact is that, if people in this country who cannot get access to treatment and are contemplating killing themselves, as I have read in this place, do get access to treatment, they can restore their lives. Many of those with psychotic disorders are untreated because of the stigma, because of the lack of access to services. Very effective treatments are available, provided governments of all levels appropriately fund the services. The other thing is to basically talk about it, because it is still one of the taboo subjects in this society. There are many issues that you read about in magazines; you can read about virtually everything. But one of the things that you consistently do not read about is mental illness and the cost to the community. It is not a sexy story. It is not a quick fix story. It is not a story that you can splash on page 3 in a bikini. But it is a story that affects every level of this community and every to slip away quilayer of government. Now I have spoken quickly about someone who is experiencing mental illness, I want to speak of the despair of someone who is a carer of a person with mental illness. She says: I have witnessed and been subjected to a distinct lack of understanding of mental illness, a distinct lack of compassion for mental illness, a distinct lack of care towards the relatives and sufferers of this illness, and most disturbingly, a distinct lack of adequate and appropriate facilities for the sufthe car, attach ferers of this illness. The plight of a carer of a mentally ill person is fraught with much unpleasantness: heartache, sorrow, sadness, worry, misgivings, fear of and for the future, fear of being labelled, fear of being ostracised ... In short, the path we carers travel is all too often intolerable, insufferable and at times inhumane. It is time that we in this place actually make a commitment to do something. I ask-in fact, I beg-the Prime Minister to convene this summit, to make it a priority issue. The longer that we leave this issue untreated, in the way we have in our community, more of our citizens are going to die, more people are going to be untreated, more lives will be lost to mental illness. In this country, we just cannot allow that to continue. Paterson Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Mr BALDWIN
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Paterson) (4.57 pm)When I consider the most important issues facing communities in my electorate, roads are without a doubt one of the main priorities. For all towns, but in particular for towns like Gloucester, Dungog or Forster-Tuncurry, roads keep their economies alive. They need the infrastructure for agricultural business, to attract tourists and to keep jobs going. Since 1996 the Australian government has provided the electorate of Paterson with $295.8 million in Roads of National Importance funding; $8.7 million in national black spot funding; $142.3 million in financial assistance grants to local councils; and $7.8 million in Roads to Recovery funding. But when I look back on 2005 it is with great disappointment that I look at the appalling way that roads have been managed, resourced and funded by the New South Wales government. The Commonwealth provides the states with funding for roads and it is then the states who manage them-and, in the case of New South Wales, it is the Roads and Traffic Authority who manage the roadworks. To say that I have been appalled by the management of some projects in my electorate would be an understatement. The Pacific Highway and Weakleys Drive are two of particular note. But I have also been angered by the failure of the New South Wales government to match Commonwealth funding of $10 million for local roads, as budgeted for under AusLink. When you consider the debacle of the cross-city tunnel in Sydney and the millions of dollars it has cost, taxpayers in my electorate can quite rightly question why it is that money is not going to their projects from the state government. In the case of the Australian government's commitment of $10 million to specific roads in Paterson, a matching contribution of $10 million from the state would greatly assist local councils in the upgrade and maintenance of important regional roads. The funding is earmarked for the Dungog Shire, for the Dungog to Clarence Town road; the Clarence Town to Raymond Terrace Road, which also crosses into the Port Stephens Shire; the Dungog to Paterson road in the Dungog Shire; and the Lakes Way in the Great Lakes Shire. To bring these roads up to scratch, all levels of government need to make an extra contribution in funding. The Commonwealth have put money on the table and, to date, we have heard nothing from the New South Wales roads minister, Joe Tripodi. Take the case of the Bucketts Way, which links the Pacific Highway to the New England area and goes through towns like Stroud, Gloucester and Kramback and all the way to Taree. The Australian government are investing $20 million over four years into this road, and we are currently into the third year of funding. This money is on top of any federal funding that councils receive from the Roads to Recovery program, the black spot program or the Financial Assistance Grants Scheme. The funding has made a considerable difference to the quality of the road. Anyone who has ever driven on the Bucketts Way will appreciate the enormity of this upgrade task. The road falls across four council areas and covers terrain that is very hilly and winding-but very beautiful country at that. Once again, the state government has not matched funding on this project. The Commonwealth had no responsibility for injecting extra funds into the upgrade, but it understood that it was the right thing to do for the community. Another project that I have fought hard to obtain funding for is the Weakleys Drive intersection on the New England Highway. The Australian government has committed $25 million to finalising this project, which involves the construction of a flyover on Weakleys Drive to carry traffic unimpeded in both directions along the New England Highway. Weakleys Drive will extend over the New England Highway via a new section of road, connecting it directly to the Thornton-Beresfield link road. Traffic lights will be installed on Weakleys Drive at the intersection below the highway to provide for safe turning movements for traffic to and from the highway. While I had hoped that, in this the second year of funding, construction would have already started, we found out in May this year that the RTA had not finalised their planning. As a result, only a further $5 million was allocated to the project in this year's budget to complete the process of design, development and land purchases. I have been advised by the minister's office this week that a stage 3 project report for construction will be delivered to the department in January next year, and tenders are expected to be called in the following months of February or March. So I hope that 2006 will finally herald the start of construction of the longawaited Weakleys Drive project and that ongoing delays with planning will finally be overcome. Also of particular interest to me is the cific Highway. Last week there was a horrific accident which claimed the lives of four people from one Maitland family. It occurred between the Tea Gardens turnoff and Bulahdelah. The crash happened when the car carrying the Maitland family, which was southbound, veered onto the other side of the highway, colliding with another vehicle. Noone was killed in the second vehicle, but passengers from Bulahdelah did sustain some very serious injuries and are in hospital recovering. As police have said, the site of the accident was not known as a dangerous section of the highway and was in fact a straight corridor with three lanes. Only time will tell why this accident occurred, when the results of an investigation are known. Unfortunately, when there is an accident on the Pacific Highway, finger pointing and squabbling seem to be the order of the day. To my mind, it is completely disrespectful for politicians to start waving their fingers at each other when families and communities are grieving for their loss and investigations have not been completed. This is also fuelled by sections of the media who do not understand jurisdictions when it comes to road responsibilities, nor respect when it comes to the fatalities that occur. Perhaps when the construction of a dual carriageway on the Pacific Highway is completed, this debate will be over, but until such time. I will continue to fight for priority to be given to specific road projects that my community wants. Of particular concern on the Pacific Highway is the turnoff to Tea Gardens. Anyone who drives past this intersection will see a great deal of work currently under way, but unfortunately it does not include a flyover. For a very long time now, the community, headed by Patricia Michelle, have been calling for a flyover to be included in this roadwork design, similar to the flyPa- over at Karuah, to enable traffic moving on and off the highway to do so in a safe manner. We lobbied the federal roads minister about the project, who then wrote to the New South Wales roads minister, asking for a design and the cost of the flyover project to be canvassed. Hundreds of people from Tea Gardens and Hawks Nest rallied on the steps of Parliament House in Sydney, calling on the state government to build a flyover, yet to date no-one has seen a report detailing possible designs or costings from the RTA. The state government, in their usual arrogant way, have dismissed community concerns. The silence from John Bartlett, the member for Port Stephens, has been deafening. At the next election he will take over the Tea Gardens-Hawks Nest area. His only response is that this area is not in his electorate yetand, with a response like that, I doubt it will be in his electorate! When it comes to the Pacific Highway, I make no apology for lobbying all levels of government to build a dual carriageway in my electorate, just like federal members north of me all the way to and beyond the Queensland border do. I have welcomed the increase in funding from the Australian government under the AusLink proposal, which recognises the importance of upgrading the road as soon as possible. The government has increased funding from $60 million to $160 million per year, and over the next three years both the Australian and the New South Wales governments will provide $480 million for the upgrade. There has been significant progress made in the Paterson electorate so far. Completed projects include the Raymond Terrace bypass, Raymond Terrace to Karuah, the Karuah bypass, Bulahdelah to Coolongolook, Coolongolook to Wang Wauk and Wang Wauk to Bundacree Creek. There are two projects now under construction. One is the $114 million construction of section 1 of the Karuah to Bulahdelah upgrade, which will provide 11 kilometres of dual carriageway from the Karuah bypass to just south of Viney Creek Road. Construction has also started on the $115 million Bundacree Creek to Possum Brush section, which is 23 kilometres south of Taree. It will provide 9.7 kilometres of new four-lane divided freeway, including an interchange serving Nabiac. Twin two-lane bridges will be constructed over the Wallamba River to replace the existing narrow bridge. Planning is also under way for two further projects, being the F3 link to Raymond Terrace and the Bulahdelah upgrade. We need to upgrade the Pacific Highway to a dual carriageway as quickly as possible. Certainly, the accident last week has again highlighted why it is that the Karuah to Bulahdelah section must be made a priority. I understand that the state minister announced last week that tenders will be called. One of the most frustrating aspects of being a member of the federal parliament is that, whilst the Australian government provides funding for the Pacific Highway, it is the state government who prioritises the work, and the Pacific Highway is actually a state road. In an effort to expedite the construction of a dual carriageway, the Australian government agreed some time ago to increase their level of funding support. As I said earlier, we now have an agreement where both levels of government will be paying $480 million each over the next three years. This is an investment into road infrastructure that has to be made. Most importantly, priority has to be given to those areas on the highway which are known to be the sites of frequent accidents. The concerns of local communities have to be heard. This is a topic that I am very passionate about, and I do not apologise for banging on the doors of all levels of government to try to have this completed as quickly as possible. This year the federal government will have a $14 billion surplus. I call on the government to invest some of that money-to be matched by the state governments-in infrastructure development like the Pacific Highway under an AusLink proposal. (Time expired) Mr Nguyen Tuong Van

Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Article 6 of the International Convention on Civil and Political Rights states: Every human being has the inherent right to life. This right shall be protected by law. No one be arbitrarily deprived of his life. The Australian Van Nguyen was hanged on Friday, December 2 by the government of Singapore after pleas for clemency by this parliament, by the government and by many others were declined. Singapore's mandatory death sentence must now come under closer scrutiny because government sponsored execution of a human being is a crime against humanity and a breach of the UN convention. As such, Singapore stands condemned for the wilful deprivation of human life. Certainly Van Nguyen's grotesque punishment was absurdly disproportionate to his crime. No amount of spin on the part of the government of Singapore can disguise the fact that this is a government with attitudes and practices towards punishment of crimes that are archaic and barbaric. Singapore is one of the world's leaders in the execution of people, and my condemnation of its actions is not reserved for the execution of Van Nguyen alone but extended to the killing of other foreigners as well as of the citizens of Singapore. When Prime Minister Lee explained his refusal to grant clemency, he said that he was aware of the seriousness of the matter and was therefore making his decision knowing that he would be accountable for his actions. But the question is: who is he accountable to? The organs of accountability do not appear to work independently of government in Singapore. Reporters Without Borders have ranked Singapore's press freedom 149th out of 167 in its 2005 world press index. Singapore's former Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong attacked this report by saying: It is a subjective measure computed through the prism of western liberals. Such dismissiveness is typical of this government, which argues that its draconian laws and control of the media are necessary shall to ensure its stability. Suppressing freedom of the press, and in fact government control of the media and journalists, is a sure sign of a government desperately trying to maintain its rule by the use of totalitarian practices that are inconsistent with the principles of accountability and freedom of speech. State control of people's rights to congregate and protest without a permit, draconian laws and the quashing of dissenting voices through the use of fear and repercussion are certainly characteristic of a totalitarian regime and are, again, inconsistent with the values and practices of our Australian democracy. I want to join with the many Australians who have come together to offer support to the Nguyen family and in particular to Van's mother, Kim. I want to concur with the statement by Father Peter Hansen that he was proud of the compassion shown by the Australian people. Like most Australians who have been horrified by this barbaric act, I do not know the Nguyen family personally. But I deeply empathise with their tragic circumstances and in particular with Van's mother. As a mother myself, I know she will endure an unspeakable grief. I offer her my condolences and I know that she will find comfort in the compassion and the humanity of the people who have come to her aid-everyone from her lawyers to the staff of the Australian High Commission in Singapore, to friends, to the Australian public and to the caring hands of the Catholic Church, amongst them Father Peter Hansen, who leads the Catholic Church congregation in Craigieburn in my electorate of Calwell. I am aware that there are many Australians who were supportive of Van Nguyen's execution. It is easy for people to be unforgiving and to loathe those who they believe by their actions perpetuate the misery of drug abuse. But we must never allow such feelings to cause us to lose sight of our humanity. I cannot therefore agree with those who support capital punishment. Putting aside all the moral and legal arguments that militate against the use of capital punishment, for me personally it is a simple case of a profound belief that no human being has the right to take the life of another under any circumstances. I particularly derive this conviction from my own Christian faith, which preaches the sanctity and dignity of life and the power of forgiveness and mercy. I know this to be an absolute truth applicable in all circumstances without exception. Particularly indefensible, therefore, is case of Singapore and, might I say, the other 74 countries in the world-including the United States, which I understand has just hanged its 1,000th prisoner-who retain and employ the use of capital punishment. State sanctioned or judicial killing is immoral and senseless because it is wilfully employed and sanctioned by governments, some of which claim to uphold the highest standards of democracy and are at the forefront of defending human rights violations in places other than their own backyards. Singapore in particular must answer to the claims put forward by many that there is an inherent contradiction between their hardline stand on punishment for drug smugglers, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, their alleged tolerance of Burmese businesses operating out of Singapore and, indeed, of known Burmese drug lords frequently moving into and out of Singapore. If these allegathem. tions are true then the government of Singapore are guilty of gross hypocrisy and double standards, making their mandatory death penalty regime even more outrageous and indecent and a perfect example of why the fear of capital punishment will never succeed in eradicating drug abuse or obstructing the global movement of narcotics. It appears that the big players are rarely caught and punished, and it also appears that some may even enjoy the hospitality and tolerance of governments who purport to be tough on drugs. The execution of Van Nguyen and the issue of capital punishment will continue to confront and to challenge our civility both as individuals and as a nation for some time to come, particularly as we await the fate of other Australians facing death penalties abroad, including the Bali nine. We are a democratic country that long ago abolished capital punishment because we realised it to be barbaric and inhumane. We believe in the the rehabilitation of those who transgress and commit crimes, and we are a fair-minded people who believe in the principle that the punishment must fit the crime. As such, I would like to support Amnesty International's growing global campaign calling for the end of the death penalty. I would also like to welcome and support former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser's calls, and those of Nguyen's lawyer, Lex Lasry, for Australia to become an advocate for the abolition of capital punishment. However, it is not enough to run such a campaign only at a people-to-people level, even though history does teach us that the drive for change always begins at the grassroots and is then followed by politicians and governments; such a campaign should also transact at a government-to-government level. There are ways that this could be done and we, as a parliament, should be exploring I know there have been many calls, in particular from the public, for the government to link the issue of human rights with trade. That in itself, I understand and acknowledge, is a difficult issue; nevertheless, it is one that may need to be considered. As I said earlier, I did not know Van Nguyen, but he was a young man who had much to live for. He made a mistake for which, unfortunately, he paid with his life. Common human decency, however, tells us that this young man's punishment far outweighed the severity of his crime. His death was therefore senseless and cruel. Although it should serve as a warning to other young Australians, unfortunately it will not, such is the cold reality of the lucrative world of drug merchandising. For me and other Australians, the Van Nguyen tragedy serves not only to remind us of the fragility of human life but more importantly to reaffirm the need to uphold the sanctity and the dignity of human life. We have a duty and particular governments have a duty to preserve, protect and, indeed, uphold every human being's inherent right to life. Capital punishment is a violation of that right and we must fight for its abolition. In conclusion, on Friday many Australians expressed their grief in many ways. A former university professor of mine sent an email to me and no doubt to other people. It is a poem written by a very prominent Greek poet, CP Cavafy. It is about a young man who was executed by hanging and is headed ‘27 June 1906, 2 pm'. I would like to dedicate this poem to the memory of Van Nguyen. It reads: When the Christians brought him to the gallows, that seventeen-year-old guileless boy, his mother, grovelling and writhing in the dust nearby under the fierce midday sun, now whined and howled like a wolf, like a wild beast, and now, exhausted by her martyrdom, lamented: ‘Just seventeen years is all you lived for me, my child.' (Time expired) Dr Jayant Patel: Report

Speaker: Mrs MAY
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: Last Wednesday, a scathing 538-page report into the Dr Death scandal was presented to the Premier of Queensland by Commissioner Geoff Davies. This report is the result of a six-month $6 million inquiry that was undertaken at the request of the Premier after allegations that India-trained surgeon Dr Patel was linked to the deaths of more than 80 patients at the Bundaberg Base Hospital. The report is damning. It is damning of a health system that has been out of control and inadequately funded and which has operated under a culture of secrecy. The report said that the former health minister, Gordon Nuttall, had hidden information about a report into Dr Patel, which was ‘at best naive and at worse disingenuous'. The report states: Such misconduct was misleading, unreasonable and careless. This long-awaited report does not reflect the heartache, the tears and the suffering of so many patients who have survived to tell their horrific stories-stories where patient care was compromised and elective surgery was less than adequate and certainly, in many cases, not safe. It is important to put on the record how this inquiry came about. In fact, if it was not for one very brave intensive care nurse, Ms Toni Hoffman, this inquiry might never have taken place. But Ms Hoffman, to her credit, blew the whistle. She took her concerns about Dr Patel and the treatment of patients at the Bundaberg Base Hospital to her local MP, Mr Rob Messenger, who detailed her concerns in the state parliament. Ms Hoffman gave damning evidence to the inquiry. She told how she had repeatedly tried to raise her concerns with hospital management and senior doctors but had gotten nowhere. Her courage and compassion on behalf of her patients is to be commended. If she had not taken her concerns to her local member, we might never have heard the true story of the state of Queensland Health. When the report was delivered last week, Toni Hoffman was at work in her job as nurse unit manager in Bundaberg's intensive care unit. She said that she and fellow ICU nurses welcomed the charges that had been recommended against Dr Patel and their former bosses, Darren Keating and Peter Leck. Toni Hoffman has been vindicated. Her concerns about the cover-up of Dr Patel have been borne out in the report. Mr Davies found Dr Keating and Mr Leck had displayed a ‘gross dereliction of duty' in not investigating complaints against Dr Patel. The report recommends that Dr Keating be referred to the Australian Federal Police over allegedly knowingly or recklessly giving false information to the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs over Dr Patel's application for year visa. It also recommends that Dr Keating be prosecuted for official misconduct. As for Mr Leck, the report found that he had failed to check Dr Patel's qualifications. Dr Patel had been banned from practising in Oregon and New York. In addition, Mr Leck's failure to suspend Dr Patel may constitute a disciplinary breach that would warrant dismissal. This inquiry opened on 23 May 2005 and finished with the final report being handed to the Premier on 30 November 2005. Tony Morris QC was the first commissioner to oversee the inquiry; however, he was sacked after 50 days and 85 witnesses by a Supreme Court ruling of apprehended bias. After being dismissed from the inquiry, Mr Morris provided the federal Standing Committee on Health and Ageing with a 33-page submission cataloguing a plethora of systemic problems, serious dysfunction at Bundaberg Base Hospital and a shocking culture of concealment in the bureaucracy. Mr Morris urged that a rapid response team investigate serious clinical problems in Queensland, that there be a review of pay scales for doctors and nurses, and the re-education of bureaucrats to ensure that they were effective rather than remote and aloof. In his report to the standing committee, Mr Morris said: One of the most urgent needs was honesty about the limitations of the public health sector ... what occurred at Bundaberg is not itself the disease-it is merely an acute symptom of a condition which is chronic, widespread and potentially terminal. Those are damning statements about the Queensland health system. And what now for the former health minister Gordon Nuttall? We know that several bureaucrats were advised last week that they will face criminal charges or disciplinary action, but their former boss, Gordon Nuttall, has shrugged off the scathing findings on his behaviour and until late last week had his bags packed for a fouran all-expenses-paid, 10-day, taxpayer funded jaunt to Brazil and the United States. Even worse, he was going with the blessing of the Premier. But the trip has now been cancelled, and so it should be. The Premier has refused to sack this minister, despite the commissioner describing his conduct as ‘misleading, unreasonable and careless'. Gordon Nuttall himself should do the honourable thing and resign. He was the minister in charge. He was aware of what was going on. His departmental staff will pay the ultimate price. He should fall on his sword and take full responsibility for what happened in Queensland Health. Ultimately the buck stops with the minister. Mr Nuttall has rejected all claims made against him in the report in a statement to parliament. This is a man who is currently being investigated by the Crime and Misconduct Commission over allegations that he lied to a parliamentary committee over his knowledge of problems with overseas-trained doctors. Key recommendations made by Commissioner Geoff Davies in the report include charging Dr Patel with manslaughter and assault, charging him with assault occasioning bodily harm, charging him with negligent acts causing harm and charging him with fraud. It has been reported that relatives of patients who died at the hands of Dr Patel, and the living victims of the botched operations of the so-called Dr Death, are delighted at the charges recommended against him. However, the patients and their families will not experience complete closure to this horrific chapter in their lives until Dr Patel is extradited from the United States to face prosecution in Queensland. There is no doubt that we have in Queensland a crumbling health system and a premier and a government who will not accept responsibility for the situation we now find ourselves in, even with a damning reportan extensive report-that highlights the grossly inadequate and underfunded public health system, a system that has let down the people of Queensland. They have not enjoyed for many years a safe and effective health system that they can have faith in. Instead, the finger pointing has begunthe blame game, a game that the Premier plays very well: hand on heart, ‘I will fix problem; we are an open and accountable government.' But of course he claims to have been underfunded by none other than the Commonwealth government. Premier Beattie is a master of shifting blame, particularly to the Commonwealth, for the underfunding, but the truth is that the most recent data clearly shows in a June 2005 report that the gap in the underfunding of Queensland public hospitals is growing. Queensland's recurrent expenditure per person on public hospitals in 2004 was still the lowest in Australia, at $440, which is below the national average of $552 per person. As for the remuneration rates for doctors, Queensland Health specialist rates are low by Queensland and Australian standards. It is no wonder that we have experienced a severe shortage of doctors in Queensland. Now the Premier is on a recruiting drive to encourage doctors back to Queensland, and it is about time. Gold Coast City has also experienced severe cutbacks as a direct result of a dysfunctional health system, a health system that has been ignored for years and starved of funding, with waiting lists that continue to grow for elective surgery. Only recently I spoke in this House about the blow-out in the number of patients waiting for elective surgery and the shutdown of the cancer treatment ward at the Gold Coast Hospital. Oncology services have been suspended and patients now have to travel to Brisbane-another indictment of the Beattie government. The Queensland government must be made to answer for the mess the health system is in. The abominable delivery of health services in Queensland has cost lives, and there is nothing as yet to indicate that conditions will improve. This government has put the lives of its citizens at risk, and one would hope that this report will see an end to that culture. There is absolutely no reason for this state the government to short-change its citizens on health care. The Beattie government has received record amounts of funding under the Australian health care agreement. The Commonwealth will spend $42 billion on public hospitals over five years, and $8 billion of that budget will go to Queensland to assist with providing public hospital services to public patients. So one would have to ask: where are these dollars being spent? Why isn't the state government delivering adequate and safe health services for all Queenslanders? There is also the GST bucket of funding, a growth tax that has seen record dollars delivered to Queensland. In 2004-05 the Beattie government received $7.328 billion. No state has benefited more from the GST arrangements than Queensland. In Queensland we have experienced boom times with boom revenue, but where has it gone? It certainly has not gone into our health system. With our growing population, it is important to make the right decisions for Queensland's future, but it would appear that we are moving backwards. Premier Beattie only recently said: ‘Our government are the No. 1 economic managers in the countryahead of any other state or territory.' It appear that Queenslanders are paying a very high price for Premier Beattie's shallow and bungling style of economic management that does not deliver. In conclusion, I want to pay tribute to all those involved in exposing the Dr Death scandal. Their courage to speak out will undoubtedly deliver a safer public health system to our state. To those who lost loved ones: I hope your pain diminishes. To those who are left bearing the scars: I wish you well and hope you recover to lead productive lives, free of pain and suffering. This era in Queensland politics has been a nightmare. I hope we can now move on and put this incredible chapter in Queensland history behind us. (Time expired) Poverty Huntington's Disease Welfare to Work

Speaker: Ms CORCORAN
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I recently received a number of letters from a group of year 7 girls at Kilbreda College in Mentone in my electorate. Lucinda Bishop, Emily Johnston, Taylor Wilcox, Beck Crowe, Alisi Falevai, Nicole Agapitos, Stephanie Hay, Marissa Moro, Lydia Honan, Michelle Mah and their teacher Louise Harms wrote to ask me to encourage my fellow parliamentarians and the government to help make poverty history. These girls have been studying experiences of poverty from around the world. Many of the girls were shocked by the enormous gap in living standards between First and Third World countries. The girls were inspired in their studies by the grassroots energy generated by the Make Poverty History campaign. Sadly, Australia lags far behind many developed countries in its pursuit of the eight Millennium Development Goals which are at the core of the campaign. One of the goals is a target of 0.7 per cent of gross national inwould come to be spent on foreign aid by developed countries by 2015. Australia's aid level remains at an embarrassingly low level of about 0.25 per cent of GNI. In writing to me, one of the girls, Nicole, asked a question I would like everyone in this House to consider. She asked: ‘Are we really doing everything or is there more? If there is, why aren't we doing it?' I found myself quite moved by the sincerity and emotion of the girls, which comes through very clearly in their letters. It is a pity that time constraints prevent me from reading more of their letters here. We are approaching Make Poverty History White Band Day, which is on 10 December. Now is the time to renew our commitment and to redouble our efforts. The girls of Kilbreda College are doing whatever they can to make poverty history. It is to our national shame that the same cannot be said of every member of this House. We can and must do better in our contribution to this very achievable aim. I join the girls of Kilbreda in saying that it is time to get serious: we can make poverty history. I recently met with a constituent who has campaigned for many years to promote a greater understanding of a heavily stigmatised and often mismanaged disease: Huntington's disease. Jim Rutherford lost his first wife, his mother-in-law, four sisters-in-law and his youngest son to Huntington's disease. His eldest son is now in the final stages of the disease. Huntington's is a genetically inherited, rapidly acting degenerative brain disease. It tends to hit sufferers in early dle age, and its effects can be similar to inson's and Alzheimer's. Sadly, specialised care for Huntington's sufferers is almost non-existent and they are often placed in aged-care facilities. Given that management of the disease involves intensive mental and physical stimulation, aged-care facilities are entirely inappropriate for Huntington's sufferers. Mr Rutherford explained to me how frustrated he has been over the years in his efforts to raise awareness of this problem in political circles and in the wider community. Recent scientific developments have given some hope to sufferers; however, a cure for the disease is still many years away. Until that day comes, it is essential that, as a community, we give greater understanding and more effective support to the thousands of Huntington's carriers in our midst and to the many thousands who are destined to battle the disease. Isaacs has been short-changed a number of times in recent weeks and will be shortchanged on an ongoing basis once some particularly nasty bits of legislation have been passed. Isaacs has been short-changed, firstly, because I have been gagged from speaking on three out of four critical pieces of legislation that have recently been before this House. I was gagged from speaking on the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 2005, on the Employment and Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Welfare to Work and Other Measures) Bill 2005 and on the Anti-Terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2005. I was lucky that I had already spoken on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Work Choices) Bill 2005 when the government gagged that debate. Many of my colleagues have not had the opportunity to represent their electorates in any of these important debates. The second ‘shortchange' is ahead for many people in Isaacs, midwho will be short-changed once the Work ParkChoices and the Welfare to Work legislation kick in. I would like to spend some time talking about the issues around the Welfare to Work legislation. The essence of this bill is that the government plans to move people from one form of welfare payment to another cheaper form-that is, those who are already under financial strain will have their incomes reduced. There are no real plans to actually help people move into work. The kindest thing that can be said is that the government is naive and thinks that a lower income will encourage people to look for work. Those of us with a better grip on reality know that most people on the DSP and on the sole parent payment are already working if they can. For those on the DSP, there are many barriers to finding suitable work, and these measures will make life even more difficult for those already under considerable financial stress. There are a number of myths circulating about the DSP, and these need to be debunked before a sensible discussion can be had about it. The Australian Council of Social Service issued an excellent document in January this year that set out 10 myths and facts about the DSP. I recommend this document to anybody interested in learning a bit more about it. Three of these myths are as follows. The first is that many people on DSP do not have ‘real' disabilities, just ‘bad backs'. The second is that people who can work part time do not have a ‘real' disability and should not be on the DSP. The third is that Australia has more people on disability payments than do comparable countries. The facts are that people only get the DSP if they have a severe disability that has been assessed by medical or other experts chosen by Centrelink. People with poor vision or hearing or who use wheelchairs are not the only ones with disabilities that stop them from working full time. For example, over one-quarter of DSP recipients have a mental illness. If your only problem is a back condition, you have to be in almost constant pain or be unable to sit or move around properly to get the DSP. Many people, such as multiple sclerosis sufferers and people with ring mental illnesses, are able to work part time but cannot hold down a full-time job. Allowing these people to keep the pension while they work part time, as the present DSP rules allow, is sensible because it encourages DSP recipients to look for work. About five per cent of Australians of work force age are on the DSP, which is around the average for wealthier OECD countries. One of the myths that regularly bobs up is that single parents are all young girls intent on having babies in order to get onto welfare and live an easy life ever after. Those of us with children know that that is a bit of a myth in itself. The facts are that the majority of single parents are aged between 30 and 50 years, less than three per cent are teenagers and 45 per cent of single parenting payment recipients who have school-aged children work. The barriers to single parents working include a lack of education. Sixty per cent of those who are not working have education only to year 10, 20 per cent have recently experienced violence and five to 10 per cent will have moved in the last year. I would be more convinced about the government's stated intentions if there were any sign of positive help being offered to those on the DSP or sole parent payment. The rationale of the government seems to be that DSP recipients and sole parents are rorting the system and that a big stick will sort them out. Let us look at the DSP compared with Newstart. I am grateful to the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling for providing the following information. Currently a DSP recipient receives $257 per week compared with the Newstart allowance which is $211 per week-a difference of $46 per week. DSP recipients can earn $64 of income before payments are reduced; Newstart recipients, $31-a difference of $33 per week. The DSP cuts out once private income reaches $706 per week; Newstart cuts out at recur- $398 per week-a massive difference of $308 per week. Now let us look at the parenting payment single. These figures are based on a person with one child. Currently the PPS is $257 per week. The Newstart payment would be $228, a difference of $29 per week. The amount a parent can earn before payments are reduced is $76. On Newstart it will be $31, a difference of $45 per week. The difference in the cut-out point-the point beyond which the payment stops-is a private income of $718 per week for those on the PPS compared with Newstart's $426, a huge difference of $292 per week. We hear about a thing called the effective marginal tax rate. This is the rate at which someone moving from welfare to work loses on each dollar they earn because of the combination of income tax and reducing social security benefits. The effective marginal tax rate for DSP and parenting payment single recipients moving into work from Newstart will be in the range of 70 to 80 per cent. We have heard a lot of talk lately about an argument that a marginal income tax rate for higher income earners of 47c is a disincentive to those seeking more work. If we are going to accept that argument, why on earth are we asking those moving between welfare and work to accept an effective tax rate of 70 to 80 per cent? And we forget the extra costs that come with going to work-the bus fare, child care and buying a clean shirt to wear to work. Labor supports real welfare reform. We believe that people who can work should and that those who cannot work should be supported, and we recognise the value of looking after young children. Labor wants real reform that tackles the reason someone is not working and that delivers practical solutions. Drought Fuel Prices New South Wales Health Services

Speaker: Mr SCHULTZ
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I take this opportunity to speak today about a number of issues which are having a significant impact on constituents in the Hume electorate. I will begin with a matter that I have raised already with the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry and also the Minister for Human Services, as the person responsible for Centrelink. That matter is the administration of this government's exceptional circumstances relief payments. I am thankful that both ministers have already acknowledged my concerns. However, I would like to place my disappointment on record with regard to events which have occurred during the past few months. Several weeks ago, farmer constituents in the Hume electorate, in the community of Young in particular, found themselves in a very difficult financial situation because of this government department's procedural tardiness. Families who had been relying on the exceptional circumstances relief payment were shocked to receive notification from Centrelink that their payments were being cut off. Despite countless phone calls and letters from my office in the weeks and, indeed, months prior to the deadline, the minisper ter for agriculture and his department failed to ensure that assistance was extended in a timely manner. The result for farming families was that Centrelink cut off their payments, and they were left in limbo for close to two weeks before a decision was announced and the payments reinstated. It is all well and good for the minister's office to say that payments will be backdated. However, that does not put food on the table or fuel in the truck or tractor for families surviving just above the breadline. And although families in Young have now been granted their extension, at least for a few more months, the same issue is threatening to put an end to Christmas for families in other drought affected areas, including East Gundagai, Yass and Goulburn, the South Coast, Moss Vale, Braidwood and the Central Tablelands. For them, the government assistance runs out this Thursday. In a letter to me back in September, the Yass Rural Lands Protection Board sought my assistance to ensure that relief would be extended beyond the 8 December deadline. The letter stated: In November 2003, support under Exceptional Circumstances Assistance was granted for the areas covered by the Yass RLPB. The assistance was provided to help producers through one the most severe drought periods in history and through the subsequent recovery period. Whilst the district has received substantial rainfall throughout winter of 2005, during the remainder of the recovery period the district has endured severe drought conditions. To maintain financial viability and sustainability under these circumstances, a large number of producers have been forced to sell off increasing numbers of their core breeding stock, invest large sums of money in failed crops and the purchase of fodder supplies. Sheep numbers in the district have dropped approximately 20 per cent and beef cattle by 10 cent from 2001 to 2005. Whilst this may seem relatively insignificant, it equates to 274,700 sheep and 6,224 cattle. This is a significant number when it comes to rebuilding flocks and herds. The Yass RLPB would like to bring to the attention of the Federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry the fact that this district was in drought for the term of the EC recovery period and is in fact still drought declared. and support is required for producers to rebuild their stock numbers, fodder supplies and to try and recover some financial backing which has been drawn upon so heavily during this period. I understand that the government cannot enter into decisions lightly and that decisions must be based on solid fact. My complaint is that, to date, investigations have not been conducted, results examined and recommendations considered by the minister within a reasonable time frame. This is not just numbers on paper but people's lives and futures we are talking about here. I call on the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to ensure that, come Thursday, families in the rest of Hume will not have to face the same stress and uncertainty as those rural producers at Young which I referred to earlier. This issue is too important to linger at the bottom of some public servant's ‘to do' pile or on the desk of a government minister. This decision needs to be made now so that families can make plans not only for this Christmas but also for the months and the years ahead. I move on now to an issue which has angered residents in the Hume electorate for a very long time. Petrol prices may have begun to fall in our metropolitan areas. However, in country areas, including Goulburn in the heart of my electorate, prices remain at more than $1.20 a litre. Late last week, for example, the local Shell service station in Goulburn was selling unleaded petrol for 123.9c a litre. On the same day, the same fuel in Young, in the western part of the Hume electorate, was selling for 127.9c per litre. Meanwhile in Picton, still in the Hume electorate but on the outskirts of Sydney, fuel was just 109.9c a litre. That is a price differential of 18c per litre between an outer metropolitan petrol station and a rural one. According to the Australian Automobile Time Association's FuelTrac pricing summary, unleaded petrol in the Sydney metropolitan area during October 2005 averaged 124.6c per litre, with a top price of 139.9c per litre. In Goulburn, by comparison, the average price for October was 135.9c per litre, with a top price of 143.5c per litre. That is an 11c difference in the average price of fuel between the city and a rural area. On several occasions I have contacted the ACCC to report this price difference and the way in which fuel prices locally fail to move in line with the price of oil, only to be told that unless collusion could be proved there was nothing they could do. The government so often points out that fuel prices are driven by world oil prices and market forces. However, as was pointed out in the media this week, Caltex has reported that its profit per barrel of oil increased from $7.28 to $11 this year, as consumers in many areas paid more than $1.40 a litre for their petrol. To my constituents, that is highway robbery. Surely when we talk about keeping the economy strong we should also be thinking about how we can ease the burden of high petrol prices on Australian families. It is what Australian families want. Moving on now, what Australian families also want is affordable and accessible health services. Like all members in this place, I know that the provision of hospital services is a state responsibility. However, the situation is getting so bad in New South Wales that I am starting to feel, and my constituents are starting to feel, that it is time for the federal government to step in and put pressure and conditions on the state government for all Commonwealth funding. In one local example, it was reported recently that the Greater Southern Area Health Service owes somewhere in the vicinity of $7 million to its medical staff and suppliers. So bad is the situation that, in one case, a woman who had gone through the trauma of a mastectomyand, might I add, I know this woman personally-went to her local department store to be fitted with a prosthesis and was told that they could not help her because the health service had not paid its account. The hard working Liberal state member, Daryl Maguire, had to step up and pay for the prosthesis himself, and I compliment him for doing that. What sort of government can allow this sort of thing to go on? The local branch of Country Labor cannot even get action from their own government, so Country Labor members have organised a rally, to be held in Goulburn this coming Sunday, to protest against any downgrade of Goulburn health services as a result of both the health service's current financial position and the shortage of nursing and medical staff. Country Labor have their hands tied, because we all know they are restricted to public posturing, as any effective action taken against the Iemma state government will break caucus solidarity and see their members expelled from the ALP. The rally will also recognise the wonderful job that nurses, doctors and other health personnel do for the community. On the day of the rally I have commitments elsewhere in the electorate, but the point I make is that there is an increasing concern within the community about these important health issues. Our hard working local doctors, nurses and health personnel deserve better. Constituents in my electorate are constantly asking me to do something about the state of health services both in Goulburn and elsewhere in the electorate and, as a committed local member, I will do everything I can do to assist. In a letter to me recently, one very vocal and passionate advocate issued a plea: When you and I were boys things were different: our local hospitals-St John's, the Base Kenmore-were LOCAL, run by local administration and serviced by local organizations such as Hospital Auxiliary, Pink Ladies, and service clubs. Our women and children, the elderly and mentally ill were well looked after. Wonderful things have happened with health services over the years but unfortunately it has not all been good, particularly now when people are being turned away from hospitals because there is a lack of staff/accommodation, expectant mothers have to travel to centres an hour away, the mentally ill wander the streets and contribute to the ever growing population of homeless people. Something must be done to bring our hospitals back to being well run, viable, safe institutions, for the staff and patients. … … … You are our Federal Member and I am asking you to speak to the Prime Minister and Mr Tony Abbott, both of whom I am sure are aware of the state of the NSW health system, and ask them to use their expertise in solving this very real problem. So, I take this opportunity in the House to issue a plea to our Minister for Health and Ageing to put whatever pressure he can on his New South Wales counterpart to ensure that something is done about the crisis which is currently facing health services in New South Wales, before it is too late. It has gone beyond the political posturing being undertaken at the moment. It is a serious issue and it needs to be addressed. Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme

Speaker: Ms GILLARD
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I join the member for Hume in his indictment of the Howard government's shocking and systematic failures in the area of health. Of course, most of the things he mentioned are things that the Howard government could address if it chose to, but it refuses to do so. I rise to grieve also about a health issue-that is, the shameful record of the Minister for Health and Ageing and, in particular, his and failure to heed the advice of his experts not to take calcium tablets off the PBS for people who need them for osteoporosis. I grieve not only on my own behalf but on behalf of the oldest and sickest Australians, who will disproportionately bear the impact of this policy. I also grieve on behalf of the Australian Medical Association, which wants the federal government to rethink its decision to remove calcium tablets from the PBS. As you would be aware, there is an old song that goes, ‘All I want for Christmas is my two front teeth'-a child's song, of course. Unfortunately, this Christmas there are too many older Australians who are saying that what they want for Christmas is their calcium tablets. But, like the Grinch that stole Christmas, the minister for health, Tony Abbott, is denying them access to this basic dietary supplement, which is so important to their health. Mr Deputy Speaker Adams, you would recall that in the last election campaign the Howard government gave a rock solid, ironclad guarantee to maintain the Medicare safety net, and its failure to honour its promfor ise on the safety net now is a matter of public record and public consternation. We should also note that during the last election campaign the Howard government made no mention of what it was planning to do to the PBS safety net. But, since the election, it has hacked into the PBS safety net, including by increasing the thresholds to qualify and excluding from the safety net many prescriptions filled within 20 days of the previous prescription. There is only one goal here, and that is budget savings. These measures come at a time when the data show that the growth in PBS spending has slowed to 2.5 per cent, down from an average of 12 per cent over the past four years. This slowdown is due primarily to the 21 per cent increase in copayments-that is, the amount that patients have to pay to access medicines-introduced in January and does not as yet fully reflect the impact of the 12.5 per cent generics pricing policy. More particularly we see, in the four-month period from 1 July to 31 October, that there was a decrease of over 1,300,000 scripts over the same period last year. Given that the growth rate in PBS scripts over this time frame has averaged 3.8 per cent over the previous four years, the decrease is really around 3.8 million scripts in that four-month period. More work needs to be done on these statistics, but I think we are right to exhibit real concern that there may be millions of times that people are making a decision not to fill their scripts because of lack of affordability, and such a drop in the access to prescription medicines requires careful analysis. PBS spending in that same time frame has dropped from $2.2 billion in 2004 to $2.034 billion in 2005. Given that the growth rate in this time period over the previous four years has averaged 13.3 per cent, the savings are actually $461 million in four months. If these trends continue we can expect to see savings the year 2005-06 of $1.38 billion on the PBS and 11.4 million fewer scripts being filled-and that is before the implementation of the new safety net provisions. The government seems certain to meet its savings targets, but at what cost? Who is missing out on medicine when we look at these statistics? I think we are right to fear that it is the poorest and sickest Australians who are missing out. Depending on what medications they are failing to take due to affordability issues, it may not really be a saving at all, as the consequences of not taking their medicine show elsewhere in the health system when they need other forms of care. The decision to take calcium tablets off the PBS is a clear example of what happens when you look for a saving today but do not give a second thought to the costs tomorrow. In making this decision the minister for health has completely disregarded expert opinion and sound policy. The minister for health was in a rush to find savings to deliver to the Treasurer in the lead-up to the last budget. On that basis of rushing around and looking for savings, he decided to remove calcium tablets from the PBS to achieve savings of $36 million over four years. That is a $9-million saving a year. What damage has this rush for savings-a rush for savings that was done without expert advice-created? That is right. I think Australians need to clearly understand this: the Minister for Health and Ageing in the budget decided to take something off the PBS without any expert advice. If this were to keep up, what else would be coming off the PBS when he is looking for a saving? Cancer medication, antidepression medication, cholesterol-lowering medication; are they things that are going to be ripped off the PBS next when the minister for health is looking for savings? We know that the cost of calcium tablets to the government when they are on the PBS is around $13 a bottle. This means that the cost for concession card holders who are accessing calcium from the PBS has gone from $4.60 to around $13 a bottle. We should note that it was not everybody who could have access to calcium on the PBS. You could not just get calcium on the PBS because you felt like taking a supplement; calcium on the PBS was only available on authority from your doctor and the doctor was required to certify that the patient needed calcium tablets. Only then were you subsidised by the PBS. The minister for health was the subject of a great deal of criticism after he took this decision. Instead of getting expert advice before the decision, he sought expert advice after the decision. He consulted the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee about his decision. They sent him some advice. He sent that advice back to them for review and then they sent him some further advice. That advice stated that they were: ... concerned that ... patient groups would not be optimally treated if they ceased taking calcium tablets should they become less affordable by delisting. So the experts told Tony Abbott, the minister for health, that he had made a mistake and that he ought to put calcium back on the PBS. What the minister did in the face of this expert advice was to complete half a humiliating backflip. He backflipped on the question of the provision of calcium tablets to people with kidney conditions, who need a lot of calcium. But he has not backflipped on the rest-which is what he should do, no matter how humiliating the decision for him. The people who have been left without access to PBS calcium tablets are people with osteoporosis. This is a disease that costs Australia $1.9 billion per annum in health costs, putting a heavy burden on hospitals and nursing homes. It costs a further $5.6 billion in indirect costs. It represented a total of 1.2 per cent of GDP in 2000-01, or $389 for every Australian. The mortality rate for hip fractures in the elderly is high-about 20 per cent in the first 12 months. Elderly Australians around the country have been raising this issue, including at a seminar held by the member for Richmond, where one of the attendees stood up and said she had voted for The Nationals all her life but would no longer do so, specifically because of this decision. This decision is a disgrace. It came into effect on 1 December. I am using my first parliamentary opportunity to raise it. This decision needs to be reversed. The minister for health should stop pretending to be the Grinch who stole Christmas and actually do something positive for the health of Australians before we leave this parliament. The positive thing that he should do is accept the advice of experts, recognise he was wrong when he desperately clutched for budget savings and put calcium back on the PBS. Water Management

Speaker: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
Title: GRIEVANCE DEBATE
text: I rise in this debate to grieve about the way a water by-product of the mining and extraction of coal bed methane gas from the Surat Basin is merely being left to evaporate away. There are many companies in the Surat Basin extracting coal bed methane and obviously being able to find a ready market for the methane gas. This is a technology that even 10 years ago was in its infancy. Twenty years ago, coal bed methane was just lost to the environment as part of a coal mining operation. It is really about value adding to the coal industry and being able to utilise something that would otherwise have been wasted. I will explain to the House this afternoon how the coal bed methane is extracted from these coalfields. First of all, they drill to find the reserves and then they have to extract the gas. As they extract the gas, a large volume of water comes up with the gas. Why is that? The water molecule is larger than the gas molecule; so, as part of the extraction process, the water comes up to the surface ahead of the gas, as I understand it. The companies that are mining the coal bed methane gas, obviously stripping the gas from the water, are able to process it and feed it into the Roma-Brisbane pipeline to supply industries in Brisbane. There are gas pipelines that head north to Gladstone and Townsville. So an invaluable source of energy is being extracted from the Surat coal bed, and coming up with it is water. The problem with this water at the moment is that it carries salts with it, and it has to be cleaned up if it is to be used in any way other than perhaps in an industrial sense. An industrial use, for instance, could be to wash coal, as the coal industry develops in that part of Queensland. There are a very large number of feedlots in that region which require water. More water will be required as both those industries expand in the future. One of the first things that industries require before they invest capital is a known reserve of water, whether it is in the development of the coal industry or whether it is in the feedlot industry. Both of those industries really are being held back through the lack of guarantees of an available or suitable water source. Here we have a known water source which is a by-product of the coal bed methane being sold for purposes within Queensland now. Why, on the driest continent on earth, are we allowing this water that comes up as part of the coal bed methane extraction process to be merely evaporated away? It is beyond me. These companies are not doing anything illegal; it is quite legal. One of the conditions of their licence is that they can actually evaporate this water away. I want to talk a bit about the Queensland Gas Co. It has put a proposal to the federal government, under the National Water Initiative, for financial assistance to build a water pipeline so as to be able to sell this water into markets in the Condamine-Murray-Darling Basin system, particularly for towns in that region. The Queensland Gas Co. is to be commended for its actions because it wants to amend the use of the water, which is merely being evaporated away now, and to use a process of reverse osmosis to provide potable water for urban communities. Some of the water that is a by-product of that reverse osmosis process could also be used for industries. The size of the known water reserves that, over the next 20 years, will be extracted the fields that the Queensland Gas Co. is operating in at the moment is quite staggering. There are something like 352,000 megalitres of water that is known to be available over the next 20 years just from the into current extraction wells of the Queensland Gas Co. There are other wells in the region from other companies. North of Roma, where I live, I know that for a number of years they have been evaporating the water away once they have extracted the coal bed methane. There is a large number of them. But, going back to the proposal of the Queensland Gas Co., 352,000 megalitres of water is known to be available over the next 20 years. The City of Toowoomba right now has a proposal, under the National Water Initiative, in front of the federal government for some money to secure more water or to have more sustainability in their water supply. Toowoomba is a city of some 95,000 people and it needs something like 14,000 megalitres of water per year. To put that context, that is 352,000 megalitres of water over the next 20 years just from the operations of the Queensland Gas Co. that will evaporate unless something is done to assist companies to utilise this water in ways other than just evaporating it away. Put another way, 352,000 megalitres of water would provide enough water for 20 years for 2.388 million people. That gives you some idea of the sheer magnitude of the water that will be evaporated away unless something changes in the way we use it and unless financial sistance comes from both the Queensland and the federal governments. Progressive towns in my electorateDalby, Chinchilla and Miles-are all looking with great interest at this water source. They recognise that, if they are able to buy this water at affordable prices-because at the end of the day they would have to on-sell from this water to the residents of these local council areas-and if they are able to enter into contracts with the Queensland Gas Co. and other companies that are in this industry, it will release water from their sources now the Condamine-Balonne-Murray-Darling Basin system. In other words, if we are able to see a process whereby this water is not evaporated away but is put through a process of reverse osmosis and then the potable water is made available to these shires-and I know the Chinchilla Shire has shown a great deal of interest in this-then we will see a market for that water. The water would be released and, I would suggest, they would be then able to sell their current allocation of water out of the Condamine River. That would be a win-win situation for the community and for the environment because it would release that water for other purposes downstream or for environmental flows. Mr Deputy Speaker, you can see that what I grieve about this afternoon is that, whilst into current licensing conditions allow these companies that are in the coal bed methane extraction industry to merely evaporate water away, we must do more than that in the future. I am supporting the application of the Queensland Gas Co. under the National Water Initiative for financial support for that project because of the benefits that will flow to industry, the community and the environment. At the end of the day we will be utilising a resource on the driest continent on earth. It is one of the most valuable resources as- we have-I could almost say that it is more valuable to us than the coal bed methane gas itself. We have to use water better in the future, and I am strongly in support of seeing this water not being evaporated away but utilised to a greater extent for industry and the community.

Speaker: Mr HAYES
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Werriwa) (6.10 pm)Before my contribution to this second reading debate on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 was interrupted by question time last Thursday, I had made a number of comments about how tax issues had troubled the Treasurer during the whole time he has been in that position. The pressure placed on the Treasurer by the opposition last week, and obviously by the coalition backbench, resulted in the resignation last Friday of the cause of the Treasurer's latest tax problemMr Gerard. The resignation of Mr Gerard from the board of the Reserve Bank is proof of the poor judgment of the Treasurer in appointing him in the first place. Despite the strong protestations of government members who have said that the government had no influence over the decision of Mr Gerard to resign, I find that a little bit difficult to believe. The whole affair demonstrates the poor judgment of the Treasurer in this regard. I found it particularly interesting to read the comment of an unnamed coalition member who is reported to have said

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This is very complex legislation relating to the tax act. The member should be asked to return to the details of the legislation from which he has removed the himself by a very far distinction in talking about an issue

Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
