Speaker: Mr HAYES
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: In deference to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will do that, but I think my comments reflect on the bill in terms of to the the decisions being made by the Treasurer, who is responsible for the administration of the tax act. The Treasurer's problems with taxation do not stop with what occurred last week. As my colleague will probably be able to attest, there was correspondence from coalition backbenchers to the Treasurer-which I referred to last week-that detailed a couple of key issues of concern about this very piece of legislation. It said that, firstly, legislation should more fully reflect the Treasury recommendations contained in the review of self-assessment report; secondly, the legislation should have specific application to the groups who complained and prompted the Treasury review; thirdly, the legislation should apply retrospectively; and, finally, there should be greater controls on the commissioner's ongoing ability to retrospectively and unilaterally make determinations. As I said last week, that correspondence was sent by coalition backbenchers to the Treasurer to consider in relation to this legisto lation. I have no doubt that these are pretty insightful comments but at the same time they offer a damning criticism when they are ignored. And that is precisely what did occur-they were ignored. Unlike the Treasurer in this regard, Labor are willing to consider the issues that have been raised by the coalition backbench. We on this side of the House are willing to take the tax proposals that were rejected by Treasurer Costello and would be prepared to give effect to them as appropriate. I urge all of the signatories to that correspondence to the Treasurer, who have expressed concerns about this bill, to have the courage of their commitment and stand up to the Treasurer. You are on common ground with us in many respects on this matter. While I feel that the provisions of this could have gone further-and, as a matter of fact, should have gone further-I do support the increase in the level of certainty that these changes bring to Australian taxpayers. Having said that, I cannot rise to speak on a bill concerning issues of tax without passing comment on the pretty feeble attempt by the Treasurer to reduce the pages of the income tax legislation by, as he claims, 30 per cent. According to the Treasurer's media release on 24 November, the Board of Taxation esthe timates that 2,100 pages of the combined income tax assessment acts can be repealed. The Treasurer claims that this is the largest simplification of tax legislation in Australian history. Of course it is: the tax acts have become so unwieldy that cutting out 2,100 pages is by any means a considerable change. The Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 have a combined total of 6,450 pages. When you take into account the ancillary legislation, there are, as I understand it, some 10,000 pages of legislation. So the Treasurer has decided that it is time give the 25-centimetre thick, four-volume tax assessment acts a bit of a prune. This will only get them back to the level of the taxation acts he inherited back in 1996; he will only be able to prune the tax assessment acts back to the size when he got control of the legislation in 1996. That is not reform. Sure, it is important that periodically we do act to trim the size of legislation by removing clauses which are redundant, cumbersome or infrequently used-but let us not kid ourselves: that is not reform. Unlike other so called reforms by government-such as the Work Choices or Welfare to Work provisions, which tear at the very fabric of Australian society-throwing out clauses in the tax acts that have passed their use-by date is hardly radical reform. It seems that the Treasurer has lost even bill the modicum of reformist zeal that he had at the start of his nine years in office in control of the tax system. The Australian taxpayer has nothing to fear from these reformsmind you, they have little to gain either-but at least there is nothing hiding in the fine print as is the case with many other initiatives of this government. The only changes that the Treasurer has set about making to the tax laws since he has had carriage of them have resulted either in pages being added to the tax laws or in middle Australia missing out on tax cuts. In 1996, the tax acts were 3,500 pages long. Now there are nearly 10,000 pages of tax law-a threefold increase. The Treasurer's record is not a thing to be admired when it comes to tax reform, and it seems that the coalition backbench is starting to work that out. Under the Australian income tax system, if you are an ordinary PAYE taxpayer you pay tax. You are not able to avoid tax like some millionaires around the country seem to be able to. I understand that before the 1996 election both parties were advised that it was possible for millionaires to reduce their average tax bill to around 25 per cent. At that time that rate was below the rate that would have been paid by ordinary working Australians on $40,000 per annum. Nine years later, we have the highest taxing government in Australian history and what does a recent study from the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research show us? It reports that the nation's wealthiest households are still paying a tax rate of around 25 per cent. What a sensational effort by this government: after nine years and a threefold increase in the number of pages in the tax acts, the wealthiest Australians are still enjoying a tax rate below that of ordinary working Australians. Working Australians in my electorate would love nothing more than to be able to minimise their tax to the same extent that the Treasurer continues to allow the richest among us to do. It is quite clear that there deep-seated economic inefficiencies contained in Australia's current taxation regime. A tax regime that allows the highest of income earners to pay less tax than the average income earner has got to be seen as being in desperate need of repair. As the Treasurer said himself in the lead-up to the 1998 election: High tax rates mean rich people spend more time and money on tax planning to reduce their tax liabilities. Low-income earners who cannot afford such advice keep paying more tax. He is dead right about that. This makes complete sense when you consider taxation statistics which show that almost half of all individual taxpayers seek professional taxation advice that produces a total deduction in the tax system of around $1 billion annually. When individual taxpayers consider it necessary and in their interests to spend $1 billion on tax advice, surely we must realise that there is something crook in the system. When you dig a bit deeper into the tax statistics, the case for reform of income tax starts to become somewhat overwhelming. Probably the biggest inefficiency-and the greatest opportunity for rorting the tax system-comes about because of the sometimes very generous claims for work related deductions that are allowed. Don't get me wrong: work related deductions are often necessary and do reflect the fact that in order to work many people sometimes need to make purchases directly related to their occupation. But, given the current level of deductions, you would have to ask a couple of questions. In the 2002-03 financial year, there were some 10.7 million taxpayers who reported a total income of $381.2 billion. A total of $20.7 billion was claimed in deductions, about half of which were work related deductions. When billions of dollars are claimed in work related deductions, it seems are to me that these deductions are starting to move away from the reasons for which they were introduced and to become means of lowering taxable income and avoiding or at least minimising tax liabilities. While the Treasurer feels that lopping off redundant and unused parts of the tax acts is radical reform, there is an overwhelming need to address Australia's income tax system at a more fundamental level. I take this opportunity to again call on the government to get serious about tax reform, to get serious about putting incentive back into the tax system and to get serious about providing tax cuts for the more than 80 per cent of income earners in my electorate of Werriwa who missed out on the tax cuts in the last budget and are now seeing their money locked up in a $14 billion surplus that this government seems to have little desire to let go of.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: O'Connor) (6.23 pm)The member for Werriwa raised a spark of hope in this place. At one point he indicated that the opposition would be supportive of a more generous response to the great difficulty in which many taxpayers throughout Australia have found themselves in various aspects of their tax affairs and their dealings with the commissioner, which to some degree the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 seeks to address. So I rushed down in excitement to get a copy of the proposed amendment put forward by the Labor opposition. As is typical, it is best described as a pious amendment. It reads: Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government ... I thought the member for Werriwa was going to tell us how further positive amendments might be included in this legislation, something that members and the signatories to the letter he referred to, of which I am one, might have taken an interest in. But what is in this pious amendment? It seeks to condemn the government for: (1) maintaining and allowing the self assessment system to so seriously deteriorate over a long period of time so these radical reforms are needed; What change does that particular amendment bring to the House? The next clause states: (2) failing to provide sufficient certainty on how oral advice will be recorded and made available; That is quite a good point, but there is nothing in black and white to support it. Finally: (3) failure to clarify in this bill how the personal tax affairs of a taxpayer will be linked to the tax affairs of a company with which the taxpayer is associated. Okay, if there is opportunity for amendment in that regard, and considering the fact that day after day in this place the opposition complain about their lack of opportunity to properly examine legislation, surely now is the time to put forward amendments of substance and have a discussion and a debate about them. They say these opportunities for debate are so important to them when, of course, if anyone listened to their contributions on the IR legislation, for instance, there was constant repetition of ‘the sky is falling in' and no proper analysis of the legislation being debated-then or now. It is not too hard to talk constructively about legislation of this nature. In a speech earlier today, I gave a tick to the member for Rankin for his very sensible remarks about petrol pricing. I live in hope that, when I conclude my contribution, he will bring some light to this debate in terms of positive measures to deliver to the Australian people the simplicity, certainty and equity that define a good tax. But he does not have much opportunity because, presumably, his caucus or his executive have decided that the amendment I just read out is the opposition's position on this legislation. I have said in this place time and time again that good tax law will be the responsibility of this parliament, not the government of the day. But I can say with some pride that when the Hawke government and, for that matter, the Keating government brought matters of substance into this place that gave the impression of being good for Australia, such as floating the currency and other matters, it was the opposition, of which I was a member, that said, ‘Good on you.' I have said before-and I want to seriously discuss this bill-that when Keating as Treasurer proposed the sale of the Commonwealth Bank he was able to get that through caucus as an icon issue for the Labor Party because he could tell them there would be no mischief emanating from the coalition opposition. We believe in privatisation and we supported that measure. As I recollect, there was criticism by the minor parties in the Senate that they were sidelined in the debate because the two major parties actually came to a decision that they believed was right for Australia. In tax particularly, where scare campaigns are so easy to run, it is time that there was a bipartisan view. It is not helped by the member for Werriwa complaining that his constituents did not get a big enough tax cut. When he is next handing out material that asks people to vote for him, he wants to just check out how many of his constituents actually fell into the previous 42c level. Obviously not all of them would have, but I will bet you there were too many. Of course, it is a fact that, many years ago, to break into those top marginal rates you had to earn 15 times average weekly earnings. Today the figure has reduced to between one and twoI am not sure exactly where it is at this moment. It is silly, it is wrong and it is not It is not equitable. Therefore, there is an ongoing battle in the broader context of tax to have a review of taxation. I note frequently people standing up and saying, ‘You can only erode revenue so far.' I do not disagree with that. The Australian people, sometimes unwisely, seem to be more interested in having cash for an overseas trip than to pay the doctor. That is their view; it is not one to which I subscribe. On the other hand, governments are expected by the people to raise money to defend the country and provide certain services. That does not mean that we cannot revisit the structures of tax. As I have informed the House before, there are numerous ways that would allow us to reduce high rates of tax, which I think are very regressive, without significant reduction in revenue. It is not appropriate for me to go through those today having just suggested to another member, who got widely off the issue of income tax, to not speak about it. The explanatory memorandum gives us clear advice that the principal outcome of this legislation is to address a serious problem for the community-that is, the legal capacity of the tax commissioner to revisit self-assessment arrangements years after the event. Having assessed that the claims previously made by a taxpayer were not consistent with the law-most taxpayers have never had the financial capacity to take the commissioner on in the courts, unless it is a collective decision-the commissioner can say, ‘You avoided x dollars tax. I am applying a 50 per cent penalty and interest rates as high as 11 or 12 per cent compounded up until the point of advice, until the point I have told you that I think you are wrong.' Those who have dealt in the usury market would soon discover how gigantic compound interest can be. It can double a debt in a very short period. Some taxpayers, shocked by fair. this arrangement, are sometimes reassured by, for instance, promoters of various schemes who say: ‘You'll be right, mate; hang in there; we are going to take the tax office to court.' If and when the taxpayer loses, the clock has continued to tick up until that point. That is not good enough. An example that really concerned me was when a group of taxpayers sought relief from tax by contributing to an agricultural program that had received a product ruling from the tax commissioner of being acceptable under the tax act. Yet, later on, this group received a request for huge amounts of money because, in the view of the tax commissioner-eventually supported by a court-the promoter of the scheme had not complied with all aspects of the ruling. That is fine. You had better sue the promoter. Who does that? These taxpayers were not advised in a short period of that matter. The very high interest rate clock continued to operate. This legislation is doing something about that. More particularly, it is a step in the direction. Nevertheless, I am concerned that, if a taxpayer has made full disclosure of all their affairs-which I think is fundamental to self-assessment-but in that process has claimed a deduction for a scheme or other matters that might be in dispute by the tax commissioner, there needs to be a prompt response. It appears that this legislation, in the normal course of business, will limit the tax commissioner's opportunity in which to respond to a fair and reasonable tax return to two years. That to me is a fair and reasonable proposition. I am less enamoured of the fact that, where a scheme is involved, the response can be extended to four years. It is better than the never-never plan of the past, but it is still a long time if the clock is to be clicked back to the day of lodgement of the return. I may stand corrected by the member for Rankin, but my understanding is that this legislation says that the commissioner has up to four years but that the clock starts ticking after he writes back. I believe that that should be a component of any legislation. In other words, you cannot be charged, in the case of full disclosure, with interest or penalties until you get an objection to your selfassessment from the commissioner. I will continue to campaign for that arrangement. I have been told by a very senior member of the tax office that that is possible. I have argued directly to the tax office on behalf of the people of Australia that you ought to be able to have a yellow, red or brightly coloured form that you put on the front of your tax return-I do not know how you transmit that electronically, but we are into coloured copiers now, so maybe it can be donewhich says: ‘Red alert! I have participated in the woop woop scheme. Everything I tell you in this return is true. This is how much right money I have taken, but I am claiming an additional reduction in my tax of $5,000'or $10,000-‘because of my participation in this scheme.' If you give that sort of notice, it seems simple to me that the commissioner's clock has to start ticking. I would think that in those circumstances something measured in days, or a very short period of months, would be available to the commissioner in which to say, ‘No, I'm not happy with that. I advise you to pay your full tax. On the other hand, if future debate proves I'm wrong, I'll give you your money back.' Wouldn't it be nice if the commissioner added a bit of interest! The reality is that, whilst this legislation goes part of the way, it unfortunately does not address the circumstances that many people have found themselves in. There has been some moderation of the commissioner's claims, and I thank the ATO for that. And this legislation does clear up a lot of the grey areas. It is summarised by the advisers in this area in the explanatory memorandum under ‘Summary of regulation impact statement', which says: The new law will provide improved ways for taxpayers to find out the Commissioner of Taxation's (Commissioner's) view on how certain laws apply, so that the risks of uncertainty when self assessing, or working out their tax obligations or entitlements, are reduced. This is achieved by: making rulings available to many taxpayers on a wide range of matters; ensuring that the Commissioner provides rulings in a timely manner; enabling the Commissioner to obtain, and make rulings based on, relevant information; protecting taxpayers from increases in tax and from penalties and interest where they rely on rulings; limiting the ways the Commissioner can alter rulings to a taxpayer's detriment; and giving protection from interest charges where a taxpayer relies on other advice from the Commisinterest sioner, or on the Commissioner's general administrative practice. All that is positive. I am in here to support the legislation. But I would have been much more comfortable if there had been a greater degree of retrospectivity. I voted against retrospective tax in this place when it was an imposition on the taxpayer. It was a very lonely day. I think six of us sat in splendid isolation on one side of the parliament whilst the entire Labor opposition and the then Fraser government members sat on the other side. We must have gone very close to the problem that Harry Quick had the other night with another piece of legislation. The reality is that we held out very strongly against negative retrospective tax law or, for that matter, any negative retrospective legislation that shifts the goalposts after the event. I stand by that. But, as this would have been a positive measure, I think that probably we ought to have had a better response to taxpayers who got trapped in the schemes for an inordinately long period. I am not arguing in this place that people who incorrectly reduced their taxation should have got away with paying the tax. But if the ATO is unable to advise them of the failing of their request within a few months, it becomes unfair to the taxpayer, presuming they have made full disclosure. This legislation does not exclude people from the normal processes of the previous tax act where they have taken fraudulent or other actions that are means of evasion. The explanatory memorandum tells us: The unlimited amendment period for cases of fraud or evasion will continue to apply. I am not putting any argument there. But, where people make a full disclosure of their income and consequently seek to have certain reduction in that amount of money, then, if they do that through appropriate advice, they should not be subject to any penalties or until the tax commissioner disagrees with their claim. That is not part of this legislation at this point. I trust that the parliament might one day decide that that is a good idea. As I said, when the parliament can get up and bring in a much more simplified tax system, it could be reduced to not many more items than exist in the new IR legislation when it comes to awards. That would be a good idea. I am a great supporter of the GST. It should be collected at a level that fully compensates the states for all their regressive taxes. I do not think they have one that is a good idea. When people are paying $30 a week throughout their life in stamp duty on their personal residence, that is just an example of how bad some of those taxes are. All in all, I support this legislation. I would have liked it to go further, but I reject any suggestion that at this point in time the opposition has made any productive contribution to the legislation. Considering the public announcements of the member for Swan, the opposition had a responsibility to put up some decent amendments if it believed in them.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005. This bill arises out of concerns expressed in recent years by taxpayers and accountants in circumstances where the Australian Taxation Office issues an amended tax assessmentoften, in the process, overturning previous advice which taxpayers had relied upon. Bills like this, of course, go to the heart of the integrity of our tax system and the stewardship of our tax system. As I speak, we now know that Mr Ron Walker was told by Mr Gerard about his tax problems prior to the appointment of Mr Gerard to the Reserve Bank board.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I warn the member for Lilley

Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Order! Resume your seat. I give you fair warning that the naming of people and going through tax matters, unless it directly relates to this bill, will not be entertained in this chamber.

Speaker: Mr SWAN
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: It seems that everybody knew about this particular tax problem except the Treasurer, Peter Costello. As every day goes by, the Treasurer gets in deeper and deeper. I say that it is about time the Treasurer came clean on these matters and told the truth. The public has had enough of the Treasurer's false denials. But let me go back to the bill. Public concern led to a process of review announced by the Treasurer in November 2003. The Review of Aspects of Income Tax Self Assessment was intended to examine whether an appropriate balance had been struck between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole community. This bill introduces the recommendations from the review that require legislative change. In particular the bill proposes, firstly, to reduce the time period within which the ATO can audit a taxpayer-reducing it from four years to two years for those with simple tax affairs and from six years to four years for taxpayers with more complex affairs. Secondly, it proposes to alter the process by which tax rulings are made: to ensure that, where a taxpayer relies upon ATO advice, including oral advice formally requested, that taxpayer will be free from penalties; to expand the situations in which the commissioner is bound by advice tendered to the taxpayer; to specify time limits for the provision of a ruling; to allow the ruling to be made electronically; and to give the commissioner more flexibility about the date at which a ruling applies. On the whole the Labor Party sees the proposals contained in this bill as progressive and, as such, it will be supported. The nature of our income tax system, with its self-assessment regime, is that it seeks to ease the administrative burden on taxpayers when complying with tax law. The system operates to a large degree on trust, with taxpayers submitting details of their arrangements to the ATO without substantiation per se. However, the system places an onus on individual taxpayers to substantiate their affairs should the ATO conduct a review. Such reviews and detailed audits, if necessary, are conducted on a risk basis, depending on the particular taxpayer's affairs and whether particular claims are in excess of what would be expected for a taxpayer in similar circumstances. At most times the system works well; sometimes it does not. It is difficult to get the balance right. There will always be those who seek to exploit the system and avoid paying their fair share of tax. We have seen plenty of debate about that in recent weeks in this parliament. People want to know that the system is administered in an impartial way and that all taxpayers are treated equally. People want to know that there is not a double standard in the tax system, one for a few select mates of the government and entirely another for those struggling small businesses who are coping with the GST and for those working taxpayers who are paying PAYG tax. On the other hand, there are sometimes occasions when taxpayers find the law confusing and request clarification from the tax office. Typically, they receive advice and act on it in good faith. Occasionally, the tax office may revisit this advice and issue amended assessments to those taxpayers who originally relied on the tax office's advice. These taxpayers in turn feel aggrieved at this retrospective action, even though the amended assessment is often made with a more contemporary understanding of the tax law, in the light of emerging circumstances that have the potential to threaten the tax base. Given such events, the changes made in this bill are a step in the right direction. The changes in this bill to make rulings binding in more circumstances and to reduce the time frame for issuing amended assessments should increase the onus on the tax office to get it right the first time. This is a good thing, but ultimately these changes are a compromise. They are an attempt to rebalance the relationship between the taxpayer and the tax office, as each grapples with an overly complex tax system-for we do, of course, have a complex tax system. We now have some 9,500 pages of tax law-up from some 3,500 pages when the government was elected over nine years ago. Those pages include current and inoperative provisions and thousands of pages of taxation rulings and determinations. Surely if we are interested in improving the administration and fairness of the system we should tackle the root cause. Tedious and overly complex tax law will always result in more disputes than simpler laws. There is a need for simplicity. The truth is we need a simpler tax system that is easier for taxpayers to comply with and for the tax office to police. That is why the integrity of the tax system is so important. That is why the person administering the tax system and its integrity must be seen to have acted in an impartial way and must be seen not to be favouring one particular taxpayer over classes of other taxpayers. Now, despite promising to cut the burden of red tape, the Treasurer has ‘slashed' the number of pages in the tax act from an estimated 3,500 to more than 9,000. Given this record, it was extraordinary to see the Treasurer's announcement on 24 November about cutting some 2,000 pages from the tax act by repealing inoperative provisions. He heralded this as a major reform, but it was a joke. Indeed, he went on to claim that this was ‘the biggest overhaul of legislation that has ever been done in Australian history.' I kid you not. The truth is this is not tax reform; it is just window-dressing. Ridding the act of provisions that are no longer current is a good thing, but it is not reform; it is just housekeeping. The farcical thing is that tax practitioners will still need to keep the 2,000 pages of inoperative provisions, so that they can deal with retrospective tax assessments. The truth is, if the government were concerned about simplifying the tax law, they would look at truly streamlining it. That would mean revisiting the complex system of deductions, concessions and tax offsets that have seen expenditures explode under the coalition. It would also mean looking at ways to simplify the way that tax is administered and the way individual taxpayers interact with the tax office. For example, why doesn't the government contemplate measures that have the potential to end the annual grind of completing a fully-fledged tax return? Plenty of ideas have come forward, like streamlining annual income tax returns by simply issuing assessment notices to those with a history of simple claims and asking them to verify the assessment as is or amend it as necessary. Such a system could deliver significant administrative savings and ease the burden on taxpayers. I urge the Treasurer to consider proposals such as these. He has not had such a good time of late when it comes to tax, Mr Deputy Speaker-you may well have noticed thatbut we know he collects record amounts of it. He is the highest taxing Treasurer in Australian history. That tax take is built off the back of ordinary taxpayers on low and middle incomes, who expect to be treated fairly. I urge the Treasurer to stand shoulder to shoulder with those taxpayers rather than with a few of his mates from the Liberal Party, as he has been doing in recent weeks in this parliament. He needs to reduce the tax and compliance burden. It is a reform that is essential for the economy and one that would be pivotal in boosting our nation's productivity. These are all substantive issues, and they need to be addressed. The bill we are debating today is a small improvement, but it does not lessen the obligation on the Treasurer to come into this parliament and tell the truth about Mr Gerard.

Speaker: Mr ROBB
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005. I am pleased to support the amendments to our tax laws in this bill. These are measures designed to improve certainty to taxpayers, particularly in two areas: time frames for tax audits; and public, private and oral rulings. These two areas have caused a great deal of uncertainty in recent years and this is a very important series of amendments to our tax laws. I am pleased to speak to the amendments in this bill because of the distress that uncertions tainty in the past has caused many individuals, including a number of my constituents who have been adversely affected by what are commonly known as mass marketing schemes as well as employment benefit arrangements-people who believed they had sound advice from financial agents and who acted on the advice of these promoters in schemes that were understood to be legal ways of minimising tax. In many cases the Australian Taxation Commission has altered interpretations, causing great financial and emotional stress to individuals. The changes in this bill will in future remove much of this uncertainty and the associated potential for distress. As the member for Canning has done before me, I would also like to thank the member for Longman, Mal Brough, for the initiative he has taken as Assistant Treasurer to see sensible settlement of outstanding cases and for his introduction of these amendments to the House, amendments that should help in the future by ensuring that the commissioner is bound by undertakings made. The bill provides a capacity for the taxpayer to rely on public and private rulings or oral advice formally requested from the commissioner without penalty, even if that advice is subsequently deemed incorrect or the commissioner's interpretation subsequently changes. The main aim of the tax administration system is to collect revenue with a minimum of compliance and administrative costs. To this end our tax system has operated via a self-assessment system since 1986. Under this system taxpayers' returns are accepted in the first instance and the tax office may subsequently review the accuracy of the information in the return within a prescribed period. Essentially, the self-assessment system requires taxpayers to perform certain funcand take some responsibility that was previously taken by the tax office. Under the old system taxpayers provided the tax office with the relevant information and the tax office then assessed their liabilities accordingly. Under this system the obligation to the taxpayer was to provide full and true disclosure and the assessment was left to the ATO. After the tax office made assessments they could amend an assessment that had an error of fact or calculation but could not of law. Under this system taxpayers had a measure of certainty, while the costs to the tax office were borne by the community as a whole. However, under the self-assessment system the ATO still issues notices of assessment, but returns are generally taken at face value, subject to a post-assessment risk based audit and other verification checks. Under the self-assessment system the tax office is allowed to amend errors of calculation, fact and law after processing the assessment or paying a refund. The self-assessment system changed the balance of cost and risk between the tax office and the taxpayer. The selfassessment system also allows for more efficient use of tax office resources so that more revenue can be collected for less revenue costs. In the early nineties problems had been identified with the self-assessment system. The problems related to the penalties and interest and the need to provide greater certainty to the taxpayer. We are still trying to come to grips with some of these problems. When the balance changed between the cost and risk of the ATO and the taxpayer under self-assessment, some of these problems emerged due to penalties and interest and the need to provide greater certainty accordingly. In 1992 the Keating government brought in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Act, with the most notable changes being a new system of binding public rulings, a new system of binding private rulings, an extension to four years of the period within which a taxpayer could object to an assessment, a new system requiring penalties for underassessments of income tax liabilities based on the requirement that taxpayers exercise reasonable care and a new interest system for underpayments or late payments of income tax based on commercial princifix errors ples and market interest rates. Since coming to office in 1996 the Howard government has shortened the period of review for taxpayers with straightforward affairs; introduced binding oral advice; reduced the interest rate on shortfalls and late payments; and introduced the office of the Inspector-General of Taxation, a new statutory office with governance responsibility. This brings me to the current review and the new legislation against those matters introduced since 1986 and subsequently amended and improved. In December 2003 the Treasurer announced that the Treasury would be conducting a review into the self-assessment system. The review was asked to consider whether certain aspects of the self-assessment system achieved the right balance between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue stream to benefit all Australians. The review was not asked to consider fundamental tax policy changes. These amendments do not go to fundamental tax policy changes. In 2003 the review considered a wide range of issues and held discussions with many groups. Following the initial analysis, in 2004 the Treasurer released a discussion paper and 30 comprehensive submissions were received. Key comments in the submissions were criticism of the accessibility of advice from the ATO, criticism of uncertainty in relation to ATO interpreted decisions-this has been the underpinning of much of what we have in front of us todaycriticism about private rulings and great concern that the penalties for failing to follow a ruling discouraged people from applying for private binding rulings unless they were confident of getting a favourable ruling. The discussion paper was amended in the light of those submissions and the final report was released in December 2004. The government subsequently announced that it would adopt the 30 legislative recommendations made in the report. This bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Taxation Administration Act 1953. Schedule 1 of this bill reduces the periods during which the commissioner may amend income tax assessments in a range of circumstances. This is a very important provision. For most individuals with straightforward returns, the period will be two years. Currently it is four years. The majority of taxpayers will fall into this band. four-year period will apply to taxpayers with more complex affairs. These can include people who carry on a business which does not participate in the simplified tax system; taxpayer who is a beneficiary of a trust estate; a taxpayer who has entered into or carried out a scheme for the sole or dominant purpose of obtaining a scheme benefit; and other special cases as prescribed by regulation. The period of review and amendment of assessments involving arrangements with the dominant purpose of avoiding tax will be four years. Fraud or evasion cases will continue to have an unlimited amendment period. These amendments apply to assessments for the 2004-05 income year and later income years and are a very important part of improving the certainty associated with many of these tax issues. Rulings are the second major area of this legislation. The tax office gives a wide range of advice to taxpayers and their representatives about how, in the tax office's opinion, tax law applies or would apply. That advice ranges from general information for the public to advice relating to specific taxation rangements. Since 1992 the tax law has made certain categories of advice, called rulings, binding on the tax office. There are three kinds of rulings: public rulings, private rulings and oral rulings. Oral rulings were enacted in 1999 in response to a range of recommendations. They are available to individuals who apply to the tax office for a ruling on the way in which the income tax law applies to them. Oral rulings are only available on interpretive matters that are straightforward or simple, and they are legally binding on the Commissioner of Taxation if they result in a lower amount of final tax payable by the taxpayer. The object of the new system in front of A us is to provide improved ways for taxpayers to find out the commissioner's views on applying certain laws and to reduce the risk of self-assessing. Previously, the commissioner a was able to give public and private rulings only on issues of tax liability. This included income tax, withholding tax, mining withholding tax, Medicare levy, fringe benefits tax, franking deficit tax, venture capital deficit tax, overfranking tax and product grant and benefit laws. Under the new system, the commissioner will be able to make rulings on the above, plus on matters of administration and collection of those taxes in relation to the rulings regime. Another new measure under this package is that, where oral advice is provided by the tax office and is reasonably relied upon by the taxpayer, that taxpayer will not have interest or penalties imposed. Also, the new measures will mean that, if an oral ruling is sought in writing, there is protection granted against an amended assessment which would impose a higher primary tax. This bill will also give taxpayers further protection when they rely on advice or other administrative practices of the tax office. Currently, when a artaxpayer relies on other advice or general administrative practices of the tax office, the taxpayer is protected from penalties but does incur interest on the tax debt. In many cases, this has caused enormous distress and great uncertainty, with serious bills mounting up. In some cases, businesses have gone to the wall because of this uncertainty and the interest on this tax debt. Under the new system, a taxpayer will be protected from both penalties and interest when relying on other advice or general administrative procedures. Documents outlining rulings can include any publication that the commissioner makes, such as fact sheets. If a document says it is non-binding, these new provisions do not apply. In addition to the above, this new bill provides that the tax office will produce rulings in a style that is simple and easy to understand. In the submissions received by this inquiry, one of the issues that featured was the difficulty for the general public in understanding public rulings. There have been some serious problems in many parts of Australia across many groups. The provisions and the uncertainty have been used and abused by those advocating schemes that have caused much uncertainty to many law-abiding people. People who acted in a way that they thought was legal have subsequently suffered from changed determinations by the tax office. This bill will provide a greater level of certainty for taxpayers by expanding the current selfassessment system, giving protection to taxpayers in a wider range of circumstances. I commend the bill to the House.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: The reason the parliament is debating the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 is straightforward: the income tax system is riddled with lurks and loopholes. The complexity of the tax system has increased astronomically under this government and the opportunities for avoidance have risen commensurately. I was a member of a House of Representatives inquiry into mass marketed schemes. That inquiry was originally about employee share ownership arrangements and ostensibly was about more closely aligning the interests of employers and employees through concessionary arrangements for the acquisition of shares by employees. But the inquiry unearthed a very high level of tax avoidance, not only through employee share ownership schemes but, much more prevalently, through managerial arrangements where very well paid executives got into tax avoidance through schemes that were promoted aggressively by unscrupulous operators. That inquiry heard evidence that a conservative estimate of the contributions to such schemes was $1.5 billion. We on the Labor side suspected that it would be much larger than that, because that estimate was not much more than a back-of-the-envelope calculation. There has been a proliferation of private binding rulings, and this legislation clarifies the rules applying to those rulings. In that sense, it is welcome legislation and Labor supports it. But, to give you some idea of the dimensions of the problem, during the inquiry about which I spoke we heard evidence on 11 May 2000 from officials of the tax office that every year the tax office would issue over 3,000 private binding rulings. That is an astonishingly large number of private binding rulings and it certainly does highlight the complexity of the tax system. During the winter recess, while that inquiry was still under way, the Auditor-General issued a report entitled The Australian Taxation Office's administration of taxation rulings. On page 99 of that report, it says: For the calendar year 2000 the ATO issued 89,779 PBRs ... No, you have not misheard me: it was not 8,900 private binding rulings but 89,779 in one year. Upon further investigation, it became clear that a large number of those were in relation to the so-called streamlined new tax system for the new century, the GST, which was meant to simplify tax arrangements. It had obviously done anything but that, as evidenced by the fact that the tax office in one year alone had to issue such a massive number of private binding rulings. I have not been successful in obtaining information from the government on how many private binding rulings have been issued since then. I do believe that it would be in the public interest for us to know that. I am not sure that it is a state secret, but I am sure that the government is a little reluctant to provide that information. So, in anticipation of the debate, today I have lodged questions in writing. We will see if we have more luck in this term of the parliament in getting answers to those questions. I certainly will be pressing the matter if we have a repetition of the situation in the past, where I have put questions on the Notice Paper, have pleaded with the Speaker to get answers from the Treasurer and have been unsuccessful right through the term of the parliament. At the end of that parliament, those questions lapse. Then you start all over again and he just sweats it out for another three years. He will not get away with it this time. I will make a very big fuss about it if these basic figures are not provided. Further evidence of the poor state of repair of the income tax base in Australia is provided by the annual statement of tax expenditures. These are basically the concessions, the tax breaks, that are available, which do cost money in revenue forgone but also have the characteristic of making the income tax system ever more complex. That does not mean that Labor or I oppose every such concession. For example, superannuation tax concessions are very important in promoting retirement incomes in this country. But, again to give you an idea of the dimensions of these concessions, there are now more than 240 tax expenditures and fully 89 of those have been created in just the last nine years of the coalition government. So, from the beginning of the Income Tax Act-I think it was 1932-through to 1996, in excess of 150 were created, but another 89 have been created in the short space of time since then. It shows that the income tax base in this country is under siege. It is under siege from a Treasurer who seems to place no weight on the integrity of the income tax system in this country. Further evidence of that are the new business tax arrangements that were introduced in the year 2000. Some members will recall the Treasurer sitting at the table, completing the negotiations with the then shadow Treasurer, the member for Hotham. The whole basis of those negotiations was that, yes, there was a case for reducing the company tax rate from 36c to 30c in the dollar but that this would be self-financed. That is, it would be revenue neutral, paid for by removing some of the tax concessions, the tax breaks, in the system and therefore providing a simpler company income tax system. Quite important in that equation was legislation related to the alienation of personal services income, which meant that sham contractor arrangements would be seen through by the income tax system. We supported that legislation, but the long and short of it is that, very recently, documents that were obtained by the Australian newspaper under freedom of information legislation revealed that the government has no idea as to how that particular piece of legislation is working. In other words, it has not put any genuine effort into enforcing the legislation that was part of that arrangement between the two major political parties in this country. I would also point out that part of that arrangement was the taxation of trusts in the same way as companies. The Treasurer signed a letter saying that would be part of improving the integrity of the income tax system, but he was rolled by the National Party. Here we have the Treasurer of the country being rolled by the member for New England, who himself was then rolled out of parliament. But the member for New England rolled the Treasurer and the government reneged on that commitment. You do get a sense from what I am saying-89,000 private binding rulings, 240 special tax breaks, the breaking of promises in relation to improving the integrity of the income tax system-that this Treasurer does not have his heart in doing what he should be doing: his job of ensuring that there is tax integrity and some tax morality in this country. Indeed, in the past week the Treasurer has done more to debase tax morality in this country than any Treasurer for 25 years. It a big statement and goes a long way back. But when we do go back 25 years to what I am referring to we reach the bottom-of-theharbour schemes, when the previous Liberal Party Treasurer, now the Prime Minister of Australia, presided over a massive tax evasion industry. It was called tax avoidance at that time, but it was outright evasion. They were contrived schemes. The Treasury begged the Treasurer of the day to legislate against the bottom-of-the-harbour schemesthe wet Slutzkins and the dry Slutzkins. He was dragged kicking and screaming, by Labor, to do something about it. The Treasurer of the day, the now Prime Minister, did not want to repair the income tax base back then. As a result, the remaining honest taxpayers were left with a top marginal rate of 60c in the dollar. Let us remember that the top marginal tax rate under the Fraser-Howard government was 60c in the dollar. In fact, the relevant marginal rates were all high because the government needed to obtain from honest taxpayers the revenue that was being avoided or evaded by dishonest taxpayers. Does that sound familiar? Come forward 25 years and here we have the same Liberal philosophy; that is, if you have some wealthy mates who can go their hardest in avoiding or evading tax, this government almost says that that is a legitimate activity. The government turns a blind eye to it. As a result, we have had high marginal rates of income tax incurred by people who are not necessarily wealthy but who are honest-and that is the difference. The honest taxpayers confront the high marginal rates of tax. The Australian newspaper, through a survey called HILDA, was able to confirm that the wealthiest Australians do not pay the top marginal rate of 48½c in the dollar. In fact, their average tax bill is about $28,000 a year, which is less than would be paid by an honis est taxpayer earning $100,000 a year. For the very wealthy, the income tax system in Australia is essentially a voluntary tax, as it was when the current Prime Minister was the Treasurer of this country during the notorious bottom-of-the-harbour arrangements. I say that the Treasurer has done more to debase tax morality in this country than any other Treasurer has for 25 years on the basis of the defence that he launched in favour of Mr Gerard. I recognise that I do not have the time to go through all of the statements that the Treasurer made in defending Mr Gerard, so I will point to only a couple to illustrate that point. The Treasurer said that Mr Gerard had ‘broken no law'. He got whacked with a penalty tax of 45 per cent. A penalty tax of 45 per cent is applied by the tax office in the case of blatant, contrived tax evasion arrangements. I do not think tax evasion should be condoned in this country, but the Treasurer spent last week saying that Mr Gerard was a fine man and a fine person to have on the board of the Reserve Bank. The Treasurer also said in this parliament that Mr Gerard had not avoided one dollar of taxthat was not for want of trying. Mr Gerard tried his little heart out to avoid paying $150 million of tax, but in the end he was caught by the tax office and defended stoutly by the Treasurer. The Treasurer said: ... Mr Gerard is eminently suitable to be a member of the Reserve Bank board. Mr Brough- Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. In examining the bill, I cannot find any determination, requirement or paragraph to do with Mr Gerard. I request that you bring the member back to the bill, which is the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 and that he not continue some witchhunt that the Labor Party is undertaking.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: the Assistant Treasurer should have done his homework and looked at (3) of the second reading amendment to the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005, which condemns the government for: ... failure to clarify in this bill how the tax affairs of a taxpayer will be linked to the tax affairs of a company with which the taxpayer is associated.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: There is no point of order.

Speaker: Dr EMERSON
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I repeat that the Treasurer said: ... Mr Gerard is eminently suitable to be a member of the Reserve Bank board. There you go: someone who has been whacked with a 45 per cent penalty tax is eminently suitable! That tells us a lot about the philosophy of this government and about the approach of the Treasurer. I do not always praise the member for Wentworth, Mr Turnbull, but on this occasion he has had the courage to say that the way to reduce high marginal rates of tax in this country is to repair the income tax base to remove some of these lurks, concessions and loopholes. That is what the member for Wentworth has been saying and he is right. Every self-respecting economist in Australia will tell you that the way forward for tax reform is to repair the income tax base and use the proceeds to reduce the marginal rates of tax that cause genuine disincentives in this country. I have argued long and hard, and will continue to do so, that a very important rate to reduce is the 42c rate. The 42c rate is paid by one million taxpayers who earn between $70,000 and $125,000 a year. One million taxpayers at present confront the 42c rate, but within the next three years 400,000 more taxpayers will confront it. They will move from a marginal rate of 30c to a marginal rate of 42c. These are people who are trying to get ahead, who are deciding whether to go for promotions and whether to work overtime-and 42c is a pretty steep rate. In a prebudget submission that I lodged with Treasury, upon invitation by the Treaspersonal urer to anyone who wanted to make a submission in advance of the budget, I suggested that an instalment could be made in the forthcoming budget to reduce the 42c rate to 36c, on the way to its total abolitionhalfway, indeed, to its total abolition. If that were to happen, think of the sort of system we would have. Ninety-seven per cent of taxpayers would face a top marginal rate of no higher than 30c in the dollar. That is genuine incentive. That is the restoration of incentive to work hard and to improve oneself. I differ from the member for Wentworth where he argues that the most important rate to reduce is the top marginal rate of 48½c in the dollar, counting the Medicare levy. That rate is paid by three per cent of taxpayers. It is clear to me that the much stronger case is to abolish the 42c rate. But then we have to consider the forgotten people. Who are they? The forgotten people are those who are on incomes of between $22,000 and $52,000 a year. The parliament will be astonished with this fact: under this government, between the year 2000 and the year 2008, the forgotten peoplehairdressers, receptionists, account clerks, metalworkers, farmhands and hospitality workers-will have had a tax cut totallingwait for it-$4 a week. This is the famous ‘sandwich and milkshake' tax cut that was delivered by this government in 2004. Yet by 2008, in that period, through bracket creep alone-that is just with the effects of inflation-they will be paying extra tax of between $17 and $31 a week. The reality is that the forgotten peoplethose of them who do not have children and therefore do not benefit from increases in family payments or any family payments at all-are footing the bill for the family payments system, which has been extended in this country to the very wealthy. The forgotten people are being smashed by this government. They are being hit with incentivecrushing, high marginal rates of income tax, yet they will have had one tax cut, and one tax cut only, of $4 a week in the entire eighthigh-flying, year period from 2000 to 2008. Their lot could be improved in a very affordable way by giving them a tax cut of $12 a week. How do we do that without making it completely unaffordable? The answer is: by increasing the low-income tax offset from $235 to $625 and converting it into a weekly or fortnightly pay-as-you-go payment. So they would get $12 a week, which is double the derisory tax cut that lowand middleincome earners received in the last budget; but the cut in the 42c rate to 36c would deliver very substantial tax cuts and improvements in incentives for people earning between $70,000 and $125,000. This proposal is a proposal for genuine reform. It is a down payment on an ultimate reform package that I also outlined in that submission. But, if we are going to genuinely achieve reform in this country, we must repair the income tax base. This legislation simply highlights the numerous tax lurks, concessions and holes that this Treasurer has poked into the system, very much at the urging of those on his backbench. That is why people get into trouble with mass-marketed tax schemesbecause the promoters of these schemes are forever saying, ‘I can give you 100 per cent return overnight if only you get into this scheme.' People get into the scheme, get into trouble and the rest, as they say, is history. We support this legislation, but Labor fundamentally support genuine tax reform. That means repairing the income tax base in order to fund reductions in the high marginal rates of tax faced by people on welfare and by those in the middle-income and higher income reaches as well. (Time expired)

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: I rise to speak on the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005. I probably will not be speaking about Robert Gerard this evening, because this amendment bill is really not about the high-avoiding taxpayer. It is very much about the average taxpayer who pays their fair share, largely through PAYG-about eight million individual taxpayers and about 745,000 very small businesses that do the right thing and deserve the trust of our government in a way that Robert Gerard does not. Firstly, I would like to comment on the name of the amendment bill. In the last couple of weeks we have seen this government play very loose with names when it comes to the truth. We have seen a Fair Pay Commission which is not fair; Work Choice, which is not about choice; and Welfare to Work, which is not about getting people to work. When I first saw the name of this bill, ‘Improvements to Self Assessment', I found myself thinking, ‘Oh no, they're going to scrap self-assessment,' because so far we have found very much with this government that the bill's name usually reflects the exact posite of the intent. But I am pleased to say that this bill really is about improvements to self-assessment, and it really does achieve substantial gains. I have not had much good to say about this government in the last couple of weeks, but I would like to acknowledge that this is a substantial improvement for nearly eight million individual taxpayers and 745,000 small businesses. These amendments came about thanks to a report called Report on aspects of income tax self assessment, released by the Treasurer in December 2004. The review commenced in November the preceding year and examined whether the right balance had been struck between protecting the rights of individual taxpayers and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole Australian community. There were 30 legislative recommendations made in the review. The first of the bills which gave effect to some of these changes, the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No.1) 2005, was passed into law earlier this year with the support of the opposition. This second piece of legislation gives effect to the remainder the reforms. It is very rare that I would commend this government for acting quickly. Many reports brought down during the term of this government have been ignored completely. This is one case where there has been quite speedy action, although the calling of the review could have taken place a number of years earlier. The review recommended a number of refinements to the current selfassessment system that will reduce uncertainty and compliance costs for taxpayers while preserving the tax office's capacity to collect legitimate income tax liabilities. Our current self-assessment system was introduced in 1986-87 by the Hawke-Keating government. Under the self-assessment reop- gime, taxpayers' returns are generally accepted at face value in the first instance. A taxpayer submits their return to the ATO. Once the ATO receives the self-assessmentthe tax return-it issues a notice of assessment. It is that assessment which creates the formal obligation to pay tax. Underpinning this whole process is the notion that the vast majority of taxpayers can be trusted-that they will act in good faith. Given the sheer complexity of tax law at the moment, one must also accept that even taxpayers acting in good faith will from time to time make mistakes in good faith. This amendment bill certainly recognises that. The ATO does not usually check the accuracy of the tax return before sending out the notice of assessment, but it can, and often does, do it later. The ATO may verify the accuracy of the return and, if it so decides, amend its assessment of the tax return at a later time. The ATO now has the power to reopen assessments after many years. This leads to considerable uncertainty for taxpayers and many calls for constraints on the Commissioner of Taxation's capacity to enof force payment and penalties long after the original tax return has been submitted. Concerns of this nature have received some attention recently because of schemes propagated by a number of promoters and massmarketers. Many people were caught by these schemes, even though they appeared to be quite legitimate and the commissioner had given rulings which appeared to legitimise them. This amendment makes substantial improvements to the self-assessment system and substantially swings the balance of power in the relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the taxpayer towards the taxpayer. It moves the balance of fairness markedly in favour of taxpayers who act in good faith, and it does so in two main ways. It reduces the time period in which the ATO can audit and amend an assessment. For a taxpayer with simple tax affairs, it reduces the period from four years to two years and, for those with complex tax affairs, from six years to four years. For eight million individual taxpayers and 750,000-odd very small businesses, this creates certainty and closes the door on their tax returns within a reasonable time frame. One unusual element in respect of the government's approach to this amendment is that the bill does govern for people who behave well. I have said in this House recently that many of the past amendments to legislation that have been introduced by this government, whether they be about super choice, industrial relations or welfare to work, assume that the vast majority of people behave badly and that most people will break the law unless forced not to. This amendment, however, does completely the opposite. It builds on a level of trust that was established by the Keating and Hawke governments. It assumes that people act in good faith, and it does so until they are shown to have acted otherwise. It trusts taxpayers, and it reduces the time given to the ATO to revisit assessments to the minimum time required to do the job. In doing so, it reduces uncertainty for the taxpayer, or at least it does so for payers who are doing the right thing. Where the ATO believes there is fraud or evasion, an unlimited amendment period continues to apply. The unlimited amendment period kicks in with cases of deliberate bad behaviour-that is, people who engage in calculated behaviour to avoid tax. The amendment recognises that taxpayers need to operate in a state of certainty about the law. It recognises that people who seek the advice of the tax office and act on that advice should not be penalised later if the tax office changes its mind. The tax rulings system has been controversial for many years. Taxpayers have rightly complained that the commissioner can change his interpretation or withdraw a ruling after the event. There has also been consternation about relying on oral advice from the ATO and facing penalties later when the ATO changes its mind. This bill outlines a whole new process by which private and public rulings are provided. There are a number of key changes. Firstly it ensures that, if a taxpayer relies upon ATO advice, including oral advice, the taxpayer will be free from penalties. An oral ruling can be requested, which becomes binding and provides protection from imposition of any additional primary tax and a later increase in the quantum of the original tax owing prior to interest or penalties-in other words, if the ATO gives the taxpayer advice and the taxpayer acts on that advice, the taxpayer is protected from changes later on. It expands situations in which the commissioner is bound by advice given to the taxpayer, and it specifies a time limit of 60 days on the provision of a ruling. After this period, the taxpayer can request a ruling within 30 days. If the commissioner fails to respond, this can form a valid objection to the commissioner's assessment. Again, this provides a level of certainty for taxpayers making decisions about the way they contaxduct their affairs on a day-today basis. Originally the government planned that the legislative changes recommended in the review would apply to assessments from the 2004-05 income year. It did not meet that deadline; nevertheless, from December 2004 until now is really quite fast for this government, where we sometimes wait several years for promised action. There are many who quite rightly criticise the government for the dramatic growth in the sheer height of the tax law. We do not deal with it in numbers of pages anymore; we measure it in inches. This amendment does simplify the tax regime for many taxpayers. It does not reduce the number of pages in the tax act, but it does make life simpler for hundreds of thousands of small businesses and millions of everyday taxpayers. Unfortunately it does not go far enough for the taxpayers already caught by past advice from the tax office, which some of my colleagues on this side of the House and some on the government's side have already mentioned. We on this side would have liked to have seen some protection for those taxpayers who acted in good faith and have been caught much later in the ATO net. There is also a remaining unresolved issue about how the ATO will keep records of its oral advice so that taxpayers can be free from penalties when relying upon this advice, but on the whole they are small amendments. This is quite an effective amendment that provides certainty for millions of Australian taxpayers.

Speaker: Mr BROUGH
Title: TAX LAWS AMENDMENT
text: Longman-Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer) (7.35 pm)-I would like to thank all the members who participated in this debate for their tributions. The main objective of Australia's tax system is to efficiently raise the revenue required to facilitate the good running of the country, the maintenance of things such as aged care, pensions, the Defence Force-and on it goes. We try to collect this revenue the minimum administration and compliance costs possible. The Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 2) 2005 goes to the heart of these issues. On 24 November 2003, the Treasurer announced a review of aspects of income tax self-assessment. The review examined aspects of Australia's self-assessment system for income tax to determine whether the right balance had been struck between protecting the rights of the individual and protecting the revenue for the benefit of the whole Australian community. The review concluded that a number of refinements to the present arrangements were needed to improve certainty and reduce compliance costs for taxpayers without significantly affecting the capacity of the tax office to collect legitimate income tax liabilities. This bill continues the process of reform of self-assessment by implementing the remaining legislative recommendations of the report. The first schedule of the bill makes a number of changes to reduce the period during which the Commissioner of Taxation may amend income tax assessment in a range of circumstances. The period in which the commissioner can amend an assessment for most individuals or very small businesses will be standardised at two years. A four-year period of review will apply for taxpayers with more complex affairs. The period for review and amendment of assessments involving arrangements with a dominant tax avoidance purpose will be four years. This will reduce the current period, which is known as part IVA, antiavoidance provision, from six years and also applies to con- other cases with a dominant tax avoidance purpose. Where a taxpayer returns a nil tax liability for an income year, the taxpayer will have a limited period of review, either two or four years depending on the complexity of their affairs, rather than an unlimited period with of review, as is presently the case. Many people have suggested that the review of self-assessment provisions should be retrospective. This suggestion has been made in the light of the mass marketed schemes that were prevalent in the mid-nineties. This argument is often raised as a result of those issues, but if the government were to do that it would throw into doubt every assessment that has been lodged in good faith and would create an enormous amount of uncertainty. The commissioner, I might add, would still have four years to amend the circumstances for those individuals, so it is doubtful that many, if any, of those caught unfortunately in the mass marketed schemes would benefit from the retrospectivity of this particular Making the shorter review period recommendations retrospective would potentially reverse many amended assessments, including those based on general antiavoidance provisions in income tax legislation. It would also restrict the Commissioner of Taxation's ability to raise amended assessments for those years, despite the claim of tax benefits being considered to be unavailable under the law. I am sure no genuine, honest member of parliament would want to see that happen. In such circumstances, the proposals would be unfair to those taxpayers who had correctly self-assessed their tax liability but who subsequently settled their disputes with the ATO. Moreover, retrospective operation would invalidate action taken by the commissioner that was sanctioned at the time, with a dramatic consequence for taxpayers' confidence in the system. This is the reverse of what the review of aspects of tax assessment has set out to achieve. The amendments proposed in this bill should be considered in a broader context. This government has a good record when it comes to improvements in tax administration, and this bill is merely the latest in a long list of changes. As the review points out, over the last few years this government has shortened the period of review for taxpayers with straightforward tax affairs, introducing binding oral advice, reducing the rate of interest on shortfalls and late payments, and introducing the office of the Inspector General of Taxation, a new statutory officer with the responsibility for investigating systemic tax administration issues. While dealing with the issue of binding oral advice, I know a couple of members, including the member for Parramatta, who is in the chamber currently, asked a question seeking clarification as to how that would apply. It is a valid question. This has always bill. been a bone of contention with taxpayers who say that they have rung the ATO and been given some advice but it is not binding and they cannot clarify who it was from. Approximately $11 million has been allocated by the ATO to improve oral ruling systems, including introducing a voice recording system. An oral ruling includes a registration identifier-in other words, a number-so that the ruling can be identified, if required, at a later time. This is under proposed subsection 360-54 of schedule 1 to the Taxation Administration Act. In line with recommendation 2.24 in the report of aspects of income tax selfassessment, which is an administrative recommendation, the ATO has purchased voice recording equipment which, when it is fully rolled out, will provide a more robust recording system for oral advice. The first phase of the implementation of the new oral advice recording system will occur from early 2006. To put everyone's mind at rest, this will allow taxpayers to ring the ATO to get either binding tax advice or a ruling. They need to keep that number in their records so that, if they are ever audited or questioned at some stage further down the track by the ATO, they simply quote that number and it will refer to a particular oral ruling that has been provided. This is a quantum leap forward from where we have been in the past. It provides certainty and confidence to taxpayers that the advice and the rulings that they are receiving can be relied upon. Importantly, schedule 1 to this bill improves certainty by reducing the periods allowed for the Taxation Office to increase a taxpayer's liability in a wide range of situachanges tions. Around eight million individuals and over 745,000 very small businesses will have a shorter period of review. The changes will take effect with the assessment of the 200405 and later years of income. The second schedule to the bill implements a better framework for the provision of tax office advice. The tax office presently gives a wide range of advice to taxpayers and their representatives about how, in the commissioner's opinion, the tax laws apply or would apply. That advice ranges from general information to the public to advice relating to specific taxpayers and arrangements. This schedule expands the current advice and ruling framework in scope and effectiveness to provide protection in a wider range of circumstances. I thank the member for Parramatta for her acknowledgment of that very fact. Under the new framework, all tax office advice provides a level of protection for taxneed payers who have acted in good faith and who have reasonably relied on that advice. In addition, this schedule expands the categories of legally binding advice to cover matters of administration, procedure and collection. Importantly, this schedule improves the arrangements for taxpayers to find out the commissioner's view about how the taxation laws apply so that the risk of uncertainty when they are self-assessing is reduced. The changes will take effect from 1 January 2006 or from royal assent, whichever is the later. The measures contained in this bill are important steps in improving the taxpayers' experience of the self-assessment system. The government is committed to improving certainty for taxpayers by improving the Australian taxation system, and this bill is just another example of that commitment. The member for Hunter raised one other issue I will deal with before closing, and that was in relation to the shortfall interest charge applying retrospectively. This bill does not contain the government's shortfall interest charge changes at all. Those changes were dealt with by the parliament in the Tax Laws Amendment (Improvements to Self Assessment) Bill (No. 1) 2005, which received royal assent on 29 June 2005. Those changes are not part of this bill at all. For the reasons I have outlined above, I commend the bill to the House. I am sure that Australian taxpayers will have a better relationship with the tax office and continue to have strong confidence in the tax office. Most importantly, they can now get things such as oral rulings, know that they are binding and have confidence that the advice they have received can be relied upon. The period that taxpayers have to retain their records, the period in which the ATO can go back and review the predominant number of Australian taxpayers, has been reduced. This legislation gets the balance right between the to raise revenue in a fair and equitable manner in the interests of the nation and protecting the interests of the taxpayer. I commend the bill to the House.
