Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: It is my duty to make a statement to the House concerning two of the Senate amendments with respect to this bill and the matters of constitutional principle they raise. I understand that proposed Senate amendments (1) and (2) will, if enacted, have the effect of moving expenditure between financial years. The view has been taken that legally this would amount to a change in the destination of the appropriation. There is doubt that the Senate may proceed in these circumstances by way of amendment because of section 53 of the Constitution. Among other things, this section prohibits the Senate from amending a bill so as to increase ‘any proposed charge or burden on the people'. I am advised that the view has been taken that, where expenditure is to be transferred in such circumstances, section 56 of the Constitution requires that the proposed appropriation must be recommended by a message from the Governor General. I understand that such a message has been obtained in this case. The House will need to consider the way in which it should proceed to deal with the matters raised in Senate amendments (1) and (2). If it wishes to entertain the proposals reflected in the amendments, it may choose to proceed by alternative means. The matter for consideration is not so much one of the privileges and rights between the two houses as one of observance of the requirements of the Constitution concerning the appropriation of revenue.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.47 pm)-I move: That the House endorse the statement of the Deputy Speaker in relation to the constitutional questions raised by Message No. 216 transmitted by the Senate in relation to the Higher Education Legislation Amendment (2005 Budget Measures) Bill 2005. Question agreed to.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.47 pm)-I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that Senate amendment (3) be agreed to, that amendments (1) and (2) be disagreed to, but that amendments be made in place thereof and that a further relevant amendment be made. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House to first consider amendment (3) and when that amendment has been disposed of to consider amendments (1) and (2) and then the further amendment. I move: That Senate amendment (3) be agreed to. Senate amendment (3) decreases the 2008 other grants funding under the Higher Education Support Act 2003 to reflect the bringing forward of 2008 funding for the University of Western Sydney to the 2006 and 2007 funding years. Because there are no constitutional issues surrounding an amendment which decreases an appropriation, this amendment made by the Senate can be agreed to by the House.

Speaker: Ms OWENS
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: I would like to speak very briefly in support of the amendment and thank the Senate for their work in putting this proposal forward. The University of Western Sydney is very much an icon over a very large area, and it is extremely important to the people of the area. is a very young university, with particular needs because of its youth-the need to grow its campuses, the need to grow its courses and the need to grow its student population. Also, it has a particular problem because of the sheer area it covers. With campuses spread over an enormous area, it can take 45 minutes to one hour to travel from one end to the other. The university has asked that the funding be brought forward, with $3 million in 2006. The Senate has moved an amendment in accordance with that, and I thank them very much for doing that and support the amendment.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: I add my support to the support that has been voiced by the member for Parramatta. The University of Western Sydney has asked that funding be brought forward, and we are strongly supportive of the additional funding going to the university. It is much needed, as the member for Parramatta has outlined, and I formally indicate the opposition's support.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: The question is that Senate amendment (3) be agreed to. Question agreed to.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION

Without repeating my earlier comments in support of the Deputy Speaker's statement regarding the constitutional questions raised by Senate amendments (1) and (2), I need to point out to the House that these amendments would have increased the University of Western Sydney's other grants funding for 2006 and 2007 to reflect the bringing forward of funds from 2008. The amendments I It will shortly be moving will pick up on the intent of Senate amendments (1) and (2). I point out that it is at the particular request of the University of Western Sydney and that it will enable the university to move more quickly in its new building program, which was supported by the Australian government in this year's budget and, as we have just heard, by the opposition.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: The question is that Senate amendments (1) and (2) be disagreed to. Question agreed to. Message from the Governor General recommending appropriation for the bill and proposed amendments announced.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.51 pm)-I move amendments (2) and (3) in place of the Senate's amendments which have been disagreed to: (2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (cell at table item 2, 3rd column), omit the cell, substitute: $1,716,942,000 (3) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (cell at table item 3, 3rd column), omit the cell, substitute: $1,673,153,000 These amendments have two purposes. Firstly, amendment (2) will facilitate the transfer of unspent collaboration and structural reform-or CASR-funds from 2005 to 2006 by increasing the appropriation for other grants for 2006. Secondly, amendments (2) and (3) will also accommodate the intent of Senate amendments (1) and (2), disagreed to by the House for constitutional reasons, increasing other grants funding for the University of Western Sydney for 2006 and 2007 to reflect the bringing forward or rephasing of 2008 funding for US. These amendments affirm the government's commitment to more efficiently facilitating US campus developments and to promoting university collaboration and restructuring. I commend the amendments to the House and present the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Jagajaga) (7.53 pm)While we will not oppose these amendments, because we do not want the money to be lost to the universities, it is very disappointing that the government has not been able to spend this money, given the huge demand in our universities for the funding from the Colreform laboration and Structural Reform Fund. As I understand it, the whole purpose of the fund is to achieve better higher education outcomes in teaching, learning, research and innovation by promoting structural reform in the sector. I think these might even be the government's own words. So it is very disappointing to see that we have such a serious level of underspending. As I understand it, we have had a mere 10 projects funded this year, with a total amount of $3.8 million allocated from a $41 million program which was supposed to fund over $13 million this year. I am sure many of the universities are very disappointed that so much money that could have been allocated and that could be put to good use at so many places around the country is not being spent. We are very disappointed. I think it is certainly not good for the universities to see the government fall behind in this way. Nevertheless, it is very important that the money stay in the fund.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.54 pm)-I can assist the opposition in this regard. The Collaboration and Structural Reby form Fund is, as the member for Jagajaga points out, intended precisely for thatcollaboration and structural reform. It is one of many facets of the $11 billion reform program in higher education. I made a conscious decision to rephase the money and not to specifically fund all of the projects that came forward this year. The reason for that is that the 10 that I agreed to fund as the minister responsible were those that I really thought would deliver collaboration and structural reform-that five or 10 years from now we would look back and think, ‘Yes, reform was achieved through the expenditure in that way.' There were a myriad of other projects which came forward which had value, but I could not see that there would be significant in the sector as a consequence of that. I have informed the Australian ViceChancellors Committee and other people in the sector of the reasons for the decision, and I think it is fair to say that they are quite comfortable with the outcome.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: I thank the minister for that. I would be interested to know how many applications were received and would appreciate it if the minister could let us know, maybe after this debate, which applications were not agreed to, given that I think both sides of the parliament agree on the importance of collaboration. I do think that this is a way for the university sector to go. I would be interested to understand from the minister how many and which applications were rejected. Question agreed to.

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.56 pm)-I move the further relevant amendment (1): (1) Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 10), after item 1, insert: 1A Subsection 41-45(1) (cell at table item 1, column headed “Amount”) Repeal the cell, substitute: $1,539,636,000 This amendment will facilitate the transfer of the unspent collaboration and structural reform funds from 2005 to 2006 by decreasing the 2005 appropriation for other grants under the Higher Education Support Act. Amendment (2) provided for the related increase in CASR funding for 2006. This will facilitate earlier and more considered allocation of CASR funding for applicants in 2006.

Speaker: Ms MACKLIN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Jagajaga) (7.57 pm)Minister, will you provide us with the number of applications and those that were not successful?

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION LEGISLATION
text: Bradfield-Minister for Education, Science and Training) (7.57 pm)-I will take the question on notice. I will certainly provide the opposition with information in terms of how many institutions applied and the variety of purposes for which applications for grants were made, but I will take advice on the consequences of publishing all of the applications that came forward. There were a number of applications which my department recommended not be funded, there were others they recommended could be funded but advised were not of particularly high quality and there were others that were recommended as being able to be funded. As I said earlier, the reality is that those which I did not provide funding for were very worthy projects; I am not suggesting for one minute that they were not worthy. But, in terms of driving mediumto long term reform in the sector, they certainly did not meet that benchmark and in many cases were things that I think the universities ought to be doing in any case. I will take advice on it. So long as it is not prejudicial to the institutions or the individuals who applied for them, I would be happy to make that information available to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Question agreed to. NA Rearrangement
