Speaker: Mr KEENAN
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: It is a great pleasure for me to rise in support of the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. It is long standing coalition policy, and I will be very pleased when it finally passes though parliament. Since the resumption of this debate, I have been reminded by colleagues that similar legislation aimed at ensuring that freedom of association principles apply to all Australian students has, in fact, been introduced in every parliamentary term since the first coalition victory in 1996. It is about time this legislation was passed by the parliament so that Australian students, including those living in the electorate of Stirling, are able to choose how to spend their money and the organisations they want to be members of. This bill will amend the Higher Education Support Act 2003 to prohibit all higher education providers, both public and private, from requiring a person to become a member of a student association, such as a union or guild. It will also prohibit all higher education providers from requiring that students pay fees for non-academic student services. As a Western Australian and former university student, the debate about voluntary student unionism is one that I have followed closely. As a student, I was forced to pay guild fees, regardless of whether or not I utilised the services on offer. It is a situation that all Australian students currently face. As somebody who believes that in our democracy nobody should be forced to join an organisation, I am passionately opposed to compulsory student unionism. I will always defend the right to free association and freedom of choice, just as I will the right to freedom of speech. I have been amazed by some of the comments that have been made in this place prior to this debate being resumed tonight. The Labor Party have spent a lot of time lately talking about freedom of association, yet they plainly want to deny Australian students this basic right. The arguments that have been put by some on the other side of the House have, in some cases, been plainly ridiculous. Members opposite have stood in this chamber time after time and tried to make out that this is some sort of ideological debate designed to crush student guilds and the student union movement. But nothing could be further from the truth. This bill is about choice and giving university students the freedom to exercise that basic democratic right. In the arguments put, those on the other side of the House have claimed some extraordinary things. They have tried to claim that this bill will do everything from jeopardising Australia's proud sporting identity to suppressing freedom of speech, even to undermining the values of Australian mateship. Listening to those on the other side, I am reminded of one of the sad realities of modern day politics, which is that those on the Left no longer value freedom and are always ready to use coercion to get what they want. It is part of an intellectual snobbery that people on the left of politics always believe they know what is best for other people. They think that, if we allow people to exercise their own free will, it will result in terrible things, which the smarter people in the Australian Labor Party know are not good for them. Listening to previous opposition speakers, you would think that this bill abolished student unions-you would think that the government were pursuing a vendetta against their ideological opponents to wipe these organisations from the face of university campuses. That is simply not the case. All we are doing is providing students with the freedom to choose whether or not they wish to join these organisations. The higher education support amendment is about the right of students to choose whether or not they will pay for a service or product that they do or do not require. It is about the right of people to complete their education and receive their results without being forced to join a particular organisation or pay for a service that they do not want or need. It is about the right of students to spend their money on textbooks or sporting activities that they enjoy, not on those that they do not, and the right of students to support a political party that they believe in instead of the one that the student association likes most. The National Union of Students, an organisation that receives $5 per full-time stuhas dent from every affiliated organisation, spent almost a quarter of a million dollars at the last election campaign playing politics. Considering where this money ended up, it is no wonder that the Australian Labor Party want to defend the privileged status of these organisations on Australian campuses. I have no doubt that much of the membership of the organisations from which the money had been compulsorily acquired would have preferred to have seen the money spent on services. I cannot think of any other area of life where people are forced to join a specific organisation, and I cannot think of any rational argument about why Australian students should be exempted from these fundamental rights. In all the political posturing and scaremongering that we have seen about this bill, I am yet to find one person who answered either of these questions satisfactoVictoria'. rily. Instead, the ALP have argued in this place that we must have compulsory student unionism because if we do not student unions will collapse. It is a telling argument that speaks volumes about the Labor Party's belief that noone would want to be part of a student guild or union unless they are forced to be. Can there be any clearer indication that even the opposition know that students do not value the frolics of their current unions in their present state? And why should they? Woeful unions around the country waste the forcefully acquired money they get on such things as stickers that urge students to bomb the White House, which was done in appalling taste after the attacks of September 11. As I detailed earlier, they have also used other people's money to campaign for a Labor victory during last year's election. As we are resuming this debate-and it been some time since this matter was last debated in this place-I would like to remind those present about some of the other contributions that have been made, because I think that they bear repeating. The member for Boothby pointed out in his speech that last year, during the six-week period of the federal election campaign, the National Union of Students spent over $75,000 on broadcasting electoral advertisements, over $40,000 publishing such electoral advertisements, nearly $50,000 on producing campaign material like how-to-vote cards, posters and pamphlets, and almost $90,000 on direct mailing. That is over a quarter of a million dollars of students' money being used to campaign during the last federal election. To emphasise the point about which party this advertising favoured, the mailing address on the NUS return mail to the Australian Elechas toral Commission is ‘care of Trades Hall, This would be quite a different proposition if the funding to student unions had been given voluntarily by people who shared the political views of the NUS. But that is not the case. We need to be reminded that this money was compulsorily acquired. Given that, I am not surprised that the ALP wants to defend its mates. I would venture to say that much of the money spent funding this electioneering previously belonged to students who would rather have seen that money spent on services on campus. Claims from the other side of this House that allowing students to choose what services they use at the university or whether to join a student union or association will destroy sport in this great nation are equally ludicrous. Ensuring that someone who does not play sport does not have to pay for the upkeep of university soccer ovals and squash courts will not reduce participation when the student was never involved to start with. It may come as a surprise to some members of this House that voluntary student unionism does not spell the end of student unionism and student guilds. We only need to look at the experience of Western Australian universities when the Court government introduced voluntary student unionism in 1995 to see that democracy and student representative bodies can actually coexist. Between 1995 and 2002, student unionism was voluntary at Western Australian universities. The practice of voluntary student unionism in WA did not decimate sport in Western Australian universities. It did not silence student guilds and indeed it did not remove or damage the concept of Australian mateship. What it did do-and I think this is very important-was force the various student organisations and bodies to focus on providing services that were of value to students. Funnily enough, I always assumed that this was what a representative organisation was supposed to do-provide services that were valued by its members. In 1998 a study was commissioned to report on voluntary student unionism in Western Australia. The review studied the impact of voluntary student unionism on Western Australian universities. A quick flick through the pages of the report shows that, rather than services reducing during this period, they actually improved. The report concludes: ... most student services have been maintained since the implementation of VSU in Western Australia. It goes on to say: ... Despite the introduction of VSU, student guilds have, in most cases, added services in response to the needs of their members. This has been achieved with lower guild fees and without university loans or subsidies. In short, when VSU was implemented, student guilds and associations in Western Australia became better and more responsive organisations. They provided services that responded to their members' needs. And all this happened despite a smaller membership base and less income. Far from demonstrating the need for compulsory student unionism, the Western Australian experience demonstrates the very reason that we need to have voluntary student unionism Australia wide. We need to do it not only to ensure that students enjoy the same freedom of association as all others in our community but to ensure that student organisations are accountable and responsive to their members. It is unfortunate that this promising start to voluntary student unionism in Western Australia was summarily dismantled when the current Gallop Labor administration was elected. Labor has turned the clock back in WA and made students pay compulsory upfront fees unrelated to academic study for purely ideological reasons. It was a costly and retrograde decision for university students. The decision to reinstate compulsory upfront fees was made despite overwhelming evidence that the voluntary system was working. As a result, students in my electorate of Stirling-and those in your electorate of Swan, Mr Deputy Speaker Wilkie-are now forced to spend their hard-earned cash on amenities fees that fund services that they do not use, that they have no intention of using and that they will not use in the future-essentially to fund services that they simply do not want. Some of the services that they do not want have already been mentioned by the member for Indi. I want to repeat some of them here, simply because of their outrageousness. In the year ending December 2004, Monash University collected over $8½ million of compulsorily acquired fees. These fees supposedly went to essential services, but, extraordinarily, 56 per cent of the money was spent on administration. At the University of Melbourne, things were even worse. An extraordinary 72 per cent of compulsorily acquired money went into administrative costs. I am more than happy for any Australian to pursue issues that they believe are of concern to them. But when you see that this compulsorily acquired money has been used for political campaigning that does not necessarily reflect the views of all students, you realise that this is not part of our democracy. I am perfectly happy for people, including students, to campaign, but for goodness sake do it with your own money and not somebody else's. As I have stated before, this bill is not about ideology or petty politics, as the Labor Party would have us believe. It is not about preventing students from expressing their views. It is not about stopping student protests. It is not about destroying student activism. This debate is about a fundamental and most basic right that every member of our democratic society should expect to have and to enjoy. Education is one of the important protectors of democracy, but the fact that almost every Australian student at university is currently being forced to pay between $100 and $600 in up-front student union fees in order to get their education defies reason. It is not a proud symbol of our democratic country. This debate is about the fact that everyone in our community has the right to make their own choices, based on their own personal circumstances and their own individual needs. This bill will do some very important things. Firstly, it will ensure that students are no longer forced to belong to any form of student association. Secondly, it will ensure students are not forced to pay for services they do not value or utilise. Finally, it will ensure that universities cannot penalise, either through expulsion or by withholding results, any student who chooses not to pay up-front student union or service fees. This gives students the same rights that everyone else in our community enjoys. This bill will allow students to actually get some accountability from their union. They will be able to pay for the services that they value and to pass judgment on the services that they do not value. Do Australian students really need to be treated as second-class citizens and denied fundamental freedoms? I have listened closely to the debate on this bill and it has exposed some of the more unpalatable beliefs held by some members of this House. The belief that any Australian citizen should be forced to join a particular organisation should be abhorrent to anybody who values freedom. Yet speaker after speaker has risen to defend this untenable position and accused the government of trying to abolish student unions as part of some wider ideological crusade. Well, I have some news for those members: voluntary organisations can exist, based on people's desire to join and fund them. Tens of thousands of these organisations exist across Australia, including chambers of commerce, art clubs, Rotary clubs and Lions clubs. Even political parties manage to exist on the basis of people's voluntary preference to join them. All of these organisations manage to exist and to contribute to our community, without forcing people to join them against their will. In fact, under this bill, students can pay for services that they value and, as I said, pass judgment on the services that they do not value. I would like to challenge any member speaking after me to come into this House and provide us with an example of any other organisation within Australia where people are actually forced to join. We have heard a lot of talk about how we oppose free speech because we do not believe that students should be forced to subsidise particular organisations. I hate to break it to you, but that is not free speech. So do not come into talk against this bill and cite freedom as your fundamental reason for not supporting it. That is just an insult, because what this bill is about is freedom and a fundamental freedom of association. One of the other larger problems to do with the up-front fees that are forcefully acquired from students around Australia is that they take absolutely no account of a student's ability to pay. The fees force students to pay, regardless of how difficult that might be at any given time. I am surprised that the Labor Party believe that students are not to be trusted with basic rights of freedom of choice, and I am really astonished by the energetic opposition that has been shown to this bill. Nobody who genuinely believes in freedom and fairness could realistically oppose these measures to allow students to associate or not to associate with the student union on their campus. I congratulate the Minister for Education, Science and Training for bringing this legislation before the parliament and I, along with tens of thousands of Australian students, will welcome its passage. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR (Corio) (8.20 pm)-It is my pleasure to make a contribution to this debate, and I rise to oppose the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005 and to support the compromise amendment moved by my colleague the member for Jagajaga, which protects university student services while giving students the choice of whether they want to belong to a student union. It is very clear that the Labor Party has advanced in a public policy sense while the Liberal Party is still stuck in the ideological straitjacket of the 1970s. The bill proposed by the government joins a long list of bills brought to this place that essentially reflect the bald ideological prejudices of Tory members of this House. It joins the workplace relations bill as one of the most misconceived, devious and illogical bills produced by this government. The enduring legacy of this bill will be the removal of many support services to students-services that have become part of the fabric of general and at times quite specific support delivered to students as they move through their university years. Let us be very clear about the underlying motivation for this bill.

Speaker: The DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I hate to interrupt the honourable member for Corio, but I would like to point out that the amendments to be moved by the honourable member for Jagajaga have not yet been moved. They will be moved during the consideration in detail stage of the debate on the bill. Mr GAVAN O'CONNOR-Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am indebted to you for your clarification of that particular matter. I am certain that the member for Jagajaga will not mind me making the intervention that I have made and, if it is one that is a little premature, I guess that in the fullness of the consideration in detail stage all will be revealed. This bill is not about good public policy, nor is it about the promotion of a core political value of modern liberalism. It is really about the pent-up frustrations of some former Liberal uni student activists who have huge spots on their liver about the past and who are dreadfully frustrated that their political ambitions within the government are being thwarted by a bevy of bozos who now occupy portfolios on the Howard front-bench. That is the real reason why the member for Indi and the member for Casey got up in here-as I recall it, the last time this matter was debated in this parliament-and unloaded some extraordinary vitriol on student unions, people in the Labor Party and life in general. The cat was let out of the bag by the honourable member for Indi in her speech. She had this to say: So today I rejoice and join with other former eral students around the country and around the world who have fought the battle and waited for decades for this day. It must be a proud moment for the honourable member for Indi to support a bill that drives the boot into ordinary students and the services that they receive, already heavily penalised by the policies of the Howard government. They have been penalised with massive HECS debts, which I understand now total $11 billion; and of course they are saddled now with trying to compete for access to courses with students of lesser intellectual capacity whose parents happen to be able to afford the $100,000 to $200,000 to buy their way into a university course. Reading the member for Indi's speech, I see she has laid bare for all students in Australia the real political motivation behind this legislation: an ugly payback for some unseemly political brawls over the University of Melbourne's student union many years ago. This legislation is not motivated by what is best for Australian students today; it is about some ugly happenings in the past. The government's attempt to shroud its true intent in this bill behind the rhetoric of choice is a favourite tactic of the Howard government when it deals with these matters. It is no use talking to me about choice provided by any Liberal government, because I had an experience as a young university student myself of the way the Liberal Party delivers choice to students. In my day, the Liberal government was happy to compulsorily draft 18-year-old Australian males to kill in Vietnam. They had no choice in the matterthe choice was the battlefield or jail. That was the reality of Liberal choice when I was at university. So, when any Liberal member gets up in this place and talks about choice for young people, they ought to read their own history. They ought to have an appreciaLibtion of their own history, because then they would not come in here with their pathetic meanderings about providing Australian students with choice. We are talking here about a student union fee, or a fee to provide services for other students. But there has been a case in the past where a Liberal government of the day provided no choice to Australian young people about whether they would be drafted into the Australian armed forces and sent to a foreign land to kill. So let us have no nonsense in this debate about Liberal choice. I think it is important to dissect the philosophical basis for this legislation. It is encapsulated in the speeches that we have heard, particularly from the Minister for Education, Science and Training. This is an extraordinarily interventionist policy. It seeks once again to micromanage the affairs of the universities of Australia. I would have thought that, if the basic philosophical reason for this bill were choice, the minister would give universities the choice to run their own affairs. We do not see that with this minister. What we see is an extraordinarily interventionist policy, one which is manifest not only in this particular legislation but in other pieces of legislation dealing with the sector. The other philosophical basis for this legislation is the fact that it is extraordinarily punitive. If the minister cannot get his way with managing the internal affairs of a university, he is going to penalise them financially for that. That is great public policy, isn't it-you cannot win the argument in the university institutions, you cannot win the argument in the community, you cannot win the argument amongst the student body, so you bring in a punitive regime to penalise those who do not particularly agree with your view. This is an extraordinary bill in that regard. The current policy of the universities allows students to opt out of any student union. Yet the minister now has a rather fanciful notion that he is going to run a taxpayer funded student vote on voluntary student unionism. He is going to pour money into some sort of a referendum amongst students about student unions and about how universities should be running their affairs. I have a simple piece of advice for the minister: let the universities run their own affairs. Let the democratic processes within the universities work their way through and resolve these matters internally. It is very clear that a whole range of essential services are provided by student unions or student associations, and I am indebted to the member for Jagajaga for a note to this effect. They provide food and beverage services, meeting rooms, sport and physical recreation, child care, counselling, legal advice, health care, housing, employment, visual arts, performing arts and audiovisual media, debating, libraries and reading rooms, academic support, personal accident insurance for students, orientation information, support for overseas students, student representation and advocacy, student clubs and societies, social activities, cultural activibusiness, ties, welfare, commercial activities, capital funds and infrastructure, investments and reserves, student publications, student financial assistance and administrative matters related to any of these. So it is an extraordinary range of services that this government wants to curtail. That will be the inevitable result of this legislation. Services that have been provided in the past to students in universities, fully administered and accountable under the charters of the universities and the operational and administrative arrangements of the associations, will be sorely affected by this legislation. I have had many discussions with the Deakin University Student Association on this matter. They have laid out very clearly their opposition, on behalf of students in the Geelong region, to this legislation and its implications. As they point out, DUSA currently operate under the Victorian system of voluntary student unionism. The student association have listed the attributes under which they operate, and I am indebted to the student association for this material. There is a compulsory fee collected by the university. The university determines the distribution of the fee. The money is divided between the library, off-campus student support, the university's own student support services and DUSA. They have optional membership, so a student can at any time choose not to be a member of this particular organisation. But in fact very few students opt out, and I think that ought to tell the member something. It certainly tells me something-that is, that there is widespread support within the university and student body for the model that currently operates. Membership of the student association is free, and DUSA negotiates a general service fee agreement annually that determines the manner in which DUSA will conduct its along with its accountabilities. As far as democratic elections to the student union are concerned, all student representatives are elected by the general student population. So here we have a system where the university collects a fee and it is optional for students to join-but most of them do. They get their membership for free, and the administrative and operational matters ensure proper accountability. This is what the member for Indi and the member for Casey want to destroy through this legislation. I read with interest the contributions of the member for Indi and the member for Casey to this debate. It is really sad to see aspiring Liberal politicians using as a justification for this legislation their own bitter, sordid and twisted experience of student politics in their younger days at Melbourne university. I read with interest their contributions to this debate, and they both gave prominence to certain Labor Party members that they did battle with in their former university years. I note that Andrew Landeryou and Richard Marles feature rather prominently in their speeches as good Labor mates with whom the member for Indi and the member for Casey fought bitterly in their student union days at Melbourne university. Who cares? Why bring it into this particular debate to justify their point of view? Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, you mayand I know I certainly do-feature from time to time on Mr Landeryou's blog site, euphemistically called ‘The Other Cheek'. It must be the right cheek, rather than the left cheek, because he is forever hopping into the left wing of the Labor Party on a whole range of matters. I am surprised that the member for Indi would even drag this into the debate, because the interesting thing about Mr Landeryou is that he can hardly ever get his facts right on the blog site. For example, the other day he made the fanciful statement that I know little about agriculture. I did grow up on a dairy farm until my 17th year, and I was involved in every productive activity on it. On the death of my father in 1979, I returned to the farm and engaged in a range of productive farming activities. I have held the agriculture portfolio for over six years, carrying Labor's values and its standard into hostile political territory for the party, and I currently serve on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. I am a person in the Labor Party caucus who knows the farm sector intimately. Yet, in the framework and context of this debate, the honourable member for Indi used Mr Landeryou to justify an attack on the students of Australia. That is an extraordinary proposition. This parliament needs no contemporary history lesson on the Victorian Labor Party by the members for Indi and Casey. It is already public knowledge that Mr Landeryou is under police investigation for certain commercial matters. It is no secret around Labor circles that Mr Marles is a good friend of Mr Landeryou. So bringing these matters into this debate as a justification for this legislation is as spurious as much of the material that appears on Mr Landeryou's blog site. It is a sad commentary on the Liberal Party today that its younger members can stand up in this House and deliver the coup de grace to student associations around Australia in the guise of this bill and somehow justify it because of the prejudices that were honed in some sordid political battles they engaged in at the Melbourne University Student Union many years ago. The students of Australia deserve better. They deserve better than hoary old prejudicial argument underlying a bill of such moment. One thing we do know is that students rely on these services to get through their courses, to help them through their courses. At Deakin University in my electorate they have resoundingly made their statement, with the voluntary student union model, that they want to be a part of that arrangement. Of course here we have Liberal members in support of this bill peddling the worse prejudices imaginable.

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: HIGHER EDUCATION SUPPORT
text: I am pleased to speak in the parliament today on this very important bill, the Higher Education Support Amendment (Abolition of Compulsory Up-front Student Union Fees) Bill 2005. This is a significant bill for the universities of this country and for the students who attend those universities. Indeed it is a far-reaching bill that will serve very the overall community and the reputations of these universities throughout our country. I want to at the outset congratulate the Minister for Education, Science and Training and all his staff, who have worked very hard to ensure that this bill came before the House for us to debate. Before I speak about some of the contents of the bill and some of the thoughts I have on this bill, I want to take a moment in the parliament to compliment and commend very strongly and very warmly my old university at St Lucia, the University of Queensland. Last week the University of Queensland was awarded more than $10 million of the total $30 million given to five universities nationally in the top band of higher education providers by the federal government's Learning and Teaching Performance Fund. This is a very significant recognition of a great sandstone university. Being in the suburb of St Lucia in the Ryan electorate, I am very proud to represent it, in particular as a graduate of that university in arts and law. In the Australian Awards for University Teaching the University of Queensland won four of 12 awards, in the categories of physical sciences, teaching large first-year classes, enhancement of the quality of teaching and learning, and approaches to improving and enhancing assessment. So again for the record and for the benefit of the people of Ryan and those who have a very deep interest in tertiary sector education, in the parliamight ment today I am delighted to extend warm congratulations to the academics of the university, to students and to the ViceChancellor, John Hay, who at the moment is leading the university with great distinction. This is an important bill, as I mentioned, and one that I have for quite some time been looking forward to speaking on. I regret that I only have a short time in the parliament to well speak on it. This bill amends the Higher Education Support Act 2003 to abolish compulsory student unionism in tertiary institutions which receive federal government funding. Let us not forget that when we talk about federal government funding we are talking about the taxes of the people of Australia, the taxes paid by everyday Australians from my electorate who go to work and sacrifice time at home and with their family. It is very important for all of us to remember that we are not talking about endless buckets of money; we are talking about money which comes from the hard working people of our country. This bill provides a mechanism to reduce Commonwealth funding to institutions which enforce unionism on their students. Unlike other citizens of our country, students are in the situation where they are forced, compelled, to join a student union or guild and to pay fees to that entity, which I think is quite an affront. I am delighted that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing is in the chamber, my good friend the member for Sturt, who I know feels very strongly about this issue, has campaigned long and hard in his time in this parliament and was very active in his time at university in South Australia. Notwithstanding that he comes from South Australia-of course I come from Queensland, the greatest state in the Commonwealth-I know that he in particular has campaigned long and hard. In fact I take the opportunity in the parliament to pay tribute to and acknowledge all my colleagues in the coalition, who have fought very long and hard for this bill to come to fruition because it is very important. This bill will finally make student unionism a voluntary activity in higher education institutions. Finally, students will be afforded a right that we all take for granted and will no longer be coerced into an association. How ridiculous, how preposterous, that in our country in the first decade of the 21st century we have a situation where students are compelled by institutions of higher learning to join an association. It is a ridiculous state of affairs for the education sector to be in. I am very strongly in favour of this bill. support the right of students to have freedom of choice and freedom of association. I have received many representations from students, particularly from those at the University of Queensland-because, of course, I represent that university. I have had many representations also from other members of my community of Ryan. I have been delighted to meet with all those people and I have been very receptive to their representations. As the local member, it is my job to meet with my constituents and to hear their points of view and constructive comments about the government's performance and how we can improve policy and think of new ideas to make our country more progressive and more prosperous. The strong feeling that came through was that the overwhelming majority of people in my community support this piece of legislation. There are students from the university whose views differ. But I think the strong element of protectionism in the way that student unions are run and funded currently has come to an end. Once funding is distributed, there is very little impetus on the bodies that receive that funding to account for the spending of those funds. I believe that student unions and organisations which are supported on a voluntary basis will be more responsive to student needs and more accountable. It is very important that we have transparency in universities and our institutions of education and higher learning. In that regard, there is no difference between universities and student unions. Student unions will have to be in order to attract support from the student body and they will be compelled to deliver their services more efficiently and more productively. I want to draw the attention of the House, the students of the University of Queensland, all the young people of Ryan and, indeed, the broader community to an article in the HerI ald Sun on Wednesday, 23 November 2005. Quite frankly, if there is a skerrick of truth to it, this is a very disturbing article. It points to sheer abuse by student unions. I am sure that many of my colleagues will be interested to know of this article; I am sure that many of them have had their attention drawn to it already. It concerns the Monash University Student Union agreeing to pay some $1,000 to an association that has, as a key motive, the intention of attacking the good Australians who are serving in our armed forces in Iraq; it considers them a group hostile to its motives. This is very troubling indeed. I have somehow managed to be given the minutes of a meeting in May of the Monash Student Association, which show that the union gave $1,000 to Foraok Isma'al as part of an Australian speaking tour for the union activist. One student abstained from the Monash union vote, but the rest supported the motion of giving political support and $1,000 to the speaking tour. This came from the campus of Monash University and I think it is troubling indeed. MSA council chairman, Mr Nick Richardson, admitted that the resistance could include ‘violence aimed at coalition forces'. This is absolutely shocking. This is unacceptable to any Australian who supports our forces in theatres of conflict. Nick Richardson took the time to defend his decision to provide financial support to the Southern Oil Workers Union in Iraq, which he described as a ‘progressive organisation'. That is rather incredible, but it is precisely the sort of evidence that has come to our attention with such organisations. The Monash Student Association should be hauled before significant authorities and questioned about why it is donating money coming from students who attend Monash University to individuals or groups of individuals that, as a very central part of their activity, advocate action that could put at risk the lives of Australian soldiers and other civilians. I think it is abhorrent in the extreme to have a student organisation at an Australian university collecting money for and donating money to the Southern Oil Workers Union in Iraq. The minutes of that meeting reveal many other things but, as I have mentioned, it is very disturbing that, but for one student, the overwhelming majority of the students at the Monash Student Association meeting in May agreed to give $1,000 of students' hardearned cash to this cause, which is inimical to the national interests of this country. I want to place on the record and draw to the attention of the people of Ryan this example of what students in union organisations at campuses around this country do. It illustrates what they get up to. I think it is high time that an end is put to this sort of activity. Its days are over. It is unacceptable certainly to me and, I know, to the people of my community in Ryan-and I am certain that it is unacceptable to the overwhelming majority of Australians. It is important that we pass this legislation, as it will play its part in preventing this sort of nonsense from happening. Importantly, with this piece of legislation there is choice for students. They are perfectly free to join unions but, equally, they are perfectly free to resist the compulsion to join; they do not have to join. I draw the attention of the House to an interesting article in Brisbane's Courier-Mail of 13 October 2005 by Ms Lucy Percival, who lives in Indooroopilly. I do not know Lucy, but she has written to the Courier-Mail and, being on the record, I draw her words to the attention of the House and particularly to the attention of the students and young people of the Ryan electorate. It is a very instructive article and really captures the essence of the bill and what it tries to address. In the article, Lucy Percival of Indooroopilly writes: I am in my third year of university so this means, at the University of Queensland, I have paid $816 in union fees. I want to know where it goes … … … A plain roll at the bakery costs at least twice as much as at other bakeries. All their food is at least as expensive as that in comparable bakeries and cafes. The coffee and drinks are just as expensive. No, union fees aren't used to provide cheap food for poor students. Maybe they're hiding it in other services? No, not there. Some of the sports are 20 per cent more expensive to play than in non-university teams so the money isn't hiding there. Photocopying is only 1c cheaper than at Officeworks. (The subsidy is only $10 per 1000 pages so it doesn't account for much of our fees.) Could it be in the “free” entertainment the union provides? Hold on, I already paid for that entertainment in my union fees so it's not free, and I don't like the bands that it chooses. Lucy Percival goes on: For my three years at university thus far, it appears to me that a lot of money goes to vested interests in the union. All those anti-voluntary student unionism T-shirts must have cost a fortune. Can I have some money for pro-VSU Tshirts? A huge amount goes to clubs and societies that spend it on bar tabs. When I see the union spending money on students' real needs, I will gladly hand over my fees. Lucy Percival is an Australian who lives in the suburb of Indooroopilly in the Ryan electorate. I think that is a very salient piece which puts to shame many of the members of the Labor opposition here in terms of capturing the spirit and the importance of what this bill is all about and what it tries to do. Indeed, a significant reason for this bill ing to this parliament and for the government parties to pass it is that there is an enormous amount of waste by the student unions that manage the student union fees. In my meetings with the National President of the NUS, Felix Eldridge, and the Queensland Branch President, Jon Hames, they certainly put their views to me very strongly, and I commend them for having their views and their ideology. But I also made it equally clear to them, while giving them the courtesy of hearing what they had to say on this matter, that I strongly disagreed with them. But it was important for me as a federal member of this parliament to listen to them on this important issue. The NUS of course made it clear that it does not support this bill. It is quite ironic that the NUS speaks out against changes to HECS fees, fees that are not up front and do not have to be repaid until a student is earning in excess of $36,000-fees that will ensure the sustainability of high-quality education for all tertiary students. Yet, when students are at their most vulnerable financially, at the time when they are studying and their capacity to earn is tempered by their need to focus on their academic work, this is the time when the NUS demands that students cough up, pay more money, for services that the overwhelming majority of students do not even use. Of course, the NUS fears that if it cannot hold students to ransom and force them to be student union members then it will not have any members and it will not have any funds to support its activitiesactivities which are, significantly, of a very political nature and which do not serve the interests of students. This is why these students no longer have a mandate-why they no longer have the support of the majority of students on their campuses, of the Australian public and, of comcourse, of the national government of this country. They are not using these funds for the purpose of taking care of the majority of students. They may certainly take care of some students. No doubt they take care of those students at universities who use the sporting ovals. No doubt they take care of the rugby clubs and the swimming clubs. I am sure they do that, but there is no interest by the majority of students in subsidising a minority of students who play rugby, who use the track and field oval or who use the swimming pool. I am a very strong and passionate believer in the game of rugby. Indeed, it is a game that I think is played in heaven. But I certainly would not have wanted the majority of students at a campus to subsidise my right and pleasure in playing the game of rugby when I was at university. I want to make very clear in the parliament today that it is important for us to acknowledge that student union fees are all about subsidising a small group of students who enjoy their own activities, at the cost of the overwhelming majority of students. That is the nub of it. That is why this government must legislate and why I encourage all my colleagues in the House of Representatives and my coalition colleagues in the Senate to pass this legislation. When we have activities in the streets where students of universities are protesting about the government or protesting about the Minister for Education, Science and Training, why is there always violence? Why is it that, unlike the majority of Australians when they have an issue, these students cannot put forward their views in a peaceful manner, in a democratic fashion? Why does there have to be violence when the minister for education turns up at a campus? Why does there have to be protest? It has always struck me as somewhat remarkable for young people who are supposed to be well educated, who are supposed to be receiving an education, who are supposed to be future leaders of our country-young people who will hold positions of importance in this nation-to be involved in this activity, these clashes with police and law enforcement officers. It is a disgrace, and I very strongly condemn any student who in the past has been involved in this sort of violent activity. It does them no good whatsoever. It does their organisation no good whatsoever. It just diminishes what they are all about. I pay tribute to the minister for education for the spirit, the manner and the fashion in which he has conducted himself in dealing with these violent protests of many young Australians. We do not hear anything from the opposition in this debate on VSU about TAFE or the vocational sector. There are some 1.6 million Australian students in the publicly funded VET system, and yet we hardly hear a word from the opposition, we hardly hear a murmur from them, about the interests of these young Australians. Are they any less important? Are they any less significant to the future of this country? Of course they are not, and yet we hardly hear anything from the opposition about the importance of the role that those young Australians are playing in the fabric of our community. There is choice there. There is no compulsion on students at TAFE or in the VET system to pay fees, so it is quite important to note that son as well. We all know that the nature of education in this country is changing. We know that the face of student life has changed dramatically. With the rise of the internet and flexible teaching arrangements and with students coming into this country from abroad, we must be aware that the fabric of the education sector in this country is changing and that the modern campus today is certainly a world away from the campuses of the previous decades, when many of those in opposition attended them. I commend the bill very strongly to the House. I encourage all my coalition colleagues very strongly to pass this bill. Debate interrupted. NA

Speaker: The SPEAKER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Order! It being 9.00 pm, I propose the question: That the House do now adjourn. Ms Lynda Blundell

Speaker: Ms VAMVAKINOU
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I rise tonight to pay my respects to the late Lynda Blundell, a woman with a great legacy in my electorate who sadly passed away on 24 November at the age of 65 years. Lynda was one of those community members who dedicated her life to the service of others. She was a woman of great strength of character who put up a pretty good fight in her long battle with cancer. Unfortunately, it was a fight that she lost just over a week ago. Lynda was a much loved and loving mother of Noel and Kathleen and the devoted grandmother of eight grandchildren, five who live in Victoria and three who live in Queensland. Born in Tallangatta in 1939, Lynda moved to Broadmeadows in her adult life, where she spent most of her life and touched the lives of so many people. Lynda had a remarkable life. Whilst commending many of her activities tonight, I am sure there are many more lesachievements than those that I will discuss. Lynda was not one to speak of her own achievements as she did not consider what she did to be remarkable at all. It was just a part of her life. Lynda was one of those people for whom actions speak louder than words. Lynda's great achievement in her service to the community of Broadmeadows was to be the first woman elected to the Broadmeadows Council, on which she served for four years. She also became the first woman mayor in the 127-year history of that council. Even though her term on council was relatively short, she left a huge mark and an enduring legacy. Lynda had many interests, all centring on the betterment of society and involving selfless dedication to others. She worked as a youth worker, a teacher, a financial counsellor, a justice of the peace for about 13 years and a civil marriage celebrant. As everyone involved in community activism knows, we often remain driven by our occasional victories on issues that we are passionate about. Lynda had many of these passions and, thankfully, she also had very many victories-for example, as a member of the Victorian People Against Child Exploitation, Lynda was one of those who lobbied for and was successful in gaining the implementation of mandatory reporting as well as for the use of videotaped evidence by children in legal proceedings. These legal reforms remain today and they represent significant milestones in the development of the law in the state of Victoria. Another of Lynda's tireless campaigns involved assisting and advocating for the rights of workers who had been denied their entitlements after the collapse all those years of the Waltons stores. Lynda fought with and for those workers and was successful in securing their entitlements. Lynda was passionate about her union activities and was a committed and devoted unionist. For 18 years, Lynda also worked as a community development worker for the Uniting Church, where she helped so many people in her community. As testimony to this tireless work, Lynda was awarded a Churchill Fellowship in 1981. Lynda was a much deserving recipient of this honour. This fellowship enabled her to travel overseas to study legal aid, financial counselling and the history and workings of credit co-ops, which provided her with additional information and skills with which to help her much beloved community of Broadmeadows on her return to Australia. In 1988 Lynda's achievements and commitment to her local community were also recognised by the then Broadmeadows City Council, when the Lynda Blundell Community Centre was named in her honour. This is a very important and popular centre in our local community and provides assistance and support to the senior citizens, the disabled and carers in the Broadmeadows area. It is indeed a fitting tribute to a woman whose life was very much spent in the assistance and service of others. Writing was another of Lynda's passions, which was not realised until later in her life. She was a member of the Grey Scribblers group. Through this group, she contributed to the book Droplets from the Grey Scribblers, which was published in 2003. Lynda will be fondly remembered by many people in my electorate, including me. She was an incredible woman and she helped so many people in our community. All those who knew Lynda, and in particular her dearest and closest friend, Terri ago MCNaughton, who was with her to the very end, are saddened by her passing. I speak on behalf of all of them when I express my deep condolences to her family and her friends. People with the dedication and selflessness of Lynda Blundell are certainly few and far between. Her life provided a great example to others and her passing will be felt by so many in the community. Lynda Blundell was a great inspiration to all of us, in particular to all the younger and older women of the community of Broadmeadows. She will be sorely missed. Workplace Relations

Speaker: Mr LAMING
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Bowman) (9.05 pm)Thank you very much for the opportunity tonight to reflect briefly on a coalescence of events that I have enjoyed. The first of these was a visit from the Queensland Teachers Union to reflect on the events of last Friday. The second, which arrived on my desk, was the ACCI position paper Workplace reform: working for Australian women. Finally, and probably most entertaining of all, was a fascinating, signed copy of Imagining Australia: ideas for our future by the authors Andrew Leigh and Peter Tynan, who are two of the four authors who join us in the Speaker's gallery today. I welcome them. I must admit that I have already had a sneak preview of this book, which came out before the last federal election. One part struck me: Equality, opportunity and community should be our core valuesbut we mustfocus our energies on making the social challenges of today the success stories of tomorrow. Nowhere is that more important than in combating long-term unemployment. A specific part of that is to make sure that women have every opportunity to join the work force if they choose and also to have the gender pay gap minimised wherever we can. I know that I have bipartisan support on the issue of narrowing the gender pay gap. It brings me back to the visit from the Queensland Teachers Union today, when I was asked three questions, obviously after the events of last Friday. The first question was, ‘What will you do when the bad news stories roll in next year about employers who are doing terrible things to their employees and when the sky is falling in?' The second was, ‘How will you answer the critics when all of the vulnerable find themselves out of a job in large numbers?' The third was, ‘When you lose your seat, will you be prepared to negotiate an AWA?' So you can see it has been an interesting day. I would like to take this opportunity to answer these questions in the next three minutes. I am not going to start with an impassioned story about creating new jobs, because I know it is so much more than that. What we do know is that over the last 20 years we have seen substantial inroads into gender pay equity. That has continued under the most recent series of workplace reforms over the last four years. Evidence has it that the gender pay gap was 20 per cent in 1983. It has now fallen to under 15 per cent. There are continuing falls in that pay gap, even with the availability of AWAs. What I found even more compelling in this publication was not only that wages are higher for those who negotiate AWAs-and that obviously pertains to a certain selection bias-but that the gender gap narrows even more significantly for those who negotiate AWAs. That is going to continue to roll out next year and give my QTU colleague an answer, I am sure. What we have also found-and this silences those on the other side-is that, while the general number of people in part-time and casualised employment has remained fairly similar over the last 10 years, it is not how many are doing part-time and casual work but who is doing it and for what reasons. I was referred to by the Leader of the Opposition in the last sitting term as a ‘child of privilege'. I certainly was the child of a mother who could not enter the work force, no matter how hard she tried in the early 1990s when she had to help to put me through university. But I am also the child of a mother who, once she found herself back at work and preferred to leave the workplace, was unable to because she had to pay the high home loan interest rates. So even for one family, for one single person, you can see that over that period where there was poor economic management there were people out of the work force who had chosen to work but who could not, and there were others who were working and who would have prefered the option of parenthood, training or further education. The most compelling argument for the series of reforms upon which this government has embarked is providing people with choice-choice to work, educate or raise a family. Those options were not available 12 years ago the way they are now, and no amount of historical revision can convince anyone, apart from a few who sit on the other side, of that fact. The past reforms have now led to record levels of employment. Even as recently as a year and a half ago there was a reference in Mr Leigh and Mr Tynan's publication as to how tough it is to bring unemployment down; there was the reflection on how tough it is to find employment for 15to 19-year-olds. The very good news for the authors of this book, of course, is that only today we discovered that not 16 but 60 local government authorities now have unemployment rates under six per cent. (Time expired) Rail Infrastructure

Speaker: Mrs IRWIN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The southern Sydney freight line is a major project which will bring great benefit to the economy by improving interstate rail freight services. The line will run parallel to the isting southern Sydney line, through Liverpool to Cabramatta and then through to Chullora via Sefton. The line provides a rail link from Melbourne to Brisbane via Sydney, in the ownership of the Australian Rail Track Corporation. The most significant impact of the line in suburban Sydney will be the section from Warwick Farm to Villawood in my electorate of Fowler. Its most severe impact will be on Cabramatta Station, which will need to be completely rebuilt to allow for the new line. Cabramatta is a vibrant commercial centre, catering to Sydney's Asian community. While the present railway line cuts Cabramatta into two sections, the construction of a third line will result in greater separation as well as the loss of much needed parking space adjacent to the line. This impact of the line on Cabramatta is of concern to Fairfield City Council. In private and public briefings with the Australian Rail Track Corporation, the council has expressed its desire to see the Cabramatta section of the line placed underground to reduce its impact on the area. This proposal is not favoured by the corporation, and Fairfield City Council has held a meeting with New South Wales government ministers, with a view to obtaining modifications to the plans affecting suburban rail services to reduce the impact on Cabramatta. Last October, Fairfield City Council wrote, seeking a meeting with the Minister for Transport and Regional Services to express its concerns and seek the best outcome for residents and businesses in the Cabramatta area. To date, the council has not had a reply from the minister. I should point out to the House that the line is designed to carry freight trains up to 1½ kilometres long, travelling at speeds of 80 kilometres an hour. At full speed, such extrains take over one minute to pass by. At the expected capacity of the service, there will be 24 trains in each direction-that is, a train passing through every half hour, day and night. There is no curfew whatsoever on the line. The noise and vibration from these trains is excessive and requires the highest standard of track and well designed noise barriers to relieve at least some of the impact on residents and businesses in the Cabramatta area. At Cabramatta Station, there is barely enough room for the existing two lines with separate platforms. Construction of the freight line at ground level would leave almost no room for pedestrian access from Railway Parade on the western side or from Broomfield Street on the eastern side. Only the complete rebuilding of the station, either underground or with an elevated concourse, will provide an acceptable means of handling the passenger traffic at Cabramatta. I should mention that Cabramatta is an important transport link. Three train services travel to the city via Granville, Regents Park and also via the Bankstown line. Trains also travel to Blacktown on the Cumberland line. Cabramatta Station services a large population and is a hub for bus services from Cecil Hills, Bonnyrigg, St Johns Park, Mount Pritchard and Edensor Park. It is one of the busiest suburban stations in Sydney. Cabramatta is an important shopping destination, with many people travelling by to buy the range of Asian groceries and foods, and the fabrics and home wares in its many special shops. Visitors have the choice of more than 40 restaurants, serving some of the best Asian foods available anywhere in Australia. Unless a suitable solution can be found, the basic realignment of the current platforms, as proposed, will prove to be unsafe and will have a detrimental effect on commerce in Cabramatta. As I said earlier, Fairfield City Council has not heard back from the minister, and my own written requests for the minister to meet with the council have not been responded to either. I would hope that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services is not deaf to the reasonable requests of Fairfield City Council and the people of Cabramatta who are seeking to minimise the impact of this project on their comfort and amenity. Ryan Electorate: Roads

Speaker: Mr JOHNSON
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Ryan) (9.15 pm)Moggill Road is one of the worse traffic bottlenecks in Brisbane and in the Ryan electorate. In 2004 a RACQ survey revealed that over the last 10 years travel times on Brisbane's major arterials have increased significantly, and the second-worse road on that RACQ list was Moggill Road. This would be of no surprise to the residents of Bellbowrie, Kenmore, Indooroopilly and Toowong. Compared with 10 years ago, average morning trips inbound on Moggill Road take an additional 14 minutes and 41 seconds. Recently the Queensland state Labor government put forward for consideration a proposal known as the Westgate proposal-the Westgate strategic plan. This was done without proper notification of the local residents of the western suburbs, and all four recently released Westgate options contained a bridge crossing from the Wacol development into Moggill-Bellbowrie, at either Priors Pocket train Road or Weekes Road and therefore represent a significant intrusion into the community lifestyle of Ryan residents in Moggill and Bellbowrie. I want to place on the record very strongly that I oppose this plan by the Queensland Labor government-that I oppose very strongly the options put forward by the Beattie Labor government. They are unacthe ceptable and have not been thought through. To highlight how incompetent this policy has been, the Queensland government has just allowed 41 days-just over a month-for community consultation. I draw to the attention of the people of the western suburbs, in particular Indooroopilly, Kenmore, Chapel Hill, Bellbowrie and Karana Downs, that just over a month's consultation is the sort of respect they are getting from the state Labor government. Today, the member for Oxley made a personal attack on me, saying that my contribution to the Ryan community is way short of what is expected of the federal member for Ryan, but he fails to admit that I won that seat from a sitting Labor member. I remind him that he should do his homework before he attacks me. He also failed to say in this parliament whether he supports the Queensland Labor government. Does he support the four options to construct a bridge across the river from Oxley into the Ryan electorate? This is important for the people of Ryan to consider, because there are state Labor members in the Ryan electorate and they will be put on the spot to say whether they support what the Queensland government is doing or whether they support the interests of the local community. The local community is overwhelmingly against the construction of any major bridges across the river, so it is very important that the member for Oxley comes clean on this. It is very important that he comes into this chamber and either he says that he supports the Beattie Labor government or he stands shoulder to shoulder with me on this, in total disagreement with the Westgate strategic plan. The Westgate proposal demonstrates the absolute policy incompetence of the Beattie government in attempting to skirt public consultation and impose on Ryan residents a river crossing into Moggill and Bellbowrie. I have made my opposition to these Westgate proposals very clear in recent days, and I want to reassure the people of the western suburbs that in the House of Representatives and in the communities of the Ryan electorate I will have no hesitation in saying very strongly that the Labor government in Queensland should put its money into the roads. I remind the people of the western suburbs that the Labor government in Queensland has been in office since 1989, bar two years of the Borbidge coalition government, and they have done nothing whatsoever to improve the state and the condition of Moggill Road. If the people of Queensland want to have continuous car parking and congestion from sun-up to sundown, vote for the Labor government in Queensland. But if they want to have reform of the roads, and if they want to have this infrastructure deficit addressed, then I strongly encourage the people of Queensland to send the Labor government a very strong message. The GST provides to the Queensland government some $7.7 billion in funds, and how much have they spent on the roads in Moggill? Probably zero. Of course, this is something I think is very important for the western suburbs to bring to the attention of the member for Indooroopilly, in particular, because he has been quite useless in drawing this matter to people's attention. (Time expired) Child Obesity

Speaker: Ms BURKE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: In the lead-up to the silly season, when we all overindulge and we should be more wary of it, I want to talk about something that is really quite important: obesity. Last week the OECD reported that Australia is one of the most obese nations in the world, ranking sixth on the list. The figures reveal that 25 per cent of our nation's children are overweight. This is very scary indeed. According to the Australian Medical Association, childhood obesity is rising at the rate of one per cent each year, and more than half of all young Australians will be overweight by 2025 unless serious action is taken and taken now. The consequences of obesity for the nation's health are deadly, and the costs to deal with these consequences will be exorbitant. To me, this data sends a loud and clear message: we need to ban junk food advertising to children and we need to ban junk food in our school canteens. It seems pretty obvious but, sadly, the message is still not getting through to the Howard government. The coalition's response to the obesity epidemic has been to blame the parents. Senator Guy Barnett said that ‘we need changed attitudes among parents and guardians'. This follows the so called Minister for Health and Ageing's recent comments on Four Corners, when he said: If the parents are foolish enough to feed their on a diet of Coca-Cola and lollies, well they should lift their game and lift it urgently. Blaming the parents is not the answer. Yes, it is important to educate parents-indeed, all Australians-on a healthy lifestyle and good nutrition, and we need to get our kids physically active, but it is vital for the government to help parents in every way possible. Let us make their lives a bit easier and regulate junk food advertising. Let us get rid of the rubbish being sold in school canteens. In an ideal world all children would take a healthy and nutritious lunch box to school. The reality is that working parents do not always have the time and, even if they do, there is no guarantee that the healthy lunch will be eaten in favour of, or in addition to, something more tempting from the school canteen. The minister should realise that parents cannot always control their children's eating habits, especially if they are not around. I do not think it would come as a surprise to anyone that a child with $2 in their hand might choose a box of Maltesers over a box of sultanas. When advertising agencies are targeting our kids, encouraging them to try the latest and coolest new chocolate bars or soft drinks, it is even harder for parents to take control. Education is integral and we need to encourage physical activity, but we also need to take the temptation away. Having been on canteen duty last Friday at my child's school, I was mortified to see what children buy at playtime and at lunch. Filling out the school orders was a bit of a shock. My child has had three takeaway orders this year. She thinks we are very neglectful, but we would rather send her to school with a lunchbox. Sadly, it sometimes comes back home with the very healthy food that we have sent intact. When we ask, ‘What went on?' she informs us that one of her friends bought her something rather nice kids from the canteen. I must admit to treating several of her friends at the canteen myself the other day, and as a parent you often do not say no when you want to give them a treat. But we need to take away the temptation. These days, the phrase ‘like a kid in a candy store' is not really a very apt way to describe emotions such as happiness or excitement, because the canteen is the candy store. For some kids, lollies and sweets are no longer a rare or occasional treat to get excited about; sadly, they are the norm. A megasized chocolate chip biscuit for morning tea, a soft drink and a meat pie for lunch, and a doughnut for afternoon tea. It is possible for school children to eat these foods every day. In my view, there is nothing wrong with the occasional treat, but the problem is that junk food is so prevalent that it is now being seen by some people as an actual meal. Queensland has recently announced it will phase out junk food from its schools and replace it with healthy alternatives. But the Howard government refuses to follow suit and has ignored almost all the recommendations of the National Obesity Taskforce. Similarly, it refuses to regulate junk food advertising that targets children. The advertising of cigarettes has been banned and the advertising of alcohol limited. Health professionals are now labelling obesity as a risk to our nation's health similar to tobacco, but the government refuses to take on the advertising and marketing industry. At a recent health inquiry in Queensland, Prince Charles Hospital's transplant services director, Keith MCNeil, said: Prince Charles Hospital probably wouldn't exist if it wasn't for smoking or obesity. The rates of childhood diabetes and high blood pressure are rising. According to the AMA, new disorders presenting in obese adolescents include: type 2 diabetes; hypertension; fatty liver; sleep apnoea; asthma; orthopaedic complications, including postural imbalance and excessive weight bearing; and poorer psychological functioning and reduced self-esteem. Our hospitals are already under increased pressure as a result of obesity related illnesses in adults. Indeed, the epidemic is being linked not just to type 2 diabetes and heart disease but also to liver disease and various forms of cancer. What will it be like in 10 or 20 years time? Action needs to be taken now. (Time expired)  tary to the Minister for Health and Ageing) (9.25 pm)-I am quite unaccustomed to speaking on the adjournment in recent times but delighted to have the opportunity to do so. I would like to highlight to the House the messages that we are giving to young people about drug taking with two specific examples. In recent weeks we have had two reports handed down to the Commonwealth about the links between cannabis smoking and mental illness. For many decades there had been an assumption made by a number of generations that cannabis and alcohol were really interchangeable products that did not do you much more harm than each other. Over a very long period of time the impression has been built up amongst young people that cannabis is really no more harmful to you than alcohol or smoking and that those people who are worried about it just have not caught up with the fact that it is the heavier drugs that people are concerned about and not cannabis. I am not pleased to say it but I think it important that we now hang a lantern on that problem and make it clear that cannabis smoking has been found to have direct links to mental illness, particularly amongst those who start smoking cannabis when they are very young and who smoke it over a long period of time. Certainly if you have a predisposition to a mental illness it is likely that cannabis smoking will bring that outschizophrenia and other psychoses. If you do not have a predisposition to mental illness, there is still evidence that smoking cannabis can bring on mental illness. I am sure that most of us in this House are young enough to know of our own friends and family members who have smoked cannabis, thinking that they were safe and immune from damaging their health only to find that their personDrugs ality has changed over some years and decades-in some cases, tragically, leading to mental illness. For that reason, it is irresponsible for the message to continue to be given to young people that cannabis is not a serious drug. When I talk about that I am referring to state governments that continue to have decriminalised laws with respect to cannabis usefines not much worse than traffic fines and speeding fines for people using cannabis for personal use and growing it for personal use. In my own state of South Australia you are entitled to have one plant of cannabis, which is not just a plant the size of these microphones but could be the size of a housecannabis plants have been known to be as tall as houses in South Australia. Mr Johnson-Have you got one at your house?  honourable colleague. The danger this presents to young people is that it perpetuates the myth that cannabis is not a dangerous drug. That is now irresponsible on the part of is the states. The states have a responsibility to act to send a tougher message on drugs that the Commonwealth has been trying to send, particularly in relation to cannabis. The second area I want to highlight to the House with respect to messages to young people is the campaign by a group called Enlighten Harm Reduction from Melbourne, from the Speaker's own state, which seeks to test pills at so-called rave parties for young people. Many of these people are perhaps well-intentioned, but the message they are sending to young people in testing pills and giving them back to partygoers is: ‘This drug will not do you damage. We have tested it and it is safe.' The message from the government, of course, is that none of these synthetic drugs is safe. You cannot be sure what is in a synthetic drug. No pill-testing kit can ascertain every aspect of a pill, because they are constantly changing. These pills have the capacity to do you tremendous damage. At a rave party on the weekend in South Australia called the Enchanted rave party, four of the patrons overdosed on synthetic drugs. The message should have been clear to them: if you take synthetic drugs, you do not know what is in them and you could do yourself dramatic damage. The group Enlighten Harm Reduction are sending the wrong message to young people that the pills they are taking can be safe and that they can test them to make sure that they are safe. It is dangerous. I would have thought that they have established a duty of care with a person they take a pill from and test and give back to that person. They are putting themselves in tremendous danger if that person suffers some adverse reaction or even dies. I am sure my honourable friend opposite, the member for Barton, who was a solicitor before entering this place, as I was, would advise clients not to do such an action. Question agreed to.
